OSSD Guide
Rosedale Global High School

BOH4M

Business Leadership: Management Fundamentals

Grade 12, University/College Preparation — Explore leadership skills, management functions, ethics, and how to effectively lead people and organizations in the business world.

Unit 1: Foundations of Management Unit 2: Leading Unit 3: Management Challenges Unit 4: Planning & Controlling Unit 5: Organizing

Course Overview

What is leadership? How do people effectively manage others? In this Business Leadership (BOH4M) course, you will explore the development of leadership skills and how these skills are used to effectively manage people and companies. You will also understand how managers function within organizations and solve real world problems. The roles, responsibilities, skills, and functions of management will also be explored. As you learn about the factors that contribute to effective leadership practices, emphasis will be placed on the importance of ethics and social responsibility. Learning how to communicate effectively for business purposes is also embedded throughout the course. By the end of your learning experience, you should be able to clearly understand what it takes to work successfully in positions of leadership and management.

Wherever you work, whether in a large corporation, your own private company, in the public sector, or a non-profit organization, you will need to be aware of the functions of management, leadership skills, organizational plans, and how to tackle challenges. To accomplish this, we will try to use as many real world examples and cases as a tool for learning in this Business Leadership course.

Grade Breakdown

70% Evaluation Activities
(Tests + Assignments)
30% Final Project
(Part A: 25% + Part B: 5%)
1
Foundations of Management
5 Lessons + Unit Highlights + Unit Test • Sections 5-11
▼
Welcome to Unit 1. In this unit, we will be examining how businesses are organized. We will start by looking at trends that affect organizations and by assessing the role of management. Our skills focus for this unit will be on developing appropriate communication techniques specific to business management. You will use a variety of concepts and theories to develop business documents and presentations. Finally, in our ever-changing business world, we will evaluate the impact of ethics and social responsibility on company management.

Overall Expectations / Learning Objectives:

  • Assess the role of management within an organization
  • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management
  • Evaluate the impact of issues related to ethics and social responsibility on organizational management
1
1-1: What's Happening in Business? (4 hours)
▼
"A business that makes nothing but money is a poor kind of business." — Henry Ford
Businesses have changed significantly over the past 100 years, and for that matter, the way of doing business today is dramatically different than even 20 years ago. Why is that? What has caused these rapid changes? How are businesses adapting? These ideas will be explored in this unit.
Technology has been one of the major drivers of the change taking place in businesses. Consider how quickly businesses have to adapt to changing technology. As more sophisticated technology enables business to be conducted more effectively and at an ever-greater pace, it also has downsides. Given broader access to company intellectual property and practices and greater complexity in accounting and business standards, the number of scandals and ethical violations has also risen. If you read or watch the news, you will find many examples of ethical scandals. In this lesson, we will examine a few of these cases.
Lesson Overview — Key Idea

This lesson will help you understand and appreciate the various ethical issues and challenges that are prevalent in the business world today. The way businesses deal with these issues affects not only them and their employees, but society at large. You will develop the skills necessary to understand how to examine these issues and their underlying ethical roots.

Learning Goals & Success Criteria
  1. Understand major ethical issues facing businesses and their impact on society
    • I can research major ethical issues facing businesses in today's world
    • I can summarize the major ethical issue in the scandal in one or two sentences
    • I have included at least 3 links to different articles or videos for others to research further
  2. Understand ethics and how ethical dilemmas impact various stakeholders
    • I can explain the meaning of ethics and what is considered ethical behaviour
    • I understand the difference between terminal and instrumental values
    • I can state and explain the four views of ethical behaviour
    • I understand the difference between cultural relativism and universalism
    • I can explain and give a real-life example of the common ethical principles of a business
    • I can explain and differentiate the three main influences on a person's ethical behaviour
  3. Understand ethical dilemmas in the workplace
    • I can explain the meaning of an ethical dilemma
  4. Use the ethical decision making model to make a decision in a variety of business scenarios
    • I understand the ethical decision-making model
    • I can use the ethical decision-making model to examine ethical dilemmas
  5. Identify potential sources of ethical issues in the workplace
    • I can identify common ethical dilemmas in the workplace
  6. Evaluate ethical dilemmas facing businesses using the ethical decision-making model
    • I can use the ethical decision-making model to resolve ethical dilemmas
    • I can explain how people rationalize their unethical behaviour and why this can result in problems in the workplace
  7. Assess the role management plays in creating and dealing with ethical issues
    • I can explain the meaning of a whistleblower
    • I can understand what a Code of Ethics is and the areas covered in it
  8. Understand the process in responding to ethical issues
    • I understand the six steps or questions to respond to an ethical case study
    • I can find the most important information when reading a case study
  9. Evaluate the impact of major ethical issues on management strategies and decision-making
    • I can apply the six steps or questions to an ethical case study to come up with a reasonable action
Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
  • Critically thinking about ethical dilemmas and ethical decision making
  • Communicate your understanding of the underlying ethical issues
  • Analyze the impact of these ethical dilemmas on businesses and society
Business Ethics & Ethical Behaviour

What have you heard about issues or scandals involving businesses in the news recently? What headlines have been prominent in the financial world? Businesses behaving unethically and creating scandals in the media are often front page news. Why is that? In this activity, we will explore a few recent scandals from the business world to help us understand the challenges facing businesses. You will develop your analytical skills as you try to peel back the news and decipher the central ethical issues.

Page 1-1A: Scandals Rock the Business World

Learning Goals

    • Understand major ethical issues facing businesses and their impact on society.

  

Scandals Rock the Business World

Have you read or heard about businesses in the news recently? What has been happening? More and more it seems we learn about businesses that are behaving unethically and the resulting scandals are being widely covered in the media. 

Below is a video of the top three scandals of 2017. As you watch the video, think about how you would summarize and explain the key factors involved in each scandal.

So what happened? Why did each develop into a large scandal?

  1. United Airlines was the center of attention when a video of three officers dragging a passenger off of an airplane went viral. The event shocked customers all around the world. The video was viewed over five billion times, dropping United Airlines market value by about $1 billion dollars.
    • Why did it become such a scandal? Passengers had been fed up with a decline in the airlines' customer service and standards.  Now, the public believed they were witness to a situation in which a persons wellbeing was jeopardized in the pursuit of profit.
    • Question to consider: Was United Airlines' primary concern the bad behaviour and mistreatment of a paying customer, or merely that it was caught on tape, went viral, and brought plenty of negative attention to the company?


  2. Equifax, a company that collects peoples' sensitive financial and security data, had secure information stolen in the 5th largest hack in history. This affected approximately 150 million users in USA, UK, and Canada.
    • Why did it become such a scandal? In addition to being one of the biggest data breaches in history, the breach took place between May-July 2017 but the company did not announce the breach until September 2017.
    • Question to consider: Why did the government sit idle when it was revealed that three Equifax executives sold almost $1.8 million of their personal holdings of company shares days after Equifax discovered the breach but more than a month before the breach was made public?

  3. At Uber, various different underlying issues were made public:  from sexual harassment charges to evading government regulations to the CEO resigning and two top executives suddenly quitting.  Uber really won the prize for the biggest scandals of 2017 and Travis Kalanick's leadership was called into question. The first #DeleteUber led to the loss of 500,000 customers in one weekend.

    • Why did it become such a scandal?  The blatant lack of concern for it's stakeholders: employees who faced sexual harassment; drivers who struggled with falling prices; customers who dealt with surge pricing; or the wider society that perceived unethical behaviour from top executives. 
    • Question to consider: How much has the negative media attention impacted Uber and it's profitability?

Now that we have looked at three examples of the biggest business scandals in 2017, complete the following forum: 1-1A: Research Scandals

  

Success Criteria

I can research major ethical issues facing businesses in today's world.

 I can summarize the major ethical issue(s) in the scandal in one or two sentences.

 I have included at least three links to different articles or videos for others to research further.

H5P 1-1A: Scandals Rock the Business World VIDEO

Click here if you cannot see the video. 

Forum 1-1A: Research Scandals [CTA]

As you noticed these business scandals really affected Uber and United, so what were the underlying issues? It was a matter of ethics. What are ethics? Let's find out.

Page 1-1B: The Ethical Concern

Learning Goals

    • Understand ethics and how ethical dilemmas impact various stakeholders.
       

The Ethical Concern

What caused the business scandal? What went wrong? Could something have been done differently? 

Underlying scandals in the news these day lie a variety of ethical issues. In order to assess them, we will explore ethics, ethical behaviour, and the factors that influence ethical behaviour. 

What are Ethics?

What are ethics? What is considered ethical behaviour for a business? What are the various factors that influence ethical behaviour for people and businesses? All of these questions will be explored in the following lesson. Let's explore. PDF version available.

  

  

Although every organization has their own ethical codes and value systems which will in some ways be characterized by the nature of their business, who they are, and where they work, there are several ethical principles common to most businesses. Be sure you understand each of the terms below and look up definitions for the concepts you need to better understand. Research your own example of each ethical principle.

 

Three main influences on ethical behaviour

As we explored in the lesson above, there are various influences that affect ethical behaviour. What may be considered ethical for one person, may be viewed as unethical by another. Below are the three main categories of influences that affect a person's ethical behaviour: the person, the employer, and the society or external environment. See below for a breakdown of the different factors in each category.

 

 

Success Criteria

Before moving on to the next section where we will explore how these factors influence a person when faced with ethical dilemmas, make sure you understand the following:

I can explain the meaning of ethics and what is considered ethical behaviour.

I understand the difference between terminal and instrumental values.

 I can state and explain the four views of ethical behaviour.

 I understand the difference between cultural relativism and universalism.

 I can explain and give a real life example of the common ethical principles of a business.

 I can explain and differentiate between the three main influences on a person's ethical behaviour.

H5P 1-1B: What are Ethics?
Ethical Decision Making and Ethical Dilemmas

As we saw in the previous exploration, ethics are often not black and white. Often it is easy to discern that a behaviour is "right" or "wrong", but not all ethical situations generate behaviour or options that are crystal clear. Often, ethical decisions are more subtle and nuanced. To make matters more complicated, ethics and ethical behaviour are continuously being tested as individuals and companies challenge each other in the pursuit of profit in highly competitive markets. In the next learning activity, we will explore various ways of dealing with ethical dilemmas and test our ethical decision-making thinking through a variety of scenarios.

Page 1-1C: Ethical Decision Making

Learning Goals

    • Use the ethical decision making model to make a decision in various business scenarios.
       

Ethical Dilemmas

It is not always easy to say that a decision or judgement is "good" or "bad".  Often, ethical scenarios force decisions and choices that are not so easy to categorize as merely good or bad, right or wrong.  In this section, we will explore various ways of dealing with ethical dilemmas and test our ethical decision-making skills through various scenarios.

An ethical dilemma occurs when someone must choose whether or not to pursue a course of action that, although offering the potential of personal or organizational benefit or both, would/may be considered unethical.

    

Ethical Decision Making Model

So how should you make a decision when faced with an ethical dilemma in the workplace? Here is a quick flowchart of how to recognize an ethical dilemma and how we might construct options to deal with it.

Note: There are many different models and this is just one; feel free to research others.

Let's start by discussing an ethical dilemma that you as students may face in your academic life.

Consider: You have been studying hard for your math test tomorrow when your friend sends you a message on WeChat asking if you could proofread their English essay. 'Oh my gosh', you think, 'I haven't finished my essay yet.' As you frantically open your essay you notice you have done pretty good work so far, but the essay has to be 500 words, and you only have 300 words completed.  You review your outline and start researching on the internet, only to find a website that states the exact point you wanted to make. You copy and paste it into your essay. As your eye catches the time '12:47am' you debate, 'I know I should write this in my own words but maybe I'll just use the website's text ... '

How do you end your thought? Brainstorm and discuss with a partner. 

 

'... no one will know.'

'... it's just the last paragraph anyway, I wrote the rest myself.'

'... it's just this one time.'

'... my teacher saw me working on it, he will believe me.'

 Let's use this example to walk through the ethical decision making process step by step to reach a decision that is ethical. PDF version available. 

 

Ethical Decision Making

Now that you understand ethical behaviour and it's influences, the potential sources of ethical dilemmas, and a decision-making process, let's apply your knowledge to two different ethical dilemma that people have faced in the workplace. Read the following case studies and answer the questions in your notebook. Make sure to explain how you came to your ethical decision. 

1. Taking Credit for Others' Work: Employees often work in teams to create marketing campaigns, develop new products or fine-tune services, yet rarely does everyone in a group contribute equally to the final product. If three members of a five-person team did all the work, do those three members demand to receive proper credit while pointing out that two members of the team did not pull their weight?

2. Conducting Personal Business on Company Time: Because employees tend to spend so much of their weekday hours on the job, they often are tempted to conduct personal business on company time. This can include setting up doctor's appointments on company phone lines, making vacation reservations using their employer's computers and Internet connections or even making phone calls for a freelance side business while on company time. What if your spouse calls to tell you that your children are ill? Is it OK for you to schedule a doctor's appointment?

Original Source 

 

Success Criteria

Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

I can explain the meaning of an ethical dilemma.

 I understand the ethical decision-making model.

 I can use the ethical decision-making model to analyze ethical dilemmas.

Practice

Let's understand different ways of facing ethical dilemmas in the workplace through various case studies.

Page 1-1D: Facing Ethical Dilemmas

Learning Goals

    • Identify potential sources of ethical issues in the workplace.
    • Evaluating ethical dilemmas facing businesses using the ethical decision making model.
    • Assess the role management plays in creating and dealing with ethical issues in the workplace.

 

Ethical Dilemmas in the Workplace

An ethical dilemma occurs when someone must choose whether or not to pursue a course of action that, although offering the potential for personal or organizational benefit or both, would/may be considered unethical. Using the ethical decision making model explored in the previous lesson, we will examine various case studies to better understand how to analyze ethical dilemmas in the workplace. 

a. discrimination – the unjust treatment of people based on their age, race, sex, etc.
b. sexual harassment – unwanted sexual advances or obscene remarks.
c. conflicts of interest – personal and business interests are in conflict.
d. customer confidence – protecting customers private information.
e. organizational resources – using business resources for personal use.

 Image Source for Figure 1

 

Facing Ethical Dilemmas

Below are various case studies examining different ethical dilemmas faced in the workplace. As you explore each video, think about how you would use the ethical decision making model to address the issue.

 

The Ethics Guy on CNN:

Guiding question: As you watch the video, how would you face these ethical dilemmas in the workplace. 

 

Original Source: Youtube

 

Ethics at the Ritz Carleton:

Guiding question: As you watch the video, think about how your self-esteem is related to how ethical you are.

 

 

The Big Bang Theory Ethics:

Guiding question: If you were in this situation, what would you do? How would you resolve the issue? 

 

 

Rationalization for unethical behaviour

As you can see from the survey results above, it is not black and white, good and bad are not crystal clear, there are a lot of gray areas that require careful analysis and reflection.  Sometimes people use various excuses to rationalize unethical behaviour.  The four main ones are listed below:

    1. Convincing yourself that the behavior is not really illegal. This rationalization is particularly common in ambiguous (unclear) situations. A good rule of thumb is “when in doubt, don’t do it.”
    2. Convincing yourself that the behavior is in everyone’s best interest. This rationalization involves the mistaken belief that because someone may benefit, the behavior is also in the interest of others and therefore okay.
    3. Convincing yourself that nobody will ever find out what you’ve done. This argument assumes no crime is committed unless discovered. To deter this view, make sure sanctions for wrongdoing are made public and known.
    4. Convincing yourself that the organization will “protect” you. This implies the organization will condone your practices in every situation.  Organizational norms and loyalty should not be placed above the law or social morality. Generally the organization will use you as a scapegoat!

Thus, when faced with ethical dilemmas, even when people use the ethical decision-making model to apply ethical principles, decisions are not always obvious. People tend to rationalize their unethical decisions using excuses we read above, leading to a variety of business scandals that we see and ready about so frequently.  

 

How can high ethical standards be maintained?

There are many instances when faced with ethical dilemmas, that employees or even managers behave unethically. So what have organizations done to maintain high ethical standards? In recent years, people who have reported unethical behaviour of companies have been called whistleblowers, and laws have been developed to protect these employees.

Whistleblowers are people from within the organization that expose misdeeds of others to: 

  • preserve ethical standards
  • protect against wasteful, harmful, or illegal acts.

Laws protecting whistleblowers vary significantly across industries and countries, so whistleblowers may or may not be protected from various consequences such as losing their job, being blacklisted, or even legal action from the company.

 Barriers to whistleblowing include:

  • Strict chain of command
  • Strong work group identities
  • Ambiguous priorities

Organizational methods for overcoming whistleblowing barriers:

  • ethics advisors
  • ethics staff units

 

  

Companies also try to proactively develop codes to guide employees on how to behave when faced with ethical dilemmas and the consequences of behaving unethically. These behaviours and consequences are usually outline in a Code of Ethics. 

Codes of ethics are official written guidelines on how to behave in situations susceptible to the creation of ethical dilemmas.

Areas often covered by codes of ethics:

    • workforce diveristy
    • bribes and kickbacks
    • political contributions
    • honesty of books or records
    • customer/supplier relationships
    • confidentiality of corporate information

Image source for Code of Ethics

    

Success Criteria

Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

I can identify common ethical dilemmas in the the workplace.

 I can use the ethical decision-making model to resolve ethical dilemmas.

 I can explain how people rationalize their unethical behaviour which may end up causing problems in the workplace.

 I can explain what is a whistleblower.

 I can understand what is a Code of Ethics and the areas covered in it.

Responding to Ethical Cases

As we continue to study business, we will encounter ethical issues in businesses all the time. When encountering an ethical case study, how do we respond to it? In order to be prepared to respond to these ethical issues, let's explore a process to help guide us through it. We will learn the six steps or questions we need to address to determine the proper course of action when posed with an ethical issue.

Page 1-1E: Responding to an Ethical Case Study

  

Learning Goals

    • Understand the process involved in tackling ethical issues.

  

Responding to an Ethical Issue in the Workplace

When encountering an ethical issue, how should we properly analyze the issues at play and structure our response?  The following six factors need to be carefully addressed:

    1. FACTS: What are the relevant facts? Make a list of every relevant fact that is integral to the ethical issues being examined. Avoid injecting opinions or personal commentary at this stage.

    2. ISSUES: What are the ethical issues at play? First, ensure that you are dealing with an ethical or moral dilemma. Next, be sure to outline every ethical issue that is addressed or inferred.

    3. HARM: Which person, business, or entity is being harmed?  Who, or what may be harmed? Make a list of the stakeholders that are affected.  Be sure to detail in what form this harm may come.

    4. CHOICES: In each situation, outline every possible choice of action.  What are all of the different actions that you can take in this situation? Make a list of the alternatives.

    5. CONSEQUENCES: What are the consequences or results of each of your choices above? List the potential positive outcomes and negative outcomes for each alternative.

    6. ACTION: Finally, what action ultimately should be taken? Explain which action will promote the greatest good for the greatest number of people or which will produce the least amount of harm. You may also convey your own understanding of right and wrong and other personal values in your analysis of the ethical issue(s) at play. 

Let's look at a humorous example of how not to address an ethical dilemma in the workplace. The clip below is taken from the movie,The Internship, which deals with two salesmen who are computer illiterate and get an internship at Google.

As you can see, all kinds of ethical issues are addressed in the short clip above.  Several of the  characters interject what are clearly inappropriate responses to real ethical issues.  Practice addressing the six factors that you learned above so that you are properly equipped to deal with ethical issues as they arise.  As you have probably discovered, much of your personal and workplace success depend on the need to make wise ethical and moral decisions.  

Success Criteria

Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

 I can use the ethical decision-making model to resolve ethical dilemmas.

I understand the six factors that should be addressed in formulating a response to an ethical issue.  

 I can find the most important information when reading a case study.

 

Now, let's look at an ethical case study and respond to the ethical dilemma using the six steps we learned about and applying our understanding of management and organizations thus far.

Assignment 1-1F: Sample Ethical Case Study [GTA]

1-1F: Sample Ethical Decision Making Case Study

 Learning Goals

    • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2)
    • Evaluate the impact of issues related to ethics and social responsibility on the management of organizations. (A3)

This formative assignment will be assessed by your Grading Teacher in order to provide you with descriptive feedback essential to a future assignment.

Assignment Overview

 

Step 1: Read the Case Study 

    • Read the case study below and take notes on the main facts, details, and information. 

Eli Fogle has been selling SMART Board® and SMART® products for the last five years. His company, SMART Technologies®, produces education and business products that aid in teaching, learning and presentations. 

Eli has been one of the top five salesmen in his company for the last three years and is having a good year to date. Although he is not quite at his goal of 1 million dollars in sales, he is $40,000 dollars away from hitting the 1 million dollar sales mark. All he needs is one good sale and he will be able to meet his goal. Furthermore, SMART offers its sales employees a $30,000 personal bonus for getting 1 million dollars in sales. That $30,000 would help Eli build an addition to his house as he and his wife just had a newborn baby girl. 

Eli goes through all of his contacts in December, trying to find more customers to sell to so that he can make his goal - he needs about $40,000 more in sales. All of his contacts say that they are not ready to purchase right now, but may be able to in the new year. This is not good enough for Eli, who needs to sell $40,000 in SMART products before December 31st to get his bonus. He then calls Annette Smith, the principal of a poor school in Toronto. Eli knows that Annette's school cannot afford the technology, but that the students would greatly benefit from having some of the SMART tools. 

Eli offers to donate $15,000 of his own money to the school if the school were to purchase the $40,000 school package. The school would get a $40,000 technology hardware/software package from SMART and would only have to input $25,000 of their own money. It sounds like a win-win situation for Eli. He would donate $15,000, but would get the $30,000 bonus, allowing him to build the addition on his house. Furthermore, the school would get the technology they so desperately needed for a price that they could afford. 

After further thinking about the benefits to both him and Annette's school, Eli determines this was a good thing to do. Do you agree with Eli?    

 

Step 2:  Apply the Ethical Decision-Making Model 

    • Apply the ethical decision-making model by following the guiding questions and prompts below.  Write your responses in this graphic organizer. 

      • Facts: identify the major, important, and relevant case facts. 

      • Issues: identify and evaluate the ethical issues and dilemmas. 

      • Harm: outline the individuals, stakeholders, or entities being harmed.  Explain how they have been, or will be, harmed. 

      • Choices: identify and outline all possible choices that can resolve the issues. 

      • Consequences: for each choice, outline the positive and negative consequences. 

      • Action: identify and justify your selection of choice to resolve this case.  Be mindful about achieving the greatest good and least amount of harm. 

 

Step 3: Completing the Organizer

  • Complete the organizer  Use specific vocabulary from the unit in your responses. 

  • Write your answers in the organizer using complete sentences

  • Proofread and edit your organizer


    Submission Requirements:

      • Upload your graphic organizer as 1 compressed PDF file. *Make sure your file size does not exceed 100 MB

     Success Criteria

    You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

    1. I can read and understand the case study (A2.3). 

    2. I can apply the 6 steps (facts, ethical issues, harm, choices, consequences, and actions) of the ethical decision-making model to make a conclusion about the actions that should/ could be taken to address an ethical issue. (A3.1) 

    a. I can identify the most important facts in the case (A3.1)

    b. I can identify and evaluate the most relevant and important ethical issues in the case study (A3.1)

    c. I can outline the individuals, stakeholders, or entities being harmed (A3.1) 

    d. I can identify a series of choices that could resolve the issue (A3.1) 

    e. I can outline all possible consequences for each choice (A3.1) 

    f. I can develop and justify an action to address the issues of this case. (A3.1) 

    3. I can organize my ideas in a graphic organizer (A2.1; A2.2) 

    4. I can use business-related terminology effectively. (A2.1; A2.4) 

    5. I can present my ideas in an organized and logical sequence (A2.1; A2.4) 

      How to Submit

      • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
      • Click on the button below when you are ready to begin writing your assignment.

    ▼
    "Tend to the people, and they will tend to the business." — John Maxwell
    As we saw in the previous lesson, managers play an integral role in any organization. In this lesson, we will understand the fundamentals of management that are important for business success. Below, you will see some classic examples of managers who do not understand the fundamentals of management. As you can see, these managers would not be considered "good managers" and it is quite clear their views of management are skewed. To prevent you from becoming a manager like those in the video, let's explore the important role of management in organizations.
    Lesson Overview — Key Idea

    The key idea of this lesson is to understand basic aspects of management - the types of managers, the levels of management, and the functions of management. Once we grasp these concepts, we will explore organizations, their characteristics, and features. We will conclude the lesson by examining the roles and responsibilities of managers within organizations. We will focus on evaluating management functions and responsibilities within organizations while understanding that organizations and management work together to create a unique culture.

    Learning Goals & Success Criteria
    1. Explain the functions of management in an organization
      • I can explain the five functions of management
      • I can give an example of each function of management
      • I can identify the different tasks under each function of management
    2. Understand and identify the roles and responsibilities at each level of management
      • I can explain the three levels of managers in an organization
      • I can identify the responsibilities under each level of management
      • I can differentiate between the types of managers in different organizations
    3. Understand and identify the different types of managers that exist within organizations
    4. Apply the three characteristics of an organization to real examples
      • I can explain the three characteristics that define an organization and provide an example of each from a real business
      • I can apply my understanding of the three characteristics of an organization to different organizations
      • I can provide a real-world example of organization and identify the three characteristics within it
    5. Evaluate and explain the role managers play within organizations
      • I can explain the role managers play within organizations
      • I understand the different types of managers in an organization
      • I can explain the main managerial skills
      • I can evaluate the roles managers play in organizations
      • I can apply my understanding of managerial skills to come up with three different managerial skills
    Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
    • Critical thinking of the role managers play in organizations
    • Apply management characteristics to real world organizations
    • Analyze the functions of management
    Managers & Management

    As we learned in the previous lesson, many times it was managers who found themselves at the centre of business scandals. So, what roles are managers to play in organizations? Let's start by seeing whether you have the potential to be a manager.

    H5P 1-2A: Are YOU Management Material?

     This is for diagnostic purposes and will not be graded. Try to think outside of the box and have fun!

    So what is a manager? What are their roles and responsibilities? In this exploration activity, we will learn about the five principal functions of management in an organization.

    Page 1-2B: What is Management?

    Learning Goals

      • Explain the functions of management in an organization.

      

    What is Management?

    Management is a set of recurring functions carried out on the resources of a company. These functions include: planning, organizing, leading/directing, controlling, and staffing/allocating.

    The resources of a company include all of the things that a businesses utilizes to operate effectively and efficiently. These resources could include capital resources, natural resources, and most importantly human resources (employees).

    Thus, management involves planning, organizing, leading/directing, controlling and staffing/allocating resources to make a business more efficient.

     

      

    Planning

    Planning is preparing for future events. Managers need to prepare for the future so that the business can succeed in the future. If organizations do not prepare for the future, then they will be ill-equipped to deal with new situations that arise. Not only should managers plan, but they should also contingency plan (have secondary and tertiary plans) in case their original plans do not work out.

               

     

     

    Organizing

    Regardless of how prepared a business is for the future, one must also be organized. This means having things arranged in order so as to deal with them in an efficient manner. Managers must organize timetables for employees, files/data, schedules for meetings, money, use of assets, and more. Being organized allows a manager to be effective and efficient.

     

     

    Leading/Directing

    This involves communicating instructions to employees and directing when to use other physical resources. With employees, a manager needs to motivate and encourage employees to perform well. He/she must also be able to be clear and concise when giving orders. With other resources, managers need to know when and how to effectively and efficiently use the resources they are given (e.g., their budget, their capital assets, etc.)

      

    Controlling

    In business, mistakes occur. No business is perfect; however, managers can help to ensure that a businesses does not continually make the same mistakes. A good controller is able to identify mistakes when they occur and then take the necessary steps to prevent them from happening again. In the case of employees, it may mean taking corrective measures and/or retraining. With other resources, it may mean recalling them, fixing them or moving them to other areas where they can be more effective. For example, if a machine is outputting at 85% because it is old, it may be worth it to spend $5,000 of other resources (money) in order to fix it.

     

     

    Staffing/Allocating

    This function of management deals with acquiring and releasing resources. For employees, it is comprised of hiring good employees and firing employees that are ineffective or inefficient. In terms of resources, it involves knowing when and how to acquire more resources as well as when to discard and or release current resources.

     

     

    Examples

    You want to manage a school dance. You will first plan out everything that you will need to run an effective dance. You create a budget, you set a date and time, you get a venue, and you do many other planning functions.

    Then you may actually begin to staff and acquire. You may find some friends to help you and you will probably go and pick up some items that you need - like decorations.

    Finally, you get organized. You design a theme, you sort your friends into different teams to look after different parts of the dance and you create a schedule of when you will meet with everyone.

    Now you get to the most important part of management - leading/directing. Here, you tell all your friends what you expect them to do. You ensure your teams are prepared to carry out their tasks effectively whether it be ordering food or putting up the decorations. If you feel that one of your friends has more to offer than you can in a certain area, you might ask them to lead in that area.

    Next, you take control and you continually update your teams and inform them of changes and corrections. If things are not working out the way that you planned and you want to change things, you do so. If your friends come up with a better way of doing something you had already planned - you can take measures to implement their processes. You let your friends know if you would like something done differently and you take corrective measures in all areas.

    Throughout the entire process, you may also continue to staff your team. You may add more friends - creative people who can design more decorations. You may let go of (fire) some other friends because they cannot make the necessary time commitments.

    All of the above actions are functions of management. By performing them, you are trying to create the most effective and efficient dance that you can imagine.

     

    Summary Video

     

    Functions of Management - What skills are used in each function? 

    • Reflect on the skills listed in the chart below.  Which function(s) of management require each skill?  Put a check or X to indicate the functions that require each skill. 

    • PDF Available here.

    Skill

    Planning

    Organizing

    Leading

    Controlling

    Acquiring Power

    Active Listening

    Budgeting

    Choosing an effective leadership

    style

    Coaching

    Creating effective teams

    Delegating

    Developing trust

    Disciplining

    Interviewing

    Managing Conflict

    Managing resistance to change

    Mentoring

    Negotiating

    Providing feedback

    Running productive meetings

    Setting goals

    Valuing diversity

    Solving problems creatively

    Understanding a company’s culture

     

     

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section where we will explore how these factors influence a person when faced with ethical dilemmas, make sure you understand the following:

    I can explain the five functions of management.

     I can give an example of each function of management .

     I can identify the different tasks under each function of management.

     

    As we saw in the previous activity, there are many functions that managers perform in organizations. However, not all managers have the same roles or level of responsibility. In fact, there are numerous different types of managers in organizations and different levels of management. In this activity, we will explore the three different levels of management and the roles and responsibilities that are often associated with each.

    Page 1-2C: Levels & Types of Management

    Learning Goals

      • Understand the roles and responsibilities at each level of management.
      • Understand the different types of managers that exist within organizations.

      

    The Three Major Levels of Management 

    As we saw in the previous exploration, there are five main functions of management and managers at different levels have differing amounts of each of these functions which fall under their jurisdiction. The three major levels of management are: Top management; Middle management; and Lower Management. Each management level has different roles, responsibilities, activities and skills. Note the different functions for which each management level is responsible as you learn about the three levels of management below.

    Below are examples of each level of management:

      • Top-level managers: The board of directors, president, vice-president, and CEO

      • Middle-level managers: General managers, branch managers, and department managers 

      • Low-level managers: Supervisors, section leads, and foremen 

      

    Responsibilities of each Level of Management 

    Now that you have understood the three major levels of management, below we will explore the major responsibilities at each level of management. Note the overlap between responsibilities. 

     

    Types of Managers 

    Now that you have understood the three major levels of management and the responsibilities of managers at each level, we will explore the different types of managers that exist in different organizations. 

    Line vs. Staff Managers

    Line managers: Their work directly contributes to the production of the organization’s basic goods or services. Examples: Retail Managers, CEO, Plant Managers.

    Staff managers: Work in specialized support areas such as marketing, accounting, human resources, and the legal department to support the efforts of line workers. Examples: CFO, Director of Human Resources.

    Managers vs. Administrators

    Managers: Work in for profit organizations.

    Administrators: Work in non-profit organizations. Examples: Public Administrator, Principal, Hospital Administrator.

    Functional vs. General Managers

    Functional: Responsible for a single area such as accounting, engineering, marketing, human resources.

    General: Responsible for complex areas that include many functional areas. Examples: Department Store Manager, Plant Manager who oversees manufacturing, warehousing, and sales.

      

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section where we will explore how these factors influence a person when faced with ethical dilemmas, make sure you understand the following:

    I can outline the three levels of managers in an organization.

     I can identify the responsibilities under each level of management.

     I can differentiate between the types of managers in different organizations.

     

    Practice

    Let's take a moment to check our understanding of what we have learned thus far. This multiple choice quiz will test your knowledge of the different levels and types of managers. You can take the quiz only once, and the results will be recorded. However your grade on this quiz does not count toward your final mark.

     Learning Goals

    I can identify the characteristics of managers at the three different levels of management.

    Organizations

    In the first part of this lesson, we explored the roles and responsibilities of managers and the different levels of management that exist in organizations. But what are organizations exactly? Are all businesses considered organizations? Are only businesses organizations or are there many types of organizations? In this activity, we will be exploring the three basic characteristics that define organizations and explore various examples of organizations.

    Page 1-2E: What are Organizations?

      

    Learning Goals

      • Explain the three characteristics of an organization.
      • Explain the role managers play within organizations.

      • Apply the three characteristics of an organization to real-life examples.

      

    Basic Characteristics of Organizations

    An organization is a group made up of multiple people, such as an institution or an association, that has a common goal and has a purpose to carry out. The word is derived from the Greek word organon, which means "organ". View the video below to learn the three characteristics of an organization.

    Organizations

      • A collection of people working together to achieve a common purpose.
      • Three characteristics:
        1. Purpose: an organization has a specific purpose and sets goals to create a good or service to meet that purpose.
        2. Division of labour: within an organization, the different tasks required to meet the purpose are assigned to different people.
        3. Hierarchy of authority: organizations have a level-by-level management structure of increasing responsibility.

    Managers

    • A person who is responsible for the work of others.
    • Examples: CEO (Chief Executive Officer), supervisor, plant manager.
    • Must co-ordinate human resources (people) with material resources (information, raw materials) to produce goods and services.
    • A manager’s responsibility is to obtain the highest level of performance for the least amount of inputs.

     

    CONSIDER: If you were an organization, when would you put customers first? Think of a fast food business who deals with customers on a continuous basis.  What must their approach be?

     

    Real Life Examples

    Choose an organization with which you are familiar and explain how you know that it is an organization.  Post your answer, along with supporting evidence, in the padlet below. Do not use an example that already exists in the padlet below; be sure to use your own unique example.  

      

      

    Success Criteria

    I can explain the three characteristics of an organization and provide an example of each from a real business.

     I understand the role managers play within an organization.

    I can apply my understanding of the three characteristics of an organization to different organizations.

     I can provide a real world example of an organization and identify its three primary characteristics.

    Management & Organizations

    So how do we allocate managers? What hierarchy is established within organizations? In this exploration activity, we will examine organizations, their basic characteristics, and how managers fit within organizations. The focus in this section will be on the skills required by managers at different levels within organizations. We will also apply our understanding of managers in organizations, and begin to think deeper about the skills a manager needs in order to be successful.

    Page 1-2F: Managers Managing in Organizations

    Learning Goals

      • Evaluate and explain the role managers play within organizations.

      

    Managers Managing Organizations in Organizations

    As we have seen so far, there are three levels of management and each level of management carries different responsibilities. There are also many different types of managers in organizations.  In this exploration, we will see how managers function within an organization. For example, we will examine the different managerial skills that are needed in an organization using Katz' model of managerial skills.  Finally, we will examine the different roles managers play in organizations.   

    Managerial skills encompass the knowledge and ability of individuals in a managerial position to fulfill some specific management activities or tasks. This knowledge and ability can be learned and practiced. It can be acquired by implementing ideas, activities and tasks. What we are suggesting then is that you can develop managerial skills by learning management theory in a classroom such as this, or with real-life experience on the job.  As you go through the exploration, make notes about the different skills that it takes to be a successful manager.  Be sure to research any words or concepts that you do not understand.

     

    Managerial Skills

    Technical Skills

      • Specialized skills such as engineering, accounting, marketing, information technology.
      • Most important in lower management.

      

    Human Skills

      • An ability to interact with people.
      • Important at all management levels.

     

    Conceptual Skills

      • Ability to think critically and analytically.
      • Solve problems.
      • Most important in upper management.

      

    Katz's Essential Managerial Skills

    Robert Katz identifies three types of skills that are essential for successful management processes as outlined in the diagram below.

      

      Mintzberg's Managerial Roles

    Mintzberg's Management Roles cover ten roles and responsibilities that a manager may need to perform in the carrying out of their duties. These ten roles are then grouped into three areas: interpersonal, informational, and decisional. Read more in the chart below:



      

     

      Further Exploration

    Can you think of any more roles that would fit into Mintzberg's Managerial Roles?  List three.

    Next, think of all the skills that you possess.

    Which of your personal skills (list three) do you think will help you the most in a managerial position?

    Give reasons to support your answer.

    Success Criteria

    I understand the different types of managers in an organization.

     I can explain the main skills required by people in management positions. 

     I can evaluate the roles managers play in organizations.

     I can demonstrate my understanding of Katz' Managerial Skills.

     I can demonstrate my understanding of Mintzberg's Management Roles.  

     I can apply my understanding of managerial skills to come up with three different managerial skills.

    I can apply my understanding of managerial skills to produce three more managerial skills.

    ▼
    "My job is not to be easy on people. My job is to take these great people we have and to push them and make them even better." — Steve Jobs
    As we saw in the previous lesson, managers play many roles within organizations. How each unique management style is integrated into a larger management structure is unique to each organization. All businesses have their own corporate culture and part of the corporate culture is set by the top managers and the styles that they employ. Large companies like Alibaba tend to have many managers with different managing styles. In this lesson, we will explore influences on corporate culture and various management theories that managers draw from in the workplace.
    Lesson Overview — Key Idea

    In this lesson we will be exploring how management and organization come together to create unique corporate cultures. We will also explore how managers can influence the culture of an organization with their management style. You will be developing the skills of evaluating companies' corporate culture and assessing which management theories and styles are being used in particular organizations.

    Learning Goals & Success Criteria
    1. Understand corporate culture and its role in how a business functions
      • I understand the definition of corporate culture
      • I can provide at least three ingredients in corporate culture
      • I can provide real world examples of the corporate culture of at least two different businesses
    2. Explain how corporate culture affects organizations
      • I can explain the meaning of corporate culture
      • I can explain and give an example of at least four features of corporate culture
      • I can identify different types of corporate culture in different organizations
    3. Evaluate major management theories and practices
      • I understand the six major theories of management
      • I can provide a brief explanation of each theory and how it was developed
      • I can explain the differences between scientific, administrative, behavioural, and organizational environment management
    Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
    • Assessing corporate culture of organizations
    • Evaluate and assess management styles and theories of real businesses
    • Analyze the influence of management on corporate culture
    Corporate Culture

    In the previous lesson, we explored the various types and levels of managers along with their roles and responsibilities. Now we will examine how they work together. Do managers act independently? Of course not. There are many different people at all levels of an organization that impact the decisions that managers make. In addition, corporate culture provides another means of influence. This activity will start by brainstorming corporate culture.

    Page 1-3A: Corporate Culture in our World

    Learning Goals

      • Understand corporate culture and it's role in how businesses function.

    Managers & Corporate Culture

    In the previous lesson, we explored the various types and levels of managers at their roles and responsibilities. However, do they act independently? Of course not, there are many different influences on the decisions every manager makes. One of the major influences is the culture of the corporation in which they work.  So what is corporate culture?

    Defining Corporate Culture

    Culture refers to the values and attitudes of employees in the business or organization. Corporate culture is often called "the character of an organization", since it embodies the vision of the company's founders. The values of a corporation's culture influences both the ethical standards within a corporation as well as managerial behavior. 

     

    Corporate Culture Examples

    Let's take a look at the two pictures below: What do the pictures tell you about the company's culture? How do you think employees are valued in each company? How many levels of managers would each company employ? Which company would you want to work for?

    You probably guessed that Company A has a more hierarchical management structure while Company B has a more horizontal structure with fewer levels of managers. Company A is more structured in terms of the roles and responsibilities of management while Company B appears to employ a more flexible structure.

    So which company would you want to work for? Let's take a look at companies around us.

     

    Corporate Culture in our World

    In this activity you will brainstorm everything you can think of about Corporate Culture from businesses you know about today. For example, Google has a very famous culture.  See the example below.

     

    The purpose of this brainstorming activity is to reflect on what you already know about corporate culture based on what you see around you, the businesses you frequent, and what you hear see in the news or on social media.  Write down anything you can think of that demonstrates the culture of a corporation.

    Remember in brainstorming:

      • Write down all of your thoughts, there is no right or wrong answer.
      • Organize your thoughts into categories later, first just write down what comes to mind.
      • Everyone should participate and add in their thoughts.

    Be sure to write down your brainstorm on a sheet of paper. The brainstorm should look similar to the one below.

      

    Share your brainstorms!

     

     

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I understand the definition of corporate culture.

     I can give at least three examples of things that define corporate culture.

    I can provide real world examples of the corporate culture of at least two different businesses.

     

    We should now be aware that different companies have vastly different corporate cultures. What are the factors that influence corporate culture? Can managers influence or change a culture that has already been set in an organization?

    Page 1-3B: Influences on Corporate Culture

    Learning Goals

      • Explain how corporate culture affects organizations

       

    So what is Corporate Culture?

    Corporate Culture greatly influences how an organization is viewed both by employees, managers, other stakeholders, and the general public. Let's watch the video below about what is meant by Corporate Culture? 

     

     Influences on Corporate Culture

    As we saw, Corporate Culture greatly influences how an organization is viewed both by employees and managers as well as other stakeholders. Below are the key features of a company's corporate culture.

    Think back to the brainstorm activity:  Can you identify any of the features above in the examples? Which are the most obvious?

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I can explain the meaning of corporate culture.

     I can explain and give an example of at least four features of corporate culture.

     I can identity different types of corporate culture in different organizations.

     

    Management Theories

    Now that we understand the different influences on corporate culture, in this exploration we will attempt to determine how much influence managers have on developing corporate culture. We will also look at management theories which are implemented to help increase organizational productivity and service quality. Not many managers use a singular theory or concept when implementing strategies in the workplace. Rather, they use a combination of theories, depending on the workplace, purpose and workforce.

    Page 1-3C: Management Theories

    Learning Goals

      • Evaluate major management theories and practices.

       

    Management Theories

    Management theories are implemented to help increase organizational productivity and service quality. Not many managers use a singular theory or concept when implementing strategies in the workplace.  Rather, they often use a combination of a number of theories, depending on the workplace, company objectives, and employee composition.

     

    Evolution of Management Theories 

    Management theories have evolved over time.  Below is a diagram outlining the development of the major management theories.

        

    The Six Management Theories

    There are six management theories that are widely known.  The exploration below will help you understand how each theory was developed and what each theory states. If the learning object below does not work, you can download a pdf version. 

    Below is an infographic summarizing the major management theories.

      


     

     

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I understand the six major theories of management.

    I can provide a brief explanation of each theory and how it was developed.

     I can explain the differences between the different types of management theories such as scientific, administrative, behavioural, and organizational environment management.

    Corporate Culture & Management Theories

    Choose a company that you will research for your final presentation in Unit 1. Conduct research on their corporate culture and management style. Be sure to use a variety of sources to investigate the company. You will be asked to answer questions about the company's corporate culture and management style and make connections between their corporate culture and the management theories and characteristics of the organization culture that you have learned about.

    Assignment 1-3E: Research a Company's Management & Culture [GTA]

    1-3E: Research a Company's Management & Culture [GTA]

    This formative assignment will be assessed by your Grading Teacher in order to provide you with descriptive feedback essential to a future assignment.  

    Learning Goals

      • A1 Assess the role of management within an organization
      • A3 Evaluate the impact of issues related to ethics and social responsibility on the management of organizations

    Assignment Overview

     

    Step 1: Choose a Corporation to research.

      • Choose a large North American corporation to learn more about. 

     

    Step 2: Research the Corporation 

      • Locate 3 credible sources that provide the required information about the corporation. Suitable sources include the corporation’s website, current news articles or reports, academic articles, etc.

      • Research the corporation: 

        • Identify the corporation's name.
        • Identify and describe the management style
        • Describe the corporate culture 
        • Infer the effect the management style and corporate culture has on employees

    Create a table like the one below. Record your findings in the table. Use point form notes.

    Research a Corporation's Management and Culture 

    Name of Company  

    Description of management style. Include examples/evidence.

    (include APA in-text citations)

    		  
    Description of corporate culture. Include examples/evidence. (include APA in-text citations)  
    Inferences about the impact of management style and corporate culture on employees. (your thoughts)   
    Reference List (include APA formatted references with verifiable URL links ) 

    1.

    2.

    3.

    xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxx

     

    Step 3: Write a Research Report

    The first page of your report should include:

    • your name
    • the course name
    • the Grading Teacher's name
    • the date
    • the title of your report 

    The report should be 1-2 pages long (250-500 words) and include

    • Subheadings (C)
    • In-text citations (A)
    • References in an APA formatted list with verifiable URL links (A)
    Success Criteria

    You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

    1. I can identify and explain management styles (K)
    2. I can identify and explain corporate culture (K)
    3. I can make inferences about the impact of management style and corporate culture on employees (I)
    4. I can use business-related terminology effectively (C1) 
    5. I can organize and present my research clearly and effectively (C2)

    6. I can cite my sources using APA format. (A1)

    7. I can use in-text citations and a reference list to acknowledge my research sources. (A2) 

     

      Submission Requirements

      • Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
      • Submit your 2–3-page APA referenced Research Report as a pdf document 
      • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.

    1-4: Ethics & Social Responsibility (2 hours)

    Lesson Vocabulary

    Quizlets

    Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

    ▼
    "Real integrity is doing the right thing, knowing that nobody's going to know whether you did it or not." — Oprah Winfrey
    We began this unit by recognizing that ethical scandals have generated a consistent amount of media attention. Management and corporate culture have played critical roles in the failure of organizations to make ethical decisions. For the benefit of businesses and organizations around the world, it is ever more important for managers to have a solid grounding in ethics and corporate social responsibility. For example, Apple claims to be a socially responsible company. But are they? Workers were forced to live in cramped quarters, were routinely shouted at, worked long hours, and received low wages.
    Lesson Overview — Key Idea

    This lesson begins by exploring some historical business scandals and begins to deconstruct the underlying ethical issues. Next, we learned the six factors that should be addressed when formulating a response to an ethical situation. Finally we learned how companies try to proactively set higher ethical standards through carefully crafted guidelines that address Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR). We will apply these skills by responding to other ethical dilemmas in a case study.

    Learning Goals & Success Criteria
    1. Have explored some of the ten worst scandals in the business world
      • I understand what happened in the ten worst business scandals in history
      • I can give at least three examples of corporate culture
    2. Explain the nature of corporate ethical and social responsibility
      • I can define CSR
      • I can explain the two views on CSR
      • I understand the four different strategies of CSR
      • I can justify why I would invest in a company that is acting more socially responsibly than others
      • I can apply my understanding of ethics and corporate social responsibility to various real life examples
    3. Demonstrate appropriate techniques for making group and individual presentations
      • I can present CSR initiatives using effective presentation techniques and tools
    Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
    • Critical analysis of business scandals
    • Evaluate and apply the six step process to ethical issues
    • Application of CSR to real life business operations
    • Develop effective business presentation skills
    Corporate Ethical Responsibility

    As we saw in Lesson 1-1, scandals develop when poor ethical decisions are made. Having now understood the role that management plays in ethical decision making, we will examine the ten worst business scandals in history and analyze the role that management played. We will attempt to make sense of the underlying ethical issues that have been breached. We will conclude by evaluating the impact of these ethical issues on the management of organizations.

    Page 1-4A: 10 Worst Business Scandals in History

    Learning Goals

      • Explore the ten worst scandals in the business world.
      • Evaluate the impact of major ethical issues on management strategies and decision making.

      

    10 Worst Scandals in History

    Below you will read about the ten worst business scandals in history.  As you explore each case, carefully determine the underlying ethics that were violated.  Conduct further research on at least one case to understand it in greater detail.  

    TASK: As you read through the infographic below, write out the underlying ethical issues. Next, choose one case study, research it further, and make notes about the impact of these scandals on the company's image in the world.  Note that you will be asked to use this as an example in a future test question so ensure you understand the company and situation well. 

    Success Criteria

    I understand the nature of the ten worst business scandals in history.

     I can determine the ethical issues underlying each scandal.

     I have researched at least one scandal further on the Internet.

    Corporate Social Responsibility

    Sometimes companies can find themselves in a scandal even when they have done nothing wrong. At times this can occur simply because a company is associated with another organization that is part of a scandal. To minimize potential damage, companies try to proactively build goodwill in society by being socially responsible.

    Page 1-4B: Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)

    Learning Goals

      • Explain the nature and meaning of Corporate Social Responsibility.

     

    Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)

    All companies should do business and earn their profit in a socially responsible way.  Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is not simply about giving money to charity, it is about the methods used to earn money in the first place.  By building compliance management systems and working toward systemic change, companies can integrate socially responsible methods in their pursuit of profit.  To accomplish this, each company should carefully develop a CSR strategy.  In this section we will learn more about what that means and why it is important.

     

    What is CSR?

    Social responsibility is a business' obligation to maximize its positive impact, and minimize its negative impact, on society. There are several laws and regulations that force businesses to conform to society's standards, values, and attitudes, however it is up to the businesses to contract the ways that they meet these, at times, lofty societal obligations. While formulating a CSR strategy, we must always remember that companies examine ethical issues on an organizational level and act in ways that serve both it's own interests (the pursuit of profit) and the interests of it's stakeholders (society being one).  This is a delicate balancing act.  Some important points to consider:

    • CSR is an increasing priority for many organisations as many stakeholder and the greater society view companies through the lense of their social impact.
    • Organisations can demonstrate their social responsibility in a variety of ways; 
    • Society can gain important benefits from organizations that are committed to continuous improvement.

    Below is a video explaining the basics of CSR. Watch carefully and make notes.

    In the learning object below, we will explore the different views on CSR and the most common strategies to approach it. PDF version available. 

     

    Apply Your Knowledge: Apple's CSR

    Consider the video you watched at the introduction of this lesson about the student who went to work undercover in an Apple factory in China. What were some of the ethical concerns he raised in his video? Now consider the video that Apple created to represent it's ethical and social values. What difference do you notice? How do you feel about the video compared to the one you watched at the beginning of the lesson? Why do you think there is a disconnect between what Apple portrays and says they represent versus what we see in their supply chain operations in China? 

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I can define CSR.

     I can explain the two perspectives on CSR (one historic, one contemporary).

     I understand the four strategies to pursue CSR.

     I can justify why I would invest a company that is acting more socially responsibly than others.

    Practice

    A social responsibility audit can be used periodically to report on, and assess, an organization's accomplishments in areas of social responsibility. Here is a self-assessment to check your understanding of social responsibility. For each question, select TRUE if the company is acting socially responsibly and FALSE if they are not.

    Quiz 1-4C: Social Responsibility Audit Self-Check

      • Explain the nature of corporate ethical and social responsibility.

    For each question, select TRUE if the company is acting socially responsibly and FALSE if they are not acting socially responsibly.
