    CSR Investigation

    In this activity, you will research the Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) of a company of your choice. You will describe the company's social responsibility initiatives, environmental initiatives, employee benefits, wellness, and support programs, and business operations. You will also analyse their CSR efforts.

    Assignment 1-4D: CSR Investigation [CTA]

    1-4D: CSR Investigation [CTA]

    This is a CTA Activity.  

     Learning Goals

      • Explain the nature of corporate ethical and social responsibility.

      • Analyze a particular company's commitment to CSR and stakeholders.

    Assignment Overview

    In this activity, you will research the Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) of a company of your choice.  You will describe the company’s social responsibility initiatives, environmental initiatives, employee benefits, wellness, and support programs, and business operations.  You will also analyse their CSR efforts.  

     

    Step 1: Select a Company 

    Choose any ONE company from the list below:  

      • Google 
      • Samsung  
      • McDonald's  
      • H&M  
      • Ikea  
      • Or any popular company in your location or country   

     

    Step 2: Research your company 

      • Locate 2-3 sources that could be used to gather information about your company.  

      • Download a copy of the Analysis of a Company’s Social Corporate Responsibility Organizer.

      • Use the prompts in the table to guide your research. Research your company to find the required information and record it in the table.

     

    Step 3: Analysis of Corporate Social Responsibility 

      • Review the initiatives, programs, reports, and articles you found about your company.  

      • Evaluate their CSR practices.  Is your company socially responsible? Justify your answer using specific examples from your research to justify your answer.   

     

    Step 4: Share and compare 

    Share your findings with a classmate who researched a different company.  

      • Compare and contrast the companies that you researched. How are they similar with respect to CSR practices? How are they different?  

      • Evaluate the different companies’ CSR practices. Which company is more socially responsible? Justify using evidence from your research.  

      • Discuss what actions each company might take to improve their CSR. What impact would these actions have? 

     Success Criteria

    You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

      • I performed an in-depth research which fully and accurately portrays CSR initiatives, programs, and/or information.
      • I analyzed and described the impact of the company's CSR practices, initiatives, programs, and/or information.
      • I communicated the answers clearly and answered all the required questions.
      • I used relevant images to describe the main points.

      How to Submit

      • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
      • Click on the button below when you are ready to begin writing your assignment.
    Evaluation

    In this activity, you will apply your knowledge from this unit to assess and evaluate a case study. For this assignment, your focus will be on using and applying the ethical decision-making model, while incorporating your understanding of research scandals, business ethics, and corporate social responsibility. You must complete the APA Citations Quiz and score 100% before you can access this first summative.

    Assignment *1-4E: Ethical Decision Making Case Study 5%

     
    *1-4E: Ethical Decision Making Case Study  [5%]

    This activity will be counted in your final grade

    Learning Strands & Expectations

    • Assess the role of management within an organization. (A1) 

    • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 

    • Evaluate the impact of issues related to ethics and social responsibility on the management of organizations. (A3)  

     Assignment Overview

     

    In this activity, you will apply your knowledge of the ethical decision-making model and your understanding research scandals, business ethics, and corporate social responsibility to analyze a case study.  You will write a 300-400 word submission in the attached graphic organizer that analyzes the events of the case using the ethical decision-making model, provides a recommendation with justification, and demonstrates your understanding of the importance of corporate social responsibility for organizations. 

     

    Step 1:  Read the Case Study 

    Read the case study below and make notes of the key facts or ideas from the case.   

     

    You have recently taken up a position with your city’s news publisher as the senior editor’s assistant.  In your new position, you work closely with the senior editor and are responsible for helping to publish news that is sent out to subscribers of the paper.   

    Recently, a correspondent of your paper sent a proposed article to you about a situation that has occurred at a five-star restaurant in your city.  As it goes, it was found the restaurant was importing an illegal and protected species of fish to serve to their customers.  Moreover, the proposed article goes on to say that concerning traces of mercury were found in these fish, which implies continued consumption could be quite harmful.  Given the high-profile nature of this story, you immediately contact the senior editor about publishing this in the next day’s paper.  The senior editor acknowledges the significance of this story but informs you that such a story will not be printed.  Puzzled by this, you conduct an investigation of your own to understand why the senior editor would be against this.  In your efforts, you discover the senior editor and owner of the restaurant are close friends.  Therefore, publishing such a story might fracture that relationship.  Not to mention, it may be seen as a form of disobedience toward the senior editor if you push this story for print, which may result in your own punishment or termination. 
     
    What should you do? 

     

    Step 2:  PART A -  Assess the Case and Develop a Solution 

    Develop a solution to this case that answers the question “What should you do?” by applying the six steps of the ethical decision-making model. 

    Use the Ethical Decision Making Graphic Organizer to organize and record your ideas. This organizer must be completed and submitted. 

    • Facts: identify 3 major, important, and relevant facts from the case. 

    • Issues: identify and evaluate the key ethical issue and dilemma. 

    • Harm: outline at least 3 individuals, stakeholders, or entities being harmed.  Explain how they have been, or will be, harmed. 

    • Choices: identify and describe at least 3 choices that can resolve the issues. 

    • Consequences: outline at least 1 positive and 1 negative consequences for each of the 3 choices. 

    • Action: select one of the 3 choices to resolve this case and justify your selection using one of the 4 views of ethical behaviour from 1-1B.

      

    Step 3: PART B - Make Connections to the Case 

    • Review  Lesson 1-1B and explain 2 major influences on your ethical decision making.

    • Explain how a company's corporate social responsibility practices might influence your personal decisions..

    • Conduct research about a company or its product to provide a real world example that demonstrates your personal decisions regarding corporate social responsibility.  DO NOT use examples from the LMS. 

    • Record the reference(s) used for your research using APA. Include in-text citations for your reported research content.  

     

    Step 4: Complete the Ethical Decision Making Organizer

    • Complete the organizer  Use specific vocabulary from the unit in your responses. 

    • Write your answers in the graphic organizer using complete sentences

    • Proofread and edit your graphic organizer. 

    Submission Requirements  

    • Upload your completed graphic organizer as a PDF file 
    • *Make sure your file size does not exceed 100 MB. 

     Success Criteria

    You will be assessed on the success criteria listed below:

    1. I can identify 3 major, important, and relevant facts from the case A2.3. 

    1. I can identify the key ethical issue and dilemma A3.1 

    1. I can make inferences to identify the individuals, stakeholders, or entities being harmed.  A3.1 

    1. I can identify and describe 3 possible choices that can resolve the issues. A2.3 

    1. I can infer and describe 1 positive and 1 negative consequence for each choice. A3.1 

    1. I can select and justify my selection of choice using 1 of the 4 views of ethical behaviour from 1-1B.  A1.3 

    1. I can explain 2 major influences on my ethical decision-making using Lesson 1-1B. A3.1 

    1. I can conduct research on a company and its product and explain how a company’s CSR practices might influence my personal decisions. A3.2 

    1. .I can cite my sources using APA format.  I can use in-text citations and a reference list to acknowledge my research sources A2.5 

    1. I can communicate my understanding using relevant business vocabulary from the course. A2.4 

     

    How to Submit

      • This activity is meant to be completed by you in your own words. It is meant to bring out your own thoughts and ideas. Please ensure that you keep citations to a minimum and that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.

      • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.

      • Submit your completed assignment using the "Add Submission" button located at the bottom of this page.

    Lesson Vocabulary

    Quizlets

    Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

    For this lesson, focus on the following word:

      • Business Communication
    Click on 1-5: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
    ▼
    Communication is key to success in business, especially for organizational leaders. However, many leaders fail to communicate effectively. As you can see, communicating, and communicating effectively, are two different concepts. In this lesson, you will learn how to communicate effectively. You will also learn how communication has changed from largely a face-to-face exchange to an exchange which relies on a number of electronic means. After learning about business communication, you will synthesize these ideas with your CSR research project.
    Lesson Overview — Key Idea

    This lesson explores various business communication techniques and etiquette. As you become part of the business world in the future, you must learn the fundamentals of business communication. This will also help you to develop the skills you need to deliver your presentation in the 1-4 CSR assignment.

    Learning Goals & Success Criteria
    1. Demonstrate the effective use of information and communication technology
      • I can explain three ways in which technology has impacted communication in the workplace
    2. Use proper business vocabulary in oral and written communication
      • I understand the importance of professionalism in business communication
      • I can include proper business vocabulary in oral and written communication
    3. Demonstrate effective use of business communication documents
      • I understand the etiquette of business communication
      • I can explain technology, presentation, vocabulary, and document communication forms and methods
    4. Explain the influence of technology on business communication
      • I understand the trend in the increased use of social media in business
      • I can give three reasons why businesses do not want their employees to use social media in the workplace
      • I can explain three pros and three cons of allowing employees to use social media in the workplace
    Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
    • Develop business communication skills
    • Critically think about the influence of technology on business communication
    Business Communication

    The way that humanity communicates has changed dramatically in the last one hundred years, and especially so in the last generation. In this section we will explore the various factors that have shaped communication in the last few decades.

    Page 1-5A: Communication - Then vs Now

    Learning Goals

      • Demonstrate the effective use of information and communication technology.

      

    Communication - Then vs Now

    Communication is a process of exchanging information and transferring ideas.  Although we probably don't give it a great deal of thought, the means by which we accomplish this has changed dramatically in the last few decades.  There are many factors that have changed the way we communicate.  Can you think of three?  Take one minute to brainstorm your own ideas and then share them with a partner for two minutes.    

    Take a look at this clip from the movie, The Intern. The movie is about a 70-year-old man who becomes an intern for an online modern fashion company. This humorous clip shows how quickly the business world has moved away from a "staple" of business communication only fifty years ago:  the phone book.  It also demonstrates the vast differences in experience that employees who work for the same company may bring to the job.  Also notice the difference in how employees communicate in this clip versus how they would when the interviewee was a recent graduate and just starting his first job. Brainstorm three differences in how the workplace would have differed.   

     

    Preference Communication Type

    Workplaces span many different generations. As we have seen, technology has changed the way people communicate over time. Each generation tends to develop it's own preferred method of communication.  As businesses represent several generations, it is important to be aware of each generations' communication preferences. Below you will see an image that details various generations generations and their preferred communication methodology and characteristics.

    Success Criteria

     I can explain three ways in which is person's age dictates their preferred method of working and communicating.

    Even though the means and methods of communication has changed, we must remember that the basics of manners and etiquette have not. In this learning activity, we will examine the basics of communication and what helps, or hinders, communication.

    Page 1-5B: Communication in the Workplace

    Learning Goals

      • Use proper business vocabulary in oral and written communication.

      • Demonstrate effective use of business communication documents.

    Communication in the Workplace

    As we saw in the previous learning activity, technology has changed the way we communicate.  In previous generations, customers could write letters or visit companies in person for advice, feedback, or to resolve issues.  But today, customers can contact companies immediately by  phone, email, or the internet.  Therefore, a business' messaging and communication strategy has become a core component of their overall approach.  

     

    Business Communication Etiquette

    In previous generations, formal memos would be crafted, proofread, and then read again before being released.  In today's work environment, an average employee sends 10-50 emails per day, many on the fly, and few that are seriously proofread. Many companies even employ people to cover social media so that the company can be favourably communicated and defended to the public.    

    Although communication channels may be less formal, communication via email or text message must still be professional. 

     

    Communicating Through Technology

    Email: Email communications have largely replaced paper communications in the workplace, making email etiquette as important as proper business mail etiquette. Proper business email etiquette helps you make a favorable impression on clients, coworkers and supervisors.

     

    Communicating Through Presentations

    If you work in a business or corporate setting, you may be called upon to speak publicly for a variety of reasons. Below are some tips for delivering an effective business presentation

    Determining your purpose

    When giving a business presentation, chances are you already know your topic. To prepare, you just have to determine your purpose of presenting that topic to others. In doing so, you'll focus on what exactly you want to say.

    To determine your purpose, consider the following:

    • Audience. To whom are you presenting? What are the audience's special interests and concerns? Which part is most interesting or significant to the audience? How will they react to your topic? Are there any special or technical terms that should be defined?
    • Order of importance. What aspects of your topic are most important or most serious? Choose three or four main points.
    • Time. What can be most easily explained or discussed in the time or space allotted?
    • Purpose. What do you want the audience to know, understand, believe, or do when you are finished? The answer to this question should be clearly written and should focus on your three to four main points. The sentence below will serve as your purpose statement.

    Sample purpose statement: "By the end of my presentation on _________________, I want my audience to know/understand/believe/do _____________________, ______________________, and _____________________."

    Researching and organizing your presentation

    The next step is to thoroughly research each point so you can find evidence to support your statement. Remember, providing supportive evidence lends to the overall credibility of your presentation.

    To begin your research, check out:

      • Credible online resources
      • Libraries
      • Encyclopedias
      • Newspapers
      • Magazines
      • Expert interviews


    Look for facts, figures, statistics, and definitions. Consider using expert testimony, quotations, personal stories, and humor that will communicate your purpose. You may find it necessary to rewrite your purpose statement if you have discovered new things about your topic.

    There are several ways to organize your presentation:

      • Topical. This is best when there are several ideas to present and one idea seems to naturally precede the other. It is a common pattern used for informative and entertaining presentations.
      • Chronological. This is best when you want to organize your points using time sequence. It is a common pattern in informative and persuasive presentations, both of which require background information.
      • Problem/Solution. This is best for persuasive presentations. The first part of a presentation details a problem, while the second part presents a solution.
      • Cause/Effect. This is best for persuasive presentations. The first part describes the cause of a problem, while the second part describes its effect.

    Poorly designed presentations can leave an audience feeling confused, bored, and even irritated. Review these tips on making your next presentation more engaging.

     

    Communicating Through Documents 

    At some point in your professional life, you may need to write something. It’s nothing to be intimidated by, though! Business writing is any written communication used in a professional setting, including emails, memos, and reports. It’s direct, clear, and designed to be read quickly. With time and practice, you too can become an effective business writer.

     

    The basics of business writing

    Good business writing shares crucial information and keeps the concerns of the audience in mind. So before you write anything, ask yourself these two questions:

    What do I need to say?

    Who is my audience?

    Your answers will influence what and how you write, so take a moment to understand exactly why you’re writing. If you can’t clearly answer these questions, you’ll probably have trouble communicating effectively.

    Most business writing needs a call to action, which is information that instructs and encourages a response. Let your readers know what they should do, where to go, and so on. Provide your contact information (such as your phone number or email address) in case anyone has questions. Essentially, make sure everyone knows what their next move should be, like in the following example.

    Writing craft

    Get to the point quickly. Do you need to tell your employees about a change in work schedules or an update to company policy? Tell them what they should know upfront, and don’t leave them guessing.

    Make every sentence as short and clear as possible. Simplify your word choices, as you shouldn’t use complex words when simple ones will do. Also, cut any rambling thoughts. A company-wide memo about a health insurance change is not the best place to mention your recent fishing trip. In short, always omit needless words.

    Although you’re in a professional setting, remember to speak to others how you would like to be spoken to. Consider using a brief greeting or conclusion, especially if you’re sharing unpleasant news, and remember that saying please and thank you goes a long way. And whenever you’re in doubt as to whether something is appropriate to write, don’t include it.

    Aim to keep your paragraphs brief, as they will add focus to your message while making it easier to scan and remember. The example below is an efficient read, thanks to short paragraphs, clear sentences, and a polite, professional tone.

     

    Revision

    Good writing comes out of revision, so read over your first draft and figure out what works and what doesn’t. Clarify sentences and organize the loose structure until everything flows in a logical order. Don’t be surprised if it takes a few revisions until your document is ready to go.

    As part of your revision process, try reading your work aloud, which may reveal problems you may not have noticed before. You can also get someone you trust to provide feedback on your work. Hearing their perspective can lead to new insights and issues you never knew were there.

    Proofreading is another key part of revision. After you use a spell checker, read over your work again and look for spelling and grammar errors the spell checker may have missed. Also take a moment to ensure the information you’re writing about is accurate and up to date. If you submit incorrect information or sloppy writing, you may not be taken seriously. Does the following example look professional?

    Remember, you won’t master business writing overnight. Effective writing is a skill that takes a lot of time and practice to develop. But once you get comfortable with it, you’ll possess an incredibly valuable job skill.

     

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I understand the importance of professionalism in business communication.

     I know the business vocabulary appropriate in oral and written communication.

     I understand the etiquette of business communication to become an effective communicator.

     I can explain the technology, presentation, vocabulary, and document communication forms and methods.

     

    Impact of Technology on Business Communication

    As technology has changed the way we communicate, one of the more popular debates related to communication in the workplace involves the explosion of "Social Media". Let's discover more in this learning activity.

    Page 1-5C: Social Media in the Workplace

    Learning Goals

      • Explain the influence of technology on business communication.

    Social Media in the Workplace

    In this lesson, we will examine how social media has become more and more prominent in business and society.

    Let's begin by taking a look at another clip from the movie The Internship.

    Now let's take a look at the impact of social media on society and how we relate to each other and share information.  As the video below notes, "Social Media isn't a fad, it’s a fundamental shift in the way we communicate."   

    The video underscored how social media is changing the world and how vital is has become to conducting business.   However, there are some drawbacks:  employees productivity decreases as social media use increases.  Brainstorm:  How can companies effectively address this?  What other drawbacks come with increased social media use? 

    As you consider the questions above, consider the following statistics and information:

      

    Pros and Cons of Social Media in the Workplace

    Despite widespread use of social media and its unquestionable growth and importance in business, we also know that many companies are choosing to restrict access in the workplace.

    Decide for yourself:  Does social media really affect worker productivity?  How so?

    What are some advantages of allowing social media in the workplace?

    What are some disadvantages?

    The following article discusses the pros and cons of allowing social media in the workplace. As you read the article, rewrite the the pros and cons in your own words on a separate sheet of paper, or in an electronic word processing document. Click on the article here.

     

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I understand the underlying reasons for the upward trend in social media use.  

     I can give three reasons why businesses do not want their employees to use social media in the workplace.

     I can explain three pros and three cons of allowing employees to use social media in the workplace.

     

    Vocabulary (Quizlet)
    Business Communication
    Learning Log: 1-5 (Target: 2 hours) — Questionnaire
    R
    1-6: Unit 1 Highlights (Review)
    ▼
    These unit highlights will summarize the main concepts from the lessons of Unit 1. You can also use this page to check if you understand all of the concepts covered in Unit 1 and prepare for the unit test.
    1-1: What's Happening in Business?

    This lesson helped you understand and appreciate the various ethical issues and challenges that are prevalent in the business world today.

    Business Ethics & Ethical Behaviour

    • Vocabulary: Scandal, Ethics, Ethical Behaviour
    • Review how scandals that happened in the business world can have impact on society (e.g. data management breach of Equifax)
    • Understand the four views of ethical behaviour: Utilitarian View, Individualism View, Moral-Rights View, and Justice View
    • Explain real life examples of ethical principles

    Ethical Decision Making & Ethical Dilemmas

    • Vocabulary: Ethical Dilemma, Ethical Decision Making Model, Whistleblower
    • Explain how the ethical decision-model can be used to analyze ethical dilemmas and make a decision
    • Identify and explain common ethical dilemmas in the workplace

    Responding to Ethical Cases

    • Understand the six factors: Facts, Issues, Harm, Choices, Consequences, and Action
    1-2: Management Fundamentals

    Managers & Management

    • Vocabulary: Management, Administrator, Functional Manager, General Manager, Line Manager, Staff Manager
    • Understand the five functions of management: Planning, Organizing, Leading, Controlling, and Staffing
    • Identify the three levels of management
    • Discuss the difference between the types of managers in different organizations

    Organizations

    • Vocabulary: Organization, Goal, Division of Labour, Hierarchy of Authority
    • Identify the three characteristics of an organization: Purpose, Division of Labour, and Hierarchy of Authority

    Management and Organizations

    • Vocabulary: Manager, Managerial Skills
    • Identify skills required by people in management positions (Technical, Human, Conceptual)
    • Understand Katz Essential Managerial Skills
    • Explain Mintzberg's management roles: Interpersonal, Informational, and Decision Roles
    1-3: Management Theories & Corporate Culture

    Corporate Culture

    • Vocabulary: Culture, Corporate Culture
    • Explain the key features of a company's corporate culture

    Management Theories

    • Vocabulary: Management Theories, Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, Fayol's Administrative Principles, Scientific Management Theory, Administrative Management Theory, Behavioural Management Theory, Systems Theory
    • Understand the six theories of management
    • Explain Fayol's five rules of management and key principles
    • Describe Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs: Physiological, Safety, Love/Belonging, Self-Esteem, Self-Actualization
    • Explain McGregor's Theory X and Theory Y
    1-4: Ethics & Social Responsibility

    Corporate Ethical Responsibility

    • Vocabulary: Auditing, Bankruptcy, Debt, Depreciation, Fraud, Inflation, Loan, Stakeholder, Stock, Stockholder
    • Understand the worst scandals and determine the ethical issue underlying each scandal

    Corporate Social Responsibility

    • Vocabulary: Corporate Social Responsibility, Zone of Compliance, Zone of Conviction
    • Explain CSR and the two perspectives on CSR
    • Understand the four strategies to pursue CSR: Obstructionist, Defensive, Accommodative, Proactive
    1-5: Business Communication

    Business Communication

    • Vocabulary: Business communication, Etiquette, Maturists, Baby Boomers, Generation X, Generation Y, Generation Z
    • Understand the various generations and their communication methodology
    • Explain the various forms of business communications: Technology, Presentation, and Document

    Impact of Technology on Business Communication

    • Vocabulary: Technology, Social Media
    • Explain the influence of social media in the workplace
    T
    1-8: Unit 1 Test
    ▼

    You've reached the end of the unit! Review the skills you've learned throughout the recent lessons to prepare for your test and best ensure your success.

    Test Overview: This test is designed to be completed in 60-90 minutes. The test will remain open for 2 hours to accommodate special circumstances that may arise in each classroom.

    Remember to read the questions carefully and be sure to check your work before pressing submit. Do not leave any questions blank.

    All responses will be graded according to the KICA Achievement Chart.

    Quiz *UT-1: Unit 1 Test 7%
    2
    Leading
    4 Lessons + Reflection + Unit Highlights + Unit Test • Sections 12-19
    ▼
    Welcome to Unit 2 - Leading. What is leadership? What makes some leaders more effective than others? How can leaders make teams work more productively in their place of work? These are all questions we explore in this unit titled, "Leading". We begin by exploring the characteristics and skills of leaders and understanding the attributes that make leaders effective. We will also explore human behaviour so that we can better understand group dynamics. We will also have the opportunity to explore teamwork techniques that can be used in building functional and successful teams. Finally, you will also investigate your own leadership skills and styles. Lead on!

    Overall Expectations / Learning Objectives:

    • Demonstrate an understanding of human behaviour and how it contributes to functional and successful groups and teams
    • Demonstrate an understanding of group dynamics
    • Demonstrate an understanding of proper leadership techniques in a variety of situations
    1
    2-1: What is Leadership? (3 hours)
    ▼
    What is leadership? What makes a good leader? What skills make leaders effective? The leader of a group came up with a quick-thinking solution to a potentially fatal problem. You also witness how the concept of successful teamwork goes hand in hand with strong leadership. In this lesson we will be exploring the concept of leadership in a variety of contexts. We will begin by learning about the characteristics and skills that make a good leader. Further, we will understand the roles that leaders play in organizations and the functions they perform in the workplace. By the end of this unit you will have a good idea of what makes "good" leaders.
    Lesson Overview — Key Idea

    The key goal of this lesson is to generate an understanding of leadership, the main characteristics and skills of a leader, and the importance of leadership in the workplace. An opportunity will also be given to assess your own leadership characteristics and skills.

    Learning Goals & Success Criteria
    1. Identify key characteristics and skills of leaders
      • I am able to list two characteristics of leaders
      • I can explain how leadership is shown in real life using an example
      • I can list two skills that leaders demonstrate
      • I can explain how a leader has demonstrated this skill in real life through an example
      • I can list the top ten characteristics and skills of a good leader
      • I can identify which characteristics and skills leaders use in a workplace
    2. Understand what makes a leader effective
      • I can explain three things that make a leader effective
      • I can explain Simon Sinek's approach to business leadership
      • I can explain the difference between leaders and those who lead
    3. Learn about your own characteristics and skills of leadership
      • I can examine others' top ten list and look at it critically
      • I have learned about my own characteristics and skills of leadership
    4. Explain the difference between managers and leaders
      • I can understand the different roles played by managers and leaders
      • I can state and explain at least three ways in which managers and leaders are different
    5. Understand transformational leadership
      • I can explain transformational leadership
    Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
    • Evaluate your own leadership characteristics and skills
    • Self-assess leadership styles
    • Create a plan for improving skills and building leadership
    Characteristics of an Effective Leader

    In this activity, you will research contemporary leaders and explore their unique characteristics and skills. By the end of the activity, as a group, you will come up with a list of characteristics and skills that make great leaders.

    Page 2-1A: Contemporary Leaders

    Learning Goals

      • Identify key characteristics and skills of leaders.

      

     

    Leadership characteristics and skills

    Have you ever worked with a great leader? What was it about that person that made them a great leader? What characteristics and skills did they possess? Let's begin by understanding the definition of "characteristics" and "skills". 

                      

         

    Characteristics are qualities with which people are born.  While they can be developed, it takes a significant amount of nurture and experience. Skills, on the other hand, are abilities that can be developed more quickly; they can also be learned or acquired. In this activity, you will research leaders' characteristics and skills.


     

     

    Leaders in our Time activity

    Individually, select an individual that you believe is a strong, contemporary, leader.  This could be someone you have read about or seen on television or the internet, or simply someone you have heard of and about whom you would like to learn more.  Research and make an entry in the padlet below, listing two characteristics and two skills which make them a strong leader. Write one example or situation in their life where they demonstrated their personal characteristics and another story or example for when they showed that particular skill. See the example for Elon Musk below:

    EXAMPLE: Elon Musk

    Characteristics:
    - visionary
    - risk taker
    Space X was the first private company to launch a rocket.

    Skills:
    - technically skilled
    - persuasive / influential 
    He had the technical skills to develop the Teslas which are fully electrical car.

     

      

    Top 10 characteristics and skills

    In the next learning activity, you will create a list of the 10 most important “characteristics” and “skills” of leaders. Reflect on the different leaders you have read about.  Have a conversation with a classmate or peer and discuss a few different leaders.  What characteristics and skills helped make each leader successful? Which characteristics and skills do you think are most important in determining whether a leader is effective or not?  

    Record these characteristics or skills in your notebook. 

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I am able to list two characteristics of leaders.

     I can explain how these characteristics are demonstrated using real life  examples.

     I can list two skills that great leaders demonstrate.

     I can explain how a leader has demonstrated this skill in real life using at least one example.

    Page 2-1B: Characteristics and Skills of Leaders

    Learning Goals

      • Identify key characteristics and skills of leaders.

      

    Who is a Leader?

    As you can see in the definition below, in different contexts, leaders and leadership can have different meanings. For the sake of our course, we will define a leader as someone who influences the actions and attitudes of others to achieve certain results. 

      

    What are the characteristics and skills of a good leader?

    In the previous activity, you generated a list of characteristics and skills that you believed effective leaders should have.   

    CHOOSE ONE OF THE ARTICLES below.  Read the article and compare and contrast your own list of characteristics and skills with those listed in the article.  How did your list change?  Were there any characteristics and skills that you added? Deleted? Changed? What does your “Top Ten” list of characteristics and skills look like now?   

    Top 10 Qualities that make a Great Leader by Tanya Prive. You can download the pdf here. 

    The 9 Traits that Define Great Leadership by Peter Economy. You can download the pdf here. 

    The Characteristic of Leadership - 7 Important Traits by Leadership Toolbox. You can download the pdf here. 

    Finalize your list of the top ten characteristics and skills of a leader and post it in Forum 2-1C: Top Ten Characteristics and Skills of a Leader.

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I can list the top ten characteristics and skills of a great leader.

     I can identify which characteristics and skills leaders use in the workplace.

    Forum 2-1C: Top Ten Characteristics and Skills of a Leader [CTA]

    In this exploration, you will probe effective leadership even deeper. Mahatma Gandhi, Nelson Mandela, and Martin Luther King Jr. are considered effective leaders who were benevolent. However, Benito Mussolini, Vladimir Lenin, and Genghis Khan are considered effective leaders who were less than virtuous. In both cases, what made these leaders effective?

    Page 2-1D: What makes a leader effective?

    Learning Goals

      • Understand what makes a leader effective.

      

    What makes a leader effective?

    A society's values largely determine whether the leadership of an individual has been negative or positive.  But the core qualities of a leader are more complicated to measure and not necessarily determined by the overall effect they have had on society.  For example, there are many examples of “good” (e.g., moral, noble, virtuous) and “bad” (e.g., corrupt, immoral) people who have been extremely effective leaders.  List three who would fall into each category.  

    Simon Sinek on Leadership

    In the following TED Talk on Leadership by Simon Sinek, he explains what he believes what makes a leader effective and what that does for people with whom he/she works. As you watch the video, keep the following questions in mind:

      • What is Sinek's Golden Circle?
      • How does it relate to leadership?
      • What does Sinek suggest should be the goal of business?
      • Sinek suggests that, "There are leaders and those who lead."  Explain what he means.  You can use the examples of Langley and the Wright Brothers or Apple or TiVO or Martin Luther King Jr. to help you answer the question.

    Great leaders are effective when they inspire action. In Sinek’s concluding remarks, he states that leaders need to inspire and that people follow those who lead because they inspire.  In your evaluation you will be asked to explain if you agree or disagree with this statement.  Second, evaluate Sinek’s explanation of great leadership.  Do you agree or disagree?

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I can explain three characteristics or skills that make a leader effective.

    I can explain Simon Sinek's theory of leadership and successful businesses.

     I can explain the difference between leaders and those who lead.

     I can take a position on Sinek's theory of the Golden Circle.

    Difference Between Managers and Leaders

    Effective leaders are able to inspire action. How is this important in the workplace and in organizations? Companies have managers who are in charge of employees, but does that automatically mean that all managers are good leaders? What is the difference between a manager and a leader?

    Page 2-1E: Difference between Leaders and Managers

    Learning Goals

      • Explain the difference between managers and leaders.

      

    Effective Leaders Inspire Action.

    Effective leaders are able to inspire action. How does this happen in the workplace and in organizations? We are now familiar with the concept that managers are in charge of employees, but does that automatically mean that all managers are leaders? What are the similarities and difference between a manager and a leader?  The following learning activity will clarify.

      

    Effective Leadership at Facebook

    When Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's creator, wanted to take his company public, there was a lot of talk that he should step aside as the CEO of the company. Why?  Although he was a great leader and visionary in creating and bringing Facebook to life, there were questions about his ability to manage and run a large organization. Some situations can demand a manager rather than a leader.  Other situations or roles demand a visionary, great orator, orleader rather than a manager.    

    Read the article Is It Time for Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg to Step Aside as CEO?

    You can also download a pdf version.  

     

    Differences between Managers and Leaders

    As you read through the infographic below, re-write each of the 17 differences between leaders and managers. Create a small graphic that you would associate with each area of comparison.

    If you cannot view the infographic, you can download the PPT here. 

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you can do the following:

    I can understand the different roles played by managers and leaders.

    I can state and explain at least five ways in which managers and leaders are different.

    Practice

    In this self assessment, you will be given an opportunity to understand your own characteristics and skills of leadership. Leadership is diverse and there are many facets that need to be considered when looking at leadership in society and in the workplace.

    Page 2-1F: Are YOU a Leader?

    Learning Goals

      • Learn about your own characteristics and skills of leadership.
      • Understand transformational leadership.

      

    My Leadership Skills and Characteristics 

    Mindtools.com is a website that allows people to learn about management, leadership and personal excellence. On this website you will find a self assessment called,  "The Leadership Motivation Assessment", which assesses how motivated you are to be a leader. Keep in mind, the tool uses the characteristics and skills we've studied thus far to complete the assessment. 

    Complete the self assessment. You can find the test here: The Leadership Motivation Assessment. Or you can use this document.

    Below the assessment you will find the results. You will need the results for the evaluation for this lesson. 

     Keep in mind this is only one test. You are encouraged to explore other online assessment tools to learn more about yourself.

     

    Transformational Leadership

    After reading the page above, you may have noticed the topic of "transformational leadership" arise.  To demonstrate transformational leadership, watch the video clip from the movie School of Rock below.

    As you have just seen, this was an example of transformational leadership because the teacher was acting as a role model to his students.  In addition, he motivated them to buy into, and deliver, his vision. Finally, the teacher created an environment where both the teacher and student tried to raise one another to the highest level possible.

     

    Key points to take-away

    Leadership skills should be constantly refined, cultivated, and developed.  Every single job opportunity, no matter how senior or junior it may be, involves some form of leadership.  Strong leaders make the people around them better.  Do you?

    The rewards of leadership are great.  Good leadership can transform people and organizations into effective and functional teams with high levels of success. 

    Source: www.mindtools.com 

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you can do the following:

    I have learned about my own characteristics and skills as a leader.

    I can explain transformational leadership and cite numerous examples.

    Discussion Forum

    This next activity will give you the opportunity to demonstrate your learning. Now that you have completed the lesson, participate in the discussion forum.

    2-2: Understanding Human Behaviour (2 hours)
    Quizlet 2-2: Vocabulary Quizlet

    Click on 2-2: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
    ▼
    Leaders need to be able to understand each member of their team. In this lesson we will explore human behaviour and how it impacts the roles people play and the dynamic in their teams. What factors influence how people behave? Do you know what kind of personality you possess and how that works with others? In this lesson we will explore how human behaviour affects organizations.
    Lesson Overview — Key Idea

    The central theme of this lesson is human behaviour and its impact on the workplace.

    Learning Goals & Success Criteria
    1. Explain the relationship between a person's attitude and her or his behaviour in the workplace
      • I can identify at least five different types of personalities in a typical office
      • I understand the different roles people play in an office environment
    2. Analyse the elements that shape human personality and their impact on human behaviour
      • I can identify at least three influences on a person's personality
      • I can cite an example of how an influence has shaped or affected a person's personality
    3. Analyse personality assessment tools and their impact on human behaviour
      • I can explain each tool and its purpose
      • I can communicate what I learned about myself as I took a personality test
      • I can explain why I agree or disagree with the test and provide a reason
      • I can give at least one reason why employers find personality tests useful
      • I can identify two personality tests and briefly explain each
      • I can list at least two advantages and two disadvantages for each personality test
      • I can explain two reasons why a business would benefit from using personality tests
    4. Explain the relationship between job satisfaction and an individual's personality, attitudes, and perceptions
    5. Explain the relationship between a person's attitude and behaviour in the workplace
      • I can define attitude and behaviour
      • I understand the connection between attitude and workplace behaviour
      • I can explain the benefits of a good attitude and positive workplace behaviour
      • I can explain the consequences of negative workplace attitudes on the organization
    Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
    • Analyze human behaviour
    • Critically evaluate personality types
    • Assess the benefits of using personality assessment tools in the workplace
    Shaping Human Personality

    Have you considered why people behave in the manner that they do? In short, there are many different types of people with varied and diverse personalities. Let's examine this theme in more detail and how it impacts the many interactions people have in the workplace.

    Page 2-2A: Personalities in the Office

    Learning Goals

      • Explain the relationship between a person's attitude and her or his behaviour in the workplace.

      

    Personalities in the Office 

    Working in an office is a bit like joining a family, everybody has their own roles and personalities.

    Everyone has their own backgrounds, working style, strengths, and weaknesses. But one thing that unites everyone is the office culture. However, different personalities means that disagreements will always happen, which affects creativity, productivity, and satisfaction at work.

    The following list has 7 popular personality types you may run into at the office: 

      • The Workaholic: This person is the first in the office and the last one to leave. They are independent, don’t have time for meetings, and rarely ask for help.

      • The Caretaker: Every time a coworker needs to vent, The Caretaker is the go-to person. They’re always there to look after everyone and make sure they’re okay.

      • The Delegator: Opposite of The Workaholic, The Delegator regularly delegates their work to other people. While they may think no one’s on to them, they’re probably mistaken. You may want to take note of this type of employee.

      • The Chatty Cathy: This employee loves to tell good stories and gossips. They would rather spend the whole day chatting with colleagues than checking items off their to-do list.

      • The Feeder: This person is the most likely to bring in tidbits, candy, donutes, and other treats to share. The pantry will always be full when this person is around. 

      • The Downer: Downers often complain about workload, coworkers, management, and personal issues. 

      • The Upper: This person raise spirits without even trying. When team morale is low, they’re there to bring it right back up.

    Below is a fun flow-chart infographic to measure these traits based on common practices such as whether employees meet deadlines, enjoy work, and more. Answer the following to see what personality trait you have:

    Original Source

    Success Criteria

    I can identify at least five different types of personalities in an office.

     I understand the different roles people play in an office environment.

     

    What shapes our personalities? Parents, culture, friends, and media are among the more influential factors. In this activity, students will use introspection to determine what factors have most influenced their personalities.

    Page 2-2B: Influences on Personality

    Learning Goals

      • Analyse the elements that shape human personality and their impact on human behaviour.

    Influences on Personality

    There are as many personalities in the world as there are people. There are many things that influence a person's personality such as parents, culture, friends, the media, and many others. Think about what influences have most shaped your personality.

     

    Who has Influenced Me?

    Create a new post explaining what your three biggest influences have been and explain how they have influenced you. You do not have to write your name, you can keep this completely anonymous. After you have completed your post, compare it to what other people have written.  What do you have in common? What are the differences?  What do you notice are the greatest influences?

     

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I can identify at least three influences on a person's personality.

     I can cite an example of how an influential factor has shaped or affected a person's personality.

     

    Assessing Your Own Personality

    Now that you have identified the biggest influences on personality, it's time to discover more about your personality. There are many different types of personality tests: some assess your strengths and weaknesses and others assess which career you are best suited for. Many managers use tools and tests designed to help identify personality traits in employees. Some examples include the Myers-Briggs, True Colours, Big Five Personalities, and Emotional Intelligence tests.

    Page 2-2C1: Myers-Briggs Type

    Learning Goals

      • Analyse the elements that shape human personality and their impact on human behaviour.
      • Evaluate the use of personality traits assessment instruments in the workplace.

      

    Personality Test 1: Myers-Briggs Types

    One of the most common personality assessment tools available is the Myers Briggs Type Indicator personality test. It was created by the mother-daughter duo of Katherine Briggs and her daughter Isabel Briggs-Myers, and is based on the research of Carl Jung.

    Myers-Briggs Test: Take a free Myers-Briggs Test. If the website does not work, try Myers-Briggs Test 2. 

    Below is a short summary of the 16 different types resulting from the Myers-Briggs Personality Test and the best jobs suited for each personality type. Do you agree with this categorization? Do you think it would be helpful for employers and employees to refer to the chart below in their hiring process? PDF version.

        

    Success Criteria

    I can explain one personality test in detail, including its advantages and disadvantages.

     I can compare and contrast two different personality tests.

     I have taken one personality test to help me understand myself better.

     I can evaluate the use of personality tests in the workplace.

     

    Page 2-2C2: True Colours Test

    Learning Goals

      • Analyse the elements that shape human personality and their impact on human behaviour.
      • Evaluate the use of personality trait tests as instruments in the workplace.

       

    Personality Test 2: True Colours

    Which colour are you? You will fall into one of the these four category colours: GOLD, GREEN, ORANGE, BLUE. Learn more about the True Colours Test to find out which colour matches your personality. 

    True Colours Test: Take a free True Colours Test. If the website does not work, try the paper test created by the University of North Carolina.

    The True Colours Test was also developed based Carl Jung's research as well as the previous personality test created by Myers-Briggs. Although developed by Don Lowry in 1978, the origins of the theory can be traced all the way back to 428 BC, the time of Plato. Variations of this theory were also found in Ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia.

    Below is a summary of the traits that belong to each colour. How accurate was your guess? 

     

    Success Criteria

    I can explain one personality assessment in detail, including the advantages and disadvantages.

     I can compare and contrast two different personality assessments.

     I have taken one personality test to help me understand myself better.

     I can evaluate the use of personality assessments in the workplace.

     

    Page 2-2C3: The Big Five Personalities

    Learning Goals

      • Analyse the elements that shape human personality and their impact on human behaviour.
      • Evaluate the use of personality tests as instruments in the workplace.

        

    Personality Test 3: The Big 5

    We have explored a variety of personality tests, but one of the most basic ones assesses people's personality based on five major traits.  Not surprisingly, it is called the Big 5 Personality Test. Below are the five major categories into which each personality falls.  In this activity, explore these 5 traits in detail and take the Big 5 Personality Test for yourself.

    In contemporary psychology, the Big 5 factors of personality describe five broad areas which define human personality and account for individual differences. PDF of article available here.

    Initially developed by the US Air Force in the 1950s, it was further developed into the Big 5 Personality Traits in the 1990s. 

    It is important to note that each of the five personality factors represents a range between two extremes. For example, extraversion represents a continuum between extreme extraversion and extreme introversion. In the real world, most people lie somewhere in between the two extreme ends of each dimension. Below are short explanations of each of the traits and an easy way to remember the Big 5 Personality Traits is the acronym O.C.E.A.N.!

      1. Openness - People who like to learn new things and enjoy new experiences usually score high in openness. Openness includes traits like being insightful and imaginative and having a wide variety of interests.
      2. Conscientiousness - People that have a high degree of conscientiousness are reliable and prompt. Traits include being organized, methodic, and thorough.
      3. Extraversion - Extraverts get their energy from interacting with others, while introverts get their energy from within themselves. Extraversion includes the traits of being energetic, talkative, and assertive.
      4. Agreeableness - These individuals are friendly, cooperative, and compassionate. People with low agreeableness may be more distant. Traits include being kind, affectionate, and sympathetic.
      5. Neuroticism - Neuroticism is also sometimes called Emotional Stability. This dimension relates to one’s emotional stability and degree of negative emotions. People that score high on neuroticism often experience emotional instability and negative emotions. Common traits include being moody and tense.

    In the workplace, the Big 5 is used to pace employees in their work. Below is a short video explaining its application in the workplace. 

    OPTIONAL EXTENSION: If you would like to explore the Big 5 Personality Traits further, you can access these websites, or the pdf versions of the articles:

    Video 1: Explaining the 5 personality traits

     

    Article 1: The Big 5 Personality Traits by Kendra Cherry, pdf version. 

    Article 2: Deconstructing your personality into 5 basic traits, pdf version. 

     

    Success Criteria

    I can explain one personality test in detail, including the advantages and disadvantages.

     I can compare and contrast two different personality tests.

     I have taken one personality test to help me understand myself better.

     I can evaluate the use of personality tests in the workplace.

     

    Page 2-2C4: Emotional Intelligence

    Learning Goals

      • Analyse the elements that shape human personality and their impact on human behaviour.
      • Evaluate the use of personality tests as instruments in the workplace.

        

    Personality Test 4: Emotional Intelligence

    Much of ones success in the workplace is traditionally thought depend in large part on ones intelligence.  And intelligence is most often measured by something called "Intelligence Quotient".  This is more commonly referred to as "I.Q".  But more recently, there is increasing emphasis on measure people's "Emotional Quotient".  This has become known as "E.Q.".  But how can EQ be a better predictor of success than IQ? Let's get an introduction to Emotional Intelligence through the video below:

    We may be familiar with how Intelligence Quotient (IQ) is measured:  through a series of questions on short-term memory, analytical thinking, mathematical ability and spatial recognition. However, is that all that there is to intelligence? More recently, experts have discovered that there is much more in need of measuring.  One area that has been recognized as growing in importance is Emotional Quotient (EQ), which was introduced by Daniel Goleman in the 1990s. "Emotional intelligence is having one’s ability to perceive and express emotions, understand and reason with emotions, and effectively manage with emotions. This goes not only for yourself, but with others." 

    Here are some of the differences between IQ and EQ:

    It has been discovered that a combination of a high EQ and IQ creates successful leaders, so much so that many companies are now measuring EQ in the hiring and promotion process. Below are some statistics that demonstrate how people with a higher EQ tend to be more successful leaders in the workplace. PDF version available.
     

    Which is a better measure of potential success - IQ or EQ? Why?

      

    The good thing about Emotional Intelligence is that it can be developed. Below are a few ways in which you can develop your EQ.  Choose one of the ways stated below, or come up with a way you can develop your EQ. List the steps you need to take in order to further develop your EQ.

    Success Criteria

    I can explain one personality tests in detail, including the advantages and disadvantages.

     I can compare and contrast two different personality tests.

     I have taken one personality test to help me understand myself better.

     I can evaluate the use of personality tests in the workplace.

     

    Attitude and Job Satisfaction

    Our personalities shape how we interact with the world and the people with whom we work. In this exploration we have examined how our personalities inform our attitudes and express our skills and characteristics and how they, in turn, ultimately shape our suitability for a wide variety of jobs and careers.

    Page 2-2E: Attitude and Job Satisfaction

    Learning Goals

      • Explain the relationship between job satisfaction and an individual's personality, attitudes, and perceptions.
      • Explain the relationship between a person's attitude and his or her behaviour in the workplace. 

    Your view of the world

    How you see the world around you will shape your attitude. Do you see negativity, want, and discord?  Or do you see positivity, plenty, and harmony?  How you perceive the world interacts with your personality to shape your attitude.

     

    What is Attitude?

    An attitude is a manner of feeling or thinking that shows a person’s disposition or opinion.

    Attitudes are positive, negative, or neutral. A manager reflects a positive attitude when she says, “My team is the best in the business.”

    There are three components to attitude. The ABC’s of attitude are:

    1. Affective (or emotional), i.e., the component which relates to a person’s feelings toward an issue, object, event, person, or idea. E.g., the manager feels harmonious and positive about members of her team.

    2. Behavioural, i.e., the component which relates to how a person intends to respond or behave. E.g., the manager's hard work motivates his team members to do the same.

    3. Cognitive, i.e., the component which relates to a person’s knowledge and beliefs. E.g., the manager ensures that members of her team share her belief that all customers are to be treated with dignity and respect.

      

    Attitudes and Behaviours

    Attitudes and behaviours are not the same. Attitudes are usually a good predictor of behaviours, but not always.

    When a person’s attitudes and behaviours do not match, psychologists call this cognitive dissonance.

    Can you think of a time when your attitude didn't match your behaviour? This dissonance usually makes a person very uncomfortable and results in an attempt to regain balance or order. This balance can only be regained by correcting the behaviour and trying to make amends, or changing ones attitude and accepting the behaviour.

    Some people may also attempt to excuse the behaviour and blame it on a temporary lapse in judgement brought about by a particular situation.

    Positive Workplace Attitudes and Behaviours

    What attitudes should managers possess and model in the workplace? What are the attitudes that managers like to see in their employees? Here are five attitudes that are helpful in any workplace:

      1. strong commitment to the job,
      2. loyalty,
      3. courtesy,
      4. humility, and
      5. integrity.

    Ideally, a positive workplace attitude will lead to positive workplace behaviour. At most successful businesses, you can expect to see these behaviours:

      1. Low rates of absenteeism,
      2. Employees who show up each day on time (punctuality),
      3. Desire to do a good job,
      4. Respect for the boss, other employees, and customers.

      

    Attitudes in the Workplace

    Managers are very interested in employee attitudes. They want to ensure that their team of workers are happy in their jobs because happy employees are often more productive.

    Optimistic people often have a positive outlook on work and as a result their performance is usually better. Pessimists, because of their negative outlook, are often not satisfied with their jobs and studies show that their performance often is inferior to optimists. 

    Research also demonstrates that employees with a significant organizational commitment, high job involvement, and a positive attitude have lower turnover rates, less absenteeism, and higher job performance. Organizational commitment is the degree of loyalty to the organization an individual demonstrates. Job involvement is the extent to which an employee is dedicated to their job.

    Managers really want to seek out people for their teams that are committed to the organization and get the job done well.  This is why organizations are turning more and more to personality testing to help them determine employee personality fits and attitudes before making  hiring decisions. Many people with poor outlooks on life can manage, at times, to come across as happy well-adjusted individuals; but a well-designed personality test is much more difficult to fake.

      

    Attitude and Job Satisfaction

    Let's take a look at the example below of two monkeys. Why is the monkey receiving cucumbers satisfied with cucumbers at first, but then not satisfied? Inequalities frequently happen in the workplace.  What are the consequences of perceived inequalities?

    Employees can develop a poor attitude toward work if they feel they are receiving inadequate compensation, find the work unfulfilling, get wrapped up in workplace politics, or involved in hostile communication. Managers need to be aware of every employee's perspective and opinion of their work.  If they see changes in an employee's attitude then the manager should work with them to resolve any problems and issues so performance is not affected longer term. In general, it is in their own self interest that managers and executives help their employees maintain a positive outlook because happy employees are productive employees.

     

    Success Criteria

    Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

    I can define attitude and behaviour.

     I understand the connection between attitude and workplace behaviour.

     I can explain the consequences of positive and negative workplace attitudes on the organization.

    Practice

    In this assessment, you will bring together your understanding of personality tests, how businesses use them, attitudes and job satisfaction. You will use prior business experience/knowledge and research from the internet to link two personality tests to businesses.

    Assignment 2-2F: Personality Tests in Business Assignment [CTA]

    2-2F: Personality Tests in Business Assignment [CTA]

    This is a CTA Activity.  

     

     Learning Goals

      • Analyse the elements that shape human personality and their impact on human behaviour.
      • Evaluate the use of personality tests as instruments in the workplace.

    Assignment Overview

     
    Step 1:  Choose a Personality Test 
    Select one of the personality tests below  
    - Myers-Briggs Test: https://www.16personalities.com/free-personality-test Myers-Briggs Test.or Myers-Briggs Test 2 
    - True Colours Test: True Colours Test 
    - The Big 5 Personality Test: here or here 
    - Emotional Intelligence Test: Emotional Intelligence Test 
     
    Step 2:  Complete the Personality Test 
     
    After selecting a personality test, complete the test.  Record your results in the chart below and make point-form notes of any key findings, insights, or ideas. 
     

    Name of Personality Test: 

    Result: 

     

     

    Key Findings/Insights/Ideas: 

     
     
     
     
     
     
    Step 3:  Compare, Contrast, and Reflect 
     
    With a partner, or as a class, discuss the results of your personality tests.  Use the following questions to guide your discussion: 
    - What did you learn about yourself? 
    - Do you agree or disagree with the findings/outcome? 
    - What are the advantages and disadvantages of your personality test? 
    - Suppose you were managing a business; would your choice of personality test be an appropriate test to use?  If so, explain why.  If not, what other personality test would be appropriate? 
    -What factors might make your test less or more appropriate to use? Consider things like cultural factors, education levels, length, etc. You may wish to do some research to see what people say about the tests.  
     
    Exemplar: 
     
    I have decided to take the Myers-Briggs test. 
     

    Name of Personality Test: 

    Result: 

    Myers-Briggs 

    INFJ-T, “Advocate” 

    Key Findings/Insights/Ideas 

    More emphasis on deeper interactions 
     
    Open-minded and value originality 
     
    Importance placed on empathy and cooperation 
     
    From taking this test, I learned that I am an Advocate (INFJ-T), which is a role that is seen as a quiet visionary and inspiring idealist. 
     
    I agree with the results of the test because, although I like my time spent alone, I also appreciate the opportunity to engage in deeper interactions.  I would also agree that empathy and cooperation are valuable to me in how I approach various situations in my life. 
     
    I think the advantages of this personality test are that it’s quite detailed and thorough, which means results are likely to be accurate and fitting.  The scale provided is also helpful in determining an accurate result.  However, due to the complexity of some questions in the test, it may also skew results if those questions aren’t understood. 
     
    If I was managing a business, I would certainly look to use this personality test as a tool.  I believe that such a detailed and thorough test would allow me to learn a lot about my employees with regards to who they are, which could assist me in effectively interacting with them and putting them into comfortable situations in the workplace.

       

       Success Criteria

      You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

       I can explain each tool and its purpose. 

       I can explain what I learned about myself as I took the test.

       I can explain why I agree or disagree with the test and provide a reason to support my point of view.  

       I can give at least one reason why an employer might find a specific personality test very useful.

       I have answered the specific questions in each of the explorations.

       I have asked at least one question about the personality tool to push my own thinking and in doing so enabled a classmate to reply to my post. 
      Personal Leadership Skills Assignment
      Assignment 2-2G: Personal Leadership Skills Assignment [GTA]

      2-2G: Personal Leadership Skills Assignment 

       Learning Goals

      • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 
      • Apply an understanding of human behaviour to explain how individuals and groups function in the workplace. (B1) 
      • Demonstrate an understanding of proper leadership techniques in a variety of situations. (B3) 

      This formative assignment will be assessed by your Grading Teacher in order to provide you with descriptive feedback essential to a future assignment.

      Assignment Overview

      The following assignment will assess your ability to discuss and apply the concepts you have learned and prepare your work in a presentation.  You will read the instructions provided and construct your work in a creative and engaging manner.  You are to only use the LMS and its resources to fulfill the requirements of the assignment.  Outside research is not required. 

        
      Task 
      As a successful CEO, you have been invited to speak on a panel with other leaders to speak briefly about yourself to a group of business professionals.  Due to the vast amount of people attending this event, you have only a short period of time to make your impact.  Your task is to prepare a video presentation (with PPT) about yourself as a leader.  Be sure to draw on your key leadership characteristics and your personality, reflecting on the appropriate course resources. 
       
      Step 1: Prepare your Presentation.  
      • Carefully read the task description above. 
      • Create a 3-4 slide presentation that will be 1-2 minutes in length using the suggested outline below:  
        • Slide 1:  Introduction 
          • Introduce yourself and your history as a CEO 
        • Slide 2 and 3: Personality/Leadership Characteristics 
          • Briefly identify your personality.  Include the results or insights from the personality test or personality assessment instrument that you used. 
          • Identify and describe the key leadership characteristics. (e.g., integrity, drive, vision, commitment to equity and diversity in the workplace) 
          • Identify the leadership characteristics that are true about yourself and explain how they are true.  
          • Reflect on at least 2 events or examples in your life that demonstrate each of your leadership characteristics in action. Explain the example and how you demonstrated leadership.  
        • Slide 4: Conclusion 
          • Formally close your thoughts 
          • Provide one piece of leadership advice to your audience to leave a lasting impression. 
      • Use the vocabulary, terminology, and concepts from the course.  
      • Use point form on your slides. It is not necessary to create full paragraphs. If you do, make sure you do not read from it when recording your video.  
      • Organize your main ideas so that they are logical. Use transition words to move from one idea to the next.  
       
      Step 2: Record your Presentation.  
      • Practice delivering your presentation until you are comfortable and can summarize your main points without hesitation or stumbling over words.   
      • Speak loudly and clearly.  
      • Speak in a formal tone. Avoid contractions, slang, and informal language. This is an academic presentation.   
      • Speak in full sentences.  
      • Speak at a reasonable pace.   
      • Focus on maintaining good eye contact! Do NOT read your notes or text. Look at the camera.  
      • Pay attention to your body language, facial expressions, and hand gestures. Look interested.   
      • Make sure you can pronounce all the words you are using. If not, practice.  
      • Enunciate clearly.  
       
      Record your presentation. Find a quiet space to do your recording. Ensure that when you are recording, your face, shoulders, and hands are visible.  
       
      For more support on how to make an effective presentation, please review the Academic Skills Module How to Present Effectively 
       
       
      Submission Requirements  

        • 1-2 minute Video PowerPoint submission (3-4 slides) along with an uploaded compressed PDF of your PowerPoint slides. 

         Success Criteria

        You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

        1. I can identify the characteristics of effective leaders (e.g., integrity, drive, vision, commitment to equity and diversity in the workplace) that I demonstrate.  
        2. I can identify and describe my personality using the results and insights from different personality tests and instruments. (B1.4) 
        3. I can use appropriate business vocabulary to explain my ideas. (A2.1) (A2.4) 
        4. I can present my ideas using effective presentation techniques.  
        5. I can present without reading directly off my notes/script. 
        6. I can speak at an appropriate pace and tone (with inflection) 
        7. I can identify and reflect on the leadership characteristics that I demonstrate. (B3.1) 
        8. I can provide specific examples that demonstrate the application of each of the leadership skills in my life (B3.1) 

          How to Submit

          • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
          • Click on the button below when you are ready to begin writing your assignment.
        Vocabulary (Quizlet)
