        Feedback Reflection 1 [Work Habits, Learning Experience, and Teacher Support]
        3
        2-3: Leadership Theories & Styles (4 hours)
        ▼
        In our previous lessons, we explored the characteristics and skills of leaders, what affects personality and behaviour in teams, and the dynamics of groups within organizations. In this lesson, we will explore leadership through the lens of some of the greatest leaders the world has ever known, including Nelson Mandela's philosophy of leadership. There are many ways leaders can be effective. Mandela's leadership style was to lead by example and inspiration. In this lesson, we will bring together our understandings from previous lessons and explore the interactions between leaders and their teams. We will examine different types of leaders and their various styles. At the end of this lesson, you will present a theory or "style of leadership" along with a business leader that best exemplifies your chosen theory or style.
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        Understand major leadership styles and theories.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Recall the characteristics and skills of leaders and what makes an effective leader
        2. Connect theories and styles to real world leaders
          • I understand leadership in different contexts
          • I recall the characteristics and skills of leadership and what makes a leader effective
          • I can identify different leadership styles in different leaders
        3. Understanding different leadership styles
        4. Describe how these styles are exemplified by a variety of business leaders
          • I can describe the five leadership styles
          • I can explain when each leadership style is effective and when it is ineffective
          • I have researched examples of business leaders that fit each leadership style
        5. Understand leadership theories
          • I can explain at least five different leadership theories
          • I can link real life examples to at least five different leadership theories
        6. Learn what infographics are and how to create them
          • I understand the most important elements in creating an infographic
          • I can identify the main elements of creating an infographic
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Apply understanding of leadership theories in a variety of contexts
        • Create an infographic
        Leadership Styles

        Let's explore some great leaders and their styles.

        Page 2-3A: Great Leaders and How They Lead

        Learning Goals

          • Recall the characteristics and skills of leaders and what makes a leader effective.
          • Connect to real world example of leaders.

          

        Who are the Greatest Leaders you know?

        Let's start by taking a short quiz:

        • Name the three richest people in the world.
        • Name three of the world's most well known celebrities.
        • Name three presidents of countries outside of North America.

        How did you do? Not many people would do well. Let's try again:

        • List a few teachers who have helped you in school.
        • Name three friends who have helped you when going through a tough time. 
        • Name someone who has made you feel special.
        • Name someone who has inspired you. 

        Was that easier to do? Most people would say absolutely, yes!

        Why was it easier to complete the second series of questions? The people who make a difference in your life are not the ones who make the most money, have the most awards, or possess the most power. They are simply the ones who care most about you.

         

        Who are the Greatest Leaders in history?

        According to TIME magazine, leaders are people who have influenced the world in a significant way. Below is a video of the top five greatest leaders in history. As you watch the video, answer the following questions individually, then discuss your answers with a partner.

        • How familiar are you with the five leaders?
        • Research the leaders you know very little about and see if you agree that they are among the greatest leaders in history.
        • What leadership characteristics and skills do they exhibit? Would you consider them effective leaders? Why or why not

        Leaders can have a positive or negative influence over the world. This video will highlight the positive contributions of the five great leaders in history. However, you should also keep in mind that these leaders had their own biases and prejudices that influenced their political decisions. 

        Do all of the leaders lead in the same way? Each of the leaders from this video had a different leadership style. For example, Martin Luther King was considered a charismatic leader. In the following activities, we will explore the different leadership styles and theories to help us better understand the ingredients of leadership.

         

        Further Reading

        Biography.com has selected a different list of leaders that they feel have influenced the world over a longer period of time. Click here to explore Biography.com's List of Top 100 Leaders.

        Success Criteria

        I understand leadership in different contexts.

         I recall the characteristics and skills of great leadership and what makes leaders effective.

         I can identify different leadership styles in different leaders.

        As we learned in the previous activity, leaders have many different styles, forms, and types of leadership. In this activity, we will explore the different styles and the ingredients of each.

        Page 2-3B: Leadership Styles

        Learning Goals

          • Understanding different leadership styles;
          • Describe how these styles are exemplified by a variety of business leaders;  

        Leadership Styles

        Every leader has a different way of leading, over time, these have been categorized into the leadership styles, go through the learning object below to explore these leadership styles. 

        Being a leader is a lot like being an entire hockey team. There are different players and positions on a hockey team but they all have the same goal. A leader plays different roles when they manage. Sometimes they need to be firm or direct to get people to follow decisions. Sometimes they need to get opinions and suggestions from other people before they decide what to do. And, finally, there are times when they have to inspire or lead people to achieve better things.

        But, how can one person be all these leaders at once? They do not have to be. Just like in a hockey game, you need special players for special occasions. Let's have a look at some of the leadership styles and recognize when we need to be that leader.   

        We will be focusing on just these five main leadership styles: autocratic (also known as authoritarian), democratic, laissez-faire, collaborative & charismatic. 

          

         Now that you have completed the reading, check your understanding by completing the following quiz: 2-3B: Leadership Styles Self-Check

         

        Applying Leadership Styles to Business Leaders

        Find a business leader that has the five leadership styles stated above as an example, be sure to write down what makes you think the business leader has that specific leadership style. Share your findings with a partner to make sure your examples are correct. 

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can describe the five leadership styles.

         I can explain when each leadership style is effective and when it is ineffective. 

         I have researched examples of business leader that fit each leadership style.

         

        Quiz 2-3B: Leadership Styles Self-Check

        Take the quiz below to check your understanding. Don't worry, this quiz will not be counted in your final grade, but it is a useful tool for you to practice this lesson's concepts. Good luck!  

        Leadership Theories

        Every leader has their own leadership style. Decision-making is another element of leadership with which is attached leadership theory. We will explore these theories in the following learning activity.

        Page 2-3C: Leadership Theories

        Learning Goals

          • Understand leadership theories.

            

        Style vs Theory

        The difference between leadership styles and inherent traits is subtle, but important. Leadership style refers to the methods used to manage a group of individuals. In addition, leadership style refers to the methods and theories used to solve problems and make decisions. In contrast, leadership traits describe the characteristics and personality traits that are common among leaders or those in a position of authority. Typically, leadership traits encompass physical, emotional, social and intellectual characteristics.

        Leadership Styles

        Managers exercise control over their employees, just as world leaders exert control over a country. Leadership styles run the gamut from autocratic, in which leaders have complete control, to a more participative style, in which leaders encourage participation and feedback from employees. Other leadership styles can include a bureaucratic leadership style, which requires all team members to adhere to strict rules and procedures, and a laissez-faire style, which leaves team members to their own devices when completing work.

        Leadership Traits
        Leadership traits represent the individual characteristics that go into creating a specific leadership style. They represent characteristics such as self-confidence, ambition, and high energy.  These and other traits are common among great leaders. Other leadership traits include the ability to communicate effectively, motivate others and multitask. These traits allow leaders to formulate a leadership style that will move their teams or departments toward accomplishing company goals and initiatives.

        Considerations
        The type of leadership style most appropriate for managers and supervisors in a small business will vary. For instance, managers in an environment in which safety is a main concern, such as a construction job sites, will need to have more of a bureaucratic leadership style. This is because following procedures to the letter is a necessary part of ensuring safety in that environment. An organization can also benefit from having several different types of leaders throughout the organization to better match the needs of each department and team.

          

        Leadership Theories

        Using the video below, take notes about the following ten Theories of Leadership.  As they are being introduced, evaluate each and consider: "Do I agree with this theory"?   "What have I observed in my own life that lends credibility to each particular "Theory of Leadership"?  Each of these theories is worth of further research and reading.  Be ready to examine one.

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can explain at least five of the ten leadership theories.

         I can give real life examples for at least five of the different leadership theories.

        Infographics

        What do you do when you have a lot of information to communicate or convey but you want it to be colourful and visually appealing? One way is to use an infographic. In this exploration, you will learn what infographics are, what they are used for, and what are their main elements. You will use this information to create your own infographic for a leadership theory or style in the assignment at the end of this lesson.

        Page 2-3D: What is an Infographic?

        Learning Goals

          • Learn what infographics are and how to create them

           

        Infographics

        Infographics are visual presentations of information that use the elements of design to display content. Infographics express complex messages to viewers in a way that enhances their comprehension. Images are often an extension of the content of a written article, but infographics convey a self-contained message or principle.

        If a road sign has too much information on it, then it is difficult to read. Infographics compress and display this information in a visually pleasing way so that drivers don’t miss the message. Infographics communicate complex data quickly and clearly, and they are considered to be effective worldwide.

         

        Why Use Infographics?

        Infographics are used for the following reasons:

          • To communicate a message,
          • To present a lot of data or information in a way that is compact and easy to comprehend,
          • To analyze data in order to discover cause-and-effect relationships,
          • To periodically monitor the route of certain parameters.
          • Infographics are composed of three important elements:

         

        Visual Elements

          • Color coding
          • Graphics
          • Reference icons

         

        Content Elements

          • Time frames
          • Statistics
          • References

         

        Knowledge Elements

          • Facts

         

         Infographic examples

        To see more examples, go to the following web site:

        https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-infographics-2016

        For PDF Version, Click Here

           

        Creating Infographics

        Watch the following video to get some general information about infographics:


         

        To help you with the assignment in 2-3F: Create an Infographic for a Leadership Theory or Style, take a look at the following tools.

        TIPS:

          1. Stick with ONE of these tools until you feel comfortable how to use.

          4. HAVE FUN!

        Once you get comfortable with one of these tools, start your research and deciding how to create your infographic.

        1) Piktochart – www.piktochart.com

        Look at the following tutorial on Getting Started with Piktochart below. If you would like to learn more about Piktochart visit this website: https://piktochart.com/video-tutorials/

        The video below shows how to add icons, images, and text in Piktochart. For more detailed points on how to use Piktochart, watch the videos in: https://piktochart.com/blog/video-tutorials-learn-use-piktochart-in-no-time/

        2) Canva – www.canva.com

        Below is a tutorial on using Canva.If you wish to learn more about Canva, visit https://www.sitepoint.com/infographics-with-canva-tutorial/

        If you wish to use canva, visit www.canva.com to signup.

        NOTE

            1. You will have to use the Blog Graphic and
            2. Make sure you use the free fonts, graphics, etc. where indicated.

         

         

         3) Easel.ly -  https://www.easel.ly/

        The following website provides tips for using easel: https://easel.ly/introduction-to-infographics

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I understand the most important elements in creating an infographic.

        I can identify the main elements of creating an infographic.

        Evaluation

        The summative evaluation for this lesson involves creating an infographic for one leadership theory or style you have researched. You will use the tools explored in 2-3C "Creating an Infographic" to stylize and present your research. Your leadership theory will be chosen with your teacher's permission from a list.

        Assignment *2-3E: Leadership Theory Presentation 5%

         
        *2-3E: Leadership Theory Presentation [5%]

        This activity will be counted in your final grade

        Learning Strands & Expectations

        • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 
        • Apply an understanding of human behaviour to explain how individuals and groups function in the workplace. (B1) 
        • Demonstrate an understanding of proper leadership techniques in a variety of situations. (B3)  
        •  

         Assignment Overview

        NOTE TO CLASSROOM TEACHERS:

        On tasks where students have a choice of topic, as CTs, please ensure an equal and fair distribution of ALL topics among your students. In other words, if you have 10 students and students have 4 topics to choose from, ensure that not all 10 students are writing on 1 topic.

        This will help reduce the ACVs that arise due to lack of variety within the class.

        There are a number of strategies that you can use to distribute the topics to students:

        a) Place a limit on the number of students that can choose the same topic-pairs.  In this assignment, there are 12 topics; so there a significant number of topic-pairs available. 

        b) Ask students to select their topic-pairs on a first come first serve basis. Discourage the overuse of 1 specific topic in the topic-pair choices; ie.  Avoid a situation where most of the class selects Charismatic Leader as 1 of their topics. 

        c) Randomly place topics in a hat, and allow students to draw their topic.

        d) Assign students a topic-pair (least preferred as it removes student choice).

        Remind students that all work should in their own words and their own thoughts and that collusion is not allowed. Failure to follow this will result in an ACV report  - which is often a zero on the assignment. 

        Please visit the CT Instructional Resource Centre for more instructional strategies.   

        Step 1: Select two leadership theories  

        • Choose two of the twelve leadership theories mentioned below. 

        • The Great Man Theory 

        • Lewin’s Leadership Styles – Autocratic, Democratic, Laissez-Faire 

        • The Contingency Theory 

        • The Trait Theory of Leadership 

        • The Skills Theory of Leadership 

        • The Style Theory of Leadership - Managerial Grid 

        • The Situational Leadership Theory 

        • Transactional Leadership

        • Transformational Leadership 

        • Collaborative Leadership Style 

        • Charismatic Leadership Style  

        • Servant Leadership Theory 

         

        Step 2: Conduct your Research and Complete the Graphic Organizer 

        • Locate at least 4 reliable sources for your research (in addition to the LMS) that provide information on your selected leadership theories.  Record the information required to cite the sources using APA format on your Graphic Organizer

        • Research your 2 leadership theories.   

        • Compare and contrast your two leadership theories by addressing the following:  

        • Explain each theory. Include specific details and elaboration in your explanation.

        • Identify when each theory was created. 

        • Identify the creator of each theory. 

        • Identify and describe 1 major criticism (pitfall/ disadvantage/gap) of each theory. 

        • Identify and describe 1 positive feature of each theory.

        • Use your research and provide 1 real world example for how each theory has been applied in business. Be specific and provide context in your explanation.  

        • Evaluate the 2 theories and determine which is a more effective leadership theory in modern day business. Explain your rationale and provide context.

        • Record your notes in the Graphic Organizer.  Point form notes are recommended.  

        • Submit your Graphic Organizer as a pdf with your final presentation/report.  

         

        Step 3: Create your Presentation  

        • Use the information in your Graphic Organizer to prepare your presentation. Your presentation should present all of the information you have researched about both leadership theories 

        • Follow the guidelines on the Graphic Organizer to help you organize the content and length of the presentation. Your slide deck should be between 9 - 12 slides.  

        • Create your presentation. 

        • In-text citations and a reference list should be completed on both the graphic organizer and your presentation slides.

         

        Step 4: Record your Presentation 

        • Practice your presentation so you are able to deliver without reading and hesitation. Your presentation should NOT exceed 3 minutes.  

        • Review and incorporate the feedback you received on your oral presentation skills in the Graded Formative 2-2.  

        • Record your presentation while presenting your slides in a video presentation.  Make sure you are clearly visible in the video.

        • Submit your final Presentation video, along with a pdf of your PPT and graphic organizer.

         

        Submission Requirements  
        • 3 Minute Video PowerPoint submission (9-12 slides, including Title Page slide) along with an uploaded compressed PDF of your PowerPoint slides. The last slide must be an APA formatted Reference page.  Be sure to include APA formatted in-text citations in your slides. Include a pdf of your Graphic Organizer.  
        2 Submissions in Total:   
        • Compressed Video file  
        • PPT and Graphic Organizer as 1 compressed pdf 

                    

         Success Criteria

        You will be assessed on the success criteria listed below:

        1. I can research two different leadership theories.  
        2. I can describe and identify key facts about the different leadership theories. (B3.2) (B3.3) 
        3. I can organize my research and plan a presentation using a graphic organizer. (A2.1) 
        4. I can compare and contrast different leadership theories to determine criticisms of each theory. 
        5. I can compare and contrast different leadership theories to determine the positive features of each theory.  
        6. I can use appropriate business vocabulary to explain my ideas. (A2.1) (A2.4) 
        7. I can present my ideas using effective presentation techniques.  
        8. I can present without reading directly off my notes/script. 
        9. I can speak at an appropriate pace and tone (with inflection)
        10. I can apply leadership theories to businesses in the real world.  
        11. I can make connections between leadership theories and everyday life(B3.3) 
        12. I can evaluate leadership theories and determine the most effective theory for modern times.
        13. I can identify and use credible sources for my research.  
        14. I can cite my sources using APA format. (A2.1)  

        •  

          How to Submit

          • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
          • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.
          • Submit your completed assignment using the "Add Submission" button located at the bottom of this page.

          • Leadership Style

        Learning Log: 2-3 (Target: 4 hours) — Questionnaire
        4
        2-4: Group Dynamics (3 hours)
        Quizlet 2-4: Vocabulary Quizlet

         

         

        Lesson Vocabulary

        Quizlets

        Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

        For this lesson, focus on the following words:

          • Crew
          • Disruptors
          • Initiators
          • Responders
          • Standing Team
          • Task Force
        Click on 2-4: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
        ▼
        "Great things in business are never done by one person. They're done by a team of people." — Steve Jobs
        Like a sports league, various smaller teams work together in competitive workplaces. And within each team, groups of individuals with their unique personalities come together to increase overall productivity. As we will see, some teams work more effectively than others. In the following lesson, we will explore team building and the different obstacles team members work through to become a team.
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        Understand the stages of group development; demonstrate your understanding in different contexts; learn about the different types of groups within an organization.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Analyse the factors that contribute to the success or failure of a team
          • I can identify at least two things that demonstrate good teamwork
          • I can explain at least two things that demonstrate bad teamwork
        2. Analyze the stages of group development and the roles individuals play within a group structure
          • I can name different categories of group members within an organization; also name the various types
          • I can explain the role each type of member plays in a group
          • I can explain at least one advantage and one disadvantage of each type of group member
          • I understand how different types of group members will interact to create an effective team
        3. Analyse the factors that contribute to the success or failure of a team
          • I understand the five stages of group development
          • I can identify what happens at each stage
          • I can analyze what factors affect the individuals and the group in each of the stages
          • I can explain what a manager can do to help the group develop at each stage
        4. Explain the nature and types of groups within an organization
          • I can state the different types of groups
          • I understand the purpose of the different types of groups in an organization
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Develop teamwork skills
        • Apply your understanding of group development in different contexts
        Factors that Contribute to the Success or Failure of a Team

        What makes teams work well together? Why are some teams ineffective?

        Page 2-4A: Good Teamwork vs Bad Teamwork

        Learning Goals

          • Analyse the factors that contribute to the success or failure of a team.

          

        Good and Bad Teamwork 

        What makes teams work well together? Why are some teams ineffective?  As you watch the video below, start to consider the factors that contribute to each.

          

        Success Criteria

        I can identify and explain at least two factors of good teamwork.

         I can identify and explain at least two factors of bad teamwork.

         

        Now that we can see differences between good team work and bad teamwork, let's explore the different types of members that exist within a team or group.

        Page 2-4B: Types of Group Members

        Learning Goals

          • Analyze the stages of group development and the roles individuals assume within a group structure. 

        Different Types of Group Members

        There are several types of group members. These are general descriptions of the roles that people take on within a group. A group member does not always fill only one role and his/her role may change as the group dynamics change or time passes. It is also important to note that you may take on different roles depending on the group in which you work. Each role has its advantages and disadvantages and it is important to have a diverse group in order to succeed. The types of group members (or roles) are broken down into three categories: initiators, responders and disruptors.

        Initiators 

        These are the people in a group who usually speak or act first. They start conversation or processes to get the group moving.

        Role Description Advantages Disadvantages
        These group members come up with ideas and solutions to problems. They are often creative, imaginative and perceptive. They like to list alternatives and ask questions about the problems.
          • Good problem solvers
          • Can start the group down the right path toward its goal
          • Can be too focused on their own ideas and not hear/listen to others' input
        This group member has extensive knowledge in a particular area. He/she will offer specific knowledge and expertise. This person may think he/she knows it all. They are eager to share their information/knowledge.
          • Saves time  researching for specific or special knowledge
          • Can offer important information to the problem solving process
          • Can sidetrack others because of overpowering knowledge in one area
          • Can take up valuable time explaining concepts/information that may not be necessary
        These members have a story for every occasion. Whenever new information is brought up in the group, it is likely that the storyteller has a new story to tell. Often times, the stories are long and sometimes they are irrelevant.
          • Can entertain the group.
          • Can sometimes offer past experience that may help the group reach its goal.
          • Can waste a lot of time with irrelevant information.
          • Can distract group from primary tasks and moving toward goals.
        The Ideologist likes to state and rephrase ideas as they might occur under ideal or perfect circumstances. Often times, the ideologists recommendations are not realistic and cannot be achieved because they will only work if the circumstances were better or perfect. However, their ideas can help to stimulate others' ideas and solutions to problems.
          • Can stimulate other group members by offering different ideas.
          • Can remind group of larger/greater goals - like making the world better.
          • Can detract time from realistic solutions by discussing ideal circumstances.
        This group member has a past success story for any occasion. He/she likes to talk about his/her past accomplishments and achievements. Often, the star is not concerned with solving the problem or reaching the team goal(s); but rather, the star is concerned with looking good in front of others.
          • Group can leverage past achievements and performance to help solve current problems and reach current goals.
          • Doesn't usually offer a lot to help the team achieve its goal.
          • Can waste time talking about himself/herself.

        Responders

        These group members listen to the initiators and then respond by evaluating and/or commenting on the information provided.

        Role Description Advantages Disadvantages
        The Active Listener enjoys listening to new information and evaluate it. He/she will perform four major actions upon receiving new ideas - ask questions, probe for more information, restate the information or clarify the idea by adding more information.
          • Can help others understand stated information.
          • Questions can add more to the solution/idea.
          • Ideas may not be heard because they are in the form of a response.
          • Often seen as unintelligent because of constant restating/clarifying.
        This group member will always state the problems with new ideas. He/she likes to ask "what if ... " questions and he/she can generally tell you what could go wrong with a process or idea. The Devil's Advocate will ask questions about things that could fail or impede the group from reaching its goal. Often times, this group member will see disaster before it happens and will try to alert the group to it.
          • Good trouble shooters.
          • Can aid in making contingency plans.
          • Fairly negative and can decrease morale.
          • Can waste time worrying about all the things that can go wrong.
        This group member likes to complain about everything. He/she will complain about leaders/management, past groups, current situations, and anything else that is bothering him/her. When new ideas and information are brought up, the axe grinder will take the opportunity to relate the information to personal pet peeves or gripe about related issues.
          • Can help release group stress if others are also concerned about the issues that are brought up.
          • Use up group time to complain about personal problems.
          • Does not contribute a lot to reaching group goals.
        The Defeatist is convinced that none of the ideas will work. They think most solutions to the problems that the group faces are unrealistic. They do not just think that things could go wrong, they believe that ideas just won't work. They are often pessimistic and will give up on the task very easily.
          • They can often rule out solutions that really will not work by giving appropriate reasons.
          • Can decrease team morale.
          • Can be insulting to other team members when their ideas are shot down.
        This group member is out to get others in the group.They react negatively to new ideas and often times insult the person putting forth the solution/idea. They can be degrading and ruthless in their behaviours. They do not offer any new ideas of their own to help the team reach its goals.
          • The rest of the team may rally to support one another in the wake of the aggressor's destructive ways.
          • Can be destructive to group synergy.
          • Decreases morale in team and members.

          

        Disruptors

        These are roles that people take on where action is taken to distract the group members from their primary goals and focus.

        Role Description Advantages Disadvantages
        The Clown tries to entertain the group by telling jokes and being funny. They generally take up valuable group time and replace it with comedy.
          • Can reduce stress.
          • Can make breaks fun and enjoyable.
          • Can waste a lot of precious time.
        This group member is just along for the ride. They rarely contribute and they are disinterested in the group's problems and goals. They will daydream and do the bare minimum to get by.
          • They do not distract others away from the group goal like other disruptors are apt to do.
          • Cause others to do more work because they do not complete it.
          • Add stress (workload) to the group.
        The dominator tries to control the group time in order to achieve his/her own personal goals. They will take up group time trying to meet their own agenda and will try to direct others and the conversation toward their own personal goals. They are not interested in the group problem or goal.
          • If the dominator can be converted to focus on team goals, he/she can make a good leader.
          • Use up group time to complete personal agenda/goals.
          • Does not contribute a lot to reaching group goals.

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can name the three main categories of group members, the various types within each category, and the associated benefits and drawbacks of each type.  

         I understand how different types of group members interact to create an effective team.

        Stages of Team Development

        Having explored the different types of people that can exist in a group and the strengths and weaknesses of each, let's now examine the different stages a group goes through to become a team.

        Page 2-4C: Stages of Team Development

        Learning Goals

          • Analyse the stages of group development and the roles individuals assume within groups.  
          • Analyse the factors that contribute to the effectiveness of a team at various stages of development.

          

        Stages of Group Development

        Managers must be able to recognize and understand group behaviour at its various stages. What are the stages?  Bruce Tuckman identified five stages of group development.  He proposes the five stages are: forming, storming, norming, performing and adjourning.

        Groups are a common arrangement in today's business environments. Any manager who works with, or supervises, a group should be familiar with how they develop over time. Initially, Tuckman identified four stages of group development in 1965, which included the stages of forming, storming, norming and performing. A fifth stage was later added by Tuckman in 1977, which is called adjourning. It is believed that these stages are universal to all teams despite the group members purpose, goal, culture, location, demographics and so on. Below is a short explanation of the five stages of group development. 

         

         Leadership Activities at Different Group Formation Stages

        Stage

        Activities

        Forming
        • Direct the team, and establish clear objectives, both for the team as a whole and for individual team members.

        Storming
        • Establish processes and structures.
        • Build trust and good relationships between team members.
        • Resolve conflicts swiftly if they occur. Provide support, especially to those team members who are less secure.
        • Remain positive and firm in the face of challenges to your leadership, or to the team's goal. 
        • Explain the "forming, storming, norming, and performing" idea, so that people understand why problems are occurring, and so that they see that things will get better in the future. Coach team members in assertiveness and conflict resolution skills, where this is necessary.
        • Use psychometric indicators such as Myers-Briggs and the Margerison-McCann Team Management Profile to help people learn about different work styles and strengths.

        Norming
        • Step back and help team members to take responsibility for progress towards the goal. (This is a good time to arrange a team-building event.)

        Performing
        • Delegate tasks and projects as far as you can. Once the team is achieving well, you should aim to have as light a touch as possible. You will now be able to start focusing on other goals and areas of work.

        Adjourning
        • Take the time to celebrate the team's achievements – you may work with some of your people again, and this will be much easier if people view past experiences positively.

         

          

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I understand the five stages of group development.

         I can identify and explain what happens at each stage.

         I can analyze what factors affect the individuals and the group in each stage. 

         I can explain what a leadership and management activities can and should be performed at each stage of development.

         

        Practice

        This self-assessment will force you to evaluate each of the five stages of group development. This assignment will not be formally graded, but will better prepare you for a future evaluation.

        Assignment 2-4D: Stages of Team Development Assignment [CTA]

        2-4D: Stages of Team Development [CTA]


        This is a CTA Activity.  

         

         Learning Goals

          • Analyse the stages of group development and the roles individuals assume within a group structure

        Assignment Overview

        Step 1:  Complete the Table 
        Individually, with a partner, or as a class, complete the table below using your known of Bruce Tuckman’s “Stages of Group Development”.  You may use point-form notes. 

        Stage 

        Explanation 

         

         

         

         

         

         

         

         

         

         
         
        Step 2:  Apply and Explain 
        Now that you have completed your table, imagine yourself in a leadership or teamwork role.  Identify an example of a business idea where you can apply each stage of group development.  Explain or discuss the process of each stage. 
         
        Exemplar: 

        Stage 

        Explanation 

        Forming 

        • Team comes together. 

        • No goals have yet been formed 

        Storming 

        • Team members begin to share ideas. 

        • Conflict may arise. 

        • Structure and direction not yet established, or lacking 

        Norming 

        • Goals are being formed. 

        • A plan is being finalized. 

        • Team members start to receive roles. 

        Performing 

        • The plan is carried out. 

        • Roles are fulfilled. 

        • The goals are met and “performed”. 

        Transforming/Adjourning 

        • Team members start to change. 

        • Roles may be shifted. 

        • Achievements and success are celebrated. 

        • If new members join, the cycle restarts. 
         
        I have decided to apply my understanding of Tuckman’s Stages of Group Development toward a summer camp. 
         
        In the Forming stage, I will introduce myself to my fellow team members.  It is important to establish a healthy rapport and relationship if I’m going to work alongside them. 
         
        In the Storming stage, every member will contribute ideas to lead a successful summer camp.  Many ideas are put forth, with some members believing we should form a sports camp and other members believing we should form an arts camp.  Pros and cons will be exchanged, and although disagreements may happen, we will eventually settle on an idea when we form a common goal. 
         
        In the Norming stage, our ideas will start to come together.  We have decided that our main goal is to ensure children enjoy themselves while enrolled, so we will form a hybrid camp that offers sports and arts.  To effectively form this camp, each member will oversee a specific role.  I will handle enrolments, while other members will look to complete other tasks, such as finding a location for our camp, purchasing supplies, and developing a curriculum or itinerary. 
         
        In the Performing stage, the time has finally come to open our camp.  Our camp is ten days long and runs over a two-week period, which means successful performing will be high demand in such a short time.  As head of enrolment, I will ensure each camper is adequately assigned to the correct activities, while navigating any concerns brought forth by campers, their parents, or their guardians.  Other members of our team will also be carrying out their role to ensure a smooth-running and successful operation. 
        In the Transforming or Adjourning stage, we will formally end our group work.  We will celebrate our achievements and reflect on various aspects of our time working together.  If reflections are positive, this will bode well for future group work.  With this said, some members will leave the group and new members will replace them.  Therefore, it is important to become acquainted, and thus, we will start again at the Forming stage.

        [fa-check-square] Success Criteria

        You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

        I understand the five stages of group development.

        I can identify what happens at each stage.

        I can analyze what factors affect the individuals and the group in each of the stages.

         
        Types of Groups Within an Organization

        Why do group dynamics matter? Why does it matter that group dynamics grow and change in fairly predictable stages? Let's explore...

        Page 2-4E: Types of Groups Within an Organization

        Learning Goals

          • Explain the nature and types of groups within an organization. 

        Types of Groups

        There are many different types of groups within an organization/business. Most of the groups are named for the function that they perform. Groups are also broken down into the amount of time that the group is active. Some of types of groups are outlined below:

        Crew:

        This is a type of team that is formed for one short term goal. All the group members have the same goal and the roles in the group as well as communication guidelines are well established and defined. An example is a clean up crew after a concert. The team is put together for a short time, they all have one goal - to clean the stadium, and the roles are well defined (there is a leader and everyone does what he/she says). Communication is also well defined - it is mostly top down and very little meetings (if any) are needed. These teams are usually informal and formed fairly quickly.

        Task Force (Project Team, Committees):

        This is a team that comes together to complete one task and has a vague definition of member roles - most members perform functions that they specialize in. The task force can be either short term or long term. The communication between members is informal and loosely defined. Meetings are usually ad hoc as problems arise but the goal of the team is common to all members. An example of a task force is a police task force set up to offer enhanced security at an international event like the G8 in Toronto or a software development team working on a video game. These teams are usually formal having an overseeing authority.

          

        Standing Team (Department):

        This is a team where all the members play a similar role with each having additional, individual goals. Team objectives and goals are changed as needed and communication is done occasionally as needed.  These types of teams are long term and are dynamic in their tasks. An example of this type of team is a school subject department or a production management team (e.g., the Oreo cookie production team). These are formal teams that are part of a defined business structure/hierarchy.

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can identify a variety of different groups and teams that function within an organization and their associated characteristics.

        I can list an example for each type of group and team above.     

        Practice

        This is a multiple choice quiz that tests your knowledge of the learning activities in the lesson. You can take the quiz only once and the results will be sent to your teacher. This quiz will not be graded - it is a self assessment.

        Quiz 2-4F: Stages of Group Development Self-Check
        2-4F: Stages of Group Development Self-Check

         Learning Goals

          • Analyse the stages of group development and the roles individuals assume within a group structure

This quiz will not be graded - it is a self assessment that discerns whether or not you are able to move on to the next lesson in the unit. 

         Success Criteria

        You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

        I understand the different stages of group development.

        I can identify the characteristics of each stage of development.

          How to Complete the Quiz

        R
        2-5: Unit 2 Highlights (Review)
        ▼
        These unit highlights will summarize the main concepts from the lessons of Unit 2. You can also use this page to check if you understand all of the concepts covered in Unit 2 and prepare for the unit test.
        2-1: What is Leadership?

        Characteristics of an Effective Leader

        • Vocabulary: Characteristic, Skill, Leadership, Leader
        • Identify the characteristics and skills that a leader uses in the workplace
        • Explain Simon Sinek's theory of leadership (Golden Circle)

        Difference Between Managers and Leaders

        • Vocabulary: Manager, Boss, Business
        • Explain the difference between managers and leaders
        2-2: Understanding Human Behaviour

        Shaping Human Personality

        • Vocabulary: Personality, Culture, Attitude, Behaviour
        • Identify the different types of personalities in an office (Workaholic, Caretaker, Delegator, Chatty Cathy, etc.)
        • Understand different things that influence a person's personality (Parents, Culture, Friends, Media, etc.)

        Assessing Your Own Personality

        • Vocabulary: Personality, Personality Test, Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism, Intelligent Quotient
        • Understand the different personality tests: Myers-Briggs, True Colours, Big Five Personalities, and Emotional Intelligence Tests
        • Identify the difference between Intelligent Quotient and Emotional Quotient

        Attitude and Job Satisfaction

        • Vocabulary: Attitude, Job Satisfaction, Productivity, Morale, Absenteeism, Stress, Frustration, Optimistic
        • Explain attitude and identify the three components: Affective, Behavioural, Cognitive
        • Understand the connection between attitude and workplace behaviour
        • Describe positive workplace attitudes and behaviours (Loyalty, Courtesy, Low Rates of Absenteeism, Desire to do a Good Job, etc.)
        2-3: Leadership Theories & Styles

        Leadership Styles

        • Vocabulary: Leadership style
        • Connect to real world examples of leaders (MLK Jr., Nelson Mandela, Mahatma Gandhi, George Washington, etc.)
        • Describe the five leadership styles: Autocratic, Democratic, Laissez Faire, Collaborative, and Charismatic

        Leadership Theories

        • Vocabulary: Leadership Theory, Traits
        • Explain the leadership theories: The Great Man Theory, Transactional Leadership, Transformational Leadership, The Trait Theory, etc.

        Infographics

        • Vocabulary: Infographics, Color Coding, Graphics, Reference Icons, Time Frames, Statistics, Facts
        • Explain infographics and the three important elements: Visual Element, Content Element, and Knowledge Element
        • Identify common types of infographics (List, Flowchart, Map, Timeline, etc.)
        2-4: Group Dynamics

        Factors that Contribute to the Success or Failure of a Team

        • Vocabulary: Axe Grinder, Hitchhiker, Ideologist, Defeatist, Aggressor, Devil's Advocate
        • Describe the three main categories of group members: Initiators, Responders, Disruptors
        • Identify the various types within each category (Active Listener, Star, Clown, Expert, etc.)

        Stages of Team Development

        • Vocabulary: Margerison-McCann Team Management Profile, Team Members, Team, Structures
        • Explain the five stages of group development: Forming, Storming, Norming, Performing, and Transforming

        Types of Groups Within an Organization

        • Vocabulary: Department, Project Team, Committees, Objective, Goals, Group, Communication
        • Explain the types of groups: Crew, Task Force, and Standing Team
