        You've reached the end of the unit! Review the skills you've learned throughout the recent lessons to prepare for your test and best ensure your success.

        Test Overview: This test is designed to be completed in 60-90 minutes. The test will remain open for 2 hours.

        Remember to read the questions carefully and be sure to check your work before pressing submit. Do not leave any questions blank.

        All responses will be graded according to the KICA Achievement Chart.

        Quiz *UT-2: Unit 2 Test 7%
        3
        Management Challenges
        4 Lessons + Case Study + Midterm + Unit Highlights + Unit Test • Sections 20-28
        ▼
        Welcome to Unit 3. In this unit, students will learn about the different challenges that leaders and business managers face on a regular basis. Though communication was discussed in a previous unit, we will re-visit this theme as one of the most common challenges that managers face today. Students will explore employee perceptions and stress as additional challenges of business leaders. Students will also examine the different motivational obstacles that managers face when dealing with subordinates. Finally, the challenge of time management will be examined in the final lesson.

        Overall Expectations / Learning Objectives:

        • Evaluate the strategies used by individuals and organizations to manage stress and conflict
        • Compare theories of how to motivate individuals and teams in a productive work environment
        1
        3-1: The Communication Process (2 hours)
        ▼
        It is important for leaders to develop their communication skills and be aware of any possible communication barriers and errors. Much of individual and business success relies on the ability to effectively communicate in the workplace. The central lesson of this Unit will be to fully and completely understand the communication process. What are common barriers to communication? How can we improve our communication skills? What effect does perception have on communication?
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        The central concept of this lesson is the communication process and what helps, and what hinders, its effectiveness.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Understanding the communication process
        2. Explain the barriers and obstacles to effective communication
          • I can explain at least two different ways that a message can be mis-communicated
          • I can explain the communication process
          • I understand communication channels
          • I can explain barriers to communication
          • I can explain at least three barriers to communication and give an example of each
          • I can identify the three different types of noise
          • I can give at least one example of noise in message creation
        3. Analyze how personal perception can influence the interpretation of information and thereby affect individual decisions
          • I can explain what is meant by perception
          • I can explain how perception affects important decisions
          • I can explain and identify the various different perception theories and their effect on people
        4. Describe the techniques used to improve communication skills
          • I understand what communication skills are and can provide an example
          • I can define listening and its importance
          • I can explain verbal and non-verbal communication
          • I can state the five elements of listening and describe each one
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Critically analyze the communication process
        • Develop communication skills
        Barriers to Effective Communication

        In this introductory video, we will see how the communication process can, at times, break down. What can happen in cases of miscommunication?

        Forum 3-1A: Communication & Miscommunication [CTA]

        What ingredients go into communicating a message? How do we know that the sender and receiver are "on the same page"?

        Page 3-1B: The Communication Process

        Learning Goals

          • Understand the process of communication.
          • Explain the barriers and obstacles to effective communication.

        The Communication Process

        What ingredients go into communicating a message? How do we know that the sender and receiver are "on the same page"?  Let's explore the communication process in more detail.

        Below is a learning activity which explains the communication process in more detail. PDF version available. 

           

        Example of Communication Process

        Here is an example of the communication process in real life.

         

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can outline key ingredients in the communication process.

        I understand the processes and ingredients involved in communicating a message.   

        When communication is ineffective it leads to misunderstanding, failed relationships, and the inability to meet objectives. Any business or organization which suffers from excessive miscommunication is certain to fail.

        Page 3-1C: Miscommunication and Barriers

        Learning Goals

          • Explain the barriers and obstacles to effective communication.

        Causes of Miscommunication

        At each stage in the communication process, there are obstacles that can interfere. We call these obstacles "noise". Noise can alter messages, transmissions, receptions, translations and responses, effectively hampering the communication process. In this activity, students will learn about different types of noise that can exist at each stage of the communication process. 

         

        Communication Barriers

        It seems a straightforward process:  a message travels from A to B, and yet so much can go wrong in the transmission. Let's examine the most common barriers to communication, or "noise". PDF version. 

        Types of Noise

        Three Types of Noise:

        Noise can be categorized into three different types:

            1. Psychological Noise: Preconceived beliefs, attitudes and opinions that we have about the sender, audience (recipient) or situation can create noise in the communication process. Our stereotypes, biases and assumptions about what we think people will say, how they will react, or what they will hear can interfere with us giving or receiving the real message.
            2. Physical Noise: External distractions that take our attention away from the sender, message, or audience can make communication difficult. Physical noise is often a part of the external environment.
            3. Semantic Noise: The use of words and how words are interpreted can be barriers to effective communication. When senders use words that are foreign to the audience, the opportunity for semantic noise to distort the real message increases. In many cases, words or phrases mean different things to different people and this can pose as a barrier (or noise) when communicating a message.

          

        Message Creation:

        Noise can occur while the sender is in the process of creating the actual message. If there are distractions, distortions of reality, extenuating circumstances or other difficulties in creating the message, then a communication error can occur before the message is even sent. The following table explores some of the noise that can occur as the message is being created.

        TYPE OF MESSAGE TYPE OF NOISE EXAMPLES:
        Physically Written Psychological
          • The sender may have a stereotype about the audience and believes that he/she is only interested in sports. The sender then makes many analogies and references to sports in the message; however, these detract from the original message and make it difficult to understand.
          • The sender believes that the audience feels he/she is not intelligent. The sender focuses on high level concepts only and does not explain the smaller details of a situation. The message is not fully understood by the audience.
        Physically Written Physical
          • The sender's pen runs out of ink and he/she finishes the message using a pencil. This change distracts the audience as he/she wonders about the change instead of focusing on the message.
          • The sky written message dissipates soon after writing the message. The audience has trouble making out what the message says.
        Physically Written Semantic
          • The sender tries to use sarcasm in a review of his/her employee: "He is not late for our Monday meetings. He's just really early for our Tuesday meetings." Some sarcasm is difficult to read because it is difficult to capture the tone.
        Digitally Written Psychological
          • The sender believes that the audience is technologically weak and may not be able to view attachments in an email. So instead of attaching five files, the sender embeds the information from all of the files into the email message. The message is lost among the information that was originally in the attachments.
        Digitally Written Physical
          • The sender's internet is down and he/she cannot compose a message in his/her email account.
          • The sender does not have the proper settings on his/her social media account. As a result, the audience does not have access to read the message that was intended for him/her/them.
        Digitally Written Semantic
          • The sender used the following colloquialisms when writing an email to a friend: "I took the little pigs in a blanket and threw them against the wall before picking them up and putting them on a plate to eat later. My sister asked me if I had lost my marbles and I told her I had not, but rather, I was just steamed." (pigs in a blanket is a type of appetizer - hot dogs rolled up in pastry; losing one's marbles refers to losing ones mind or crazy; steamed means angry/frustrated). He/she does not explain what any of these terms mean.
        Verbal Psychological
          • The sender believes that the audience does not like him/her. He/she fills his/her message with compliments and praise for the audience. The message gets distorted and is difficult to understand.
          • The sender has been hurt by the audience in the past. He/she withholds information because of the fear of being hurt again, the message is created but is incomplete.
          • The sender is talking to his/her boss and only tells the boss what he/she thinks the boss wants to hear. The real message does not get created.
        Verbal Physical
          • The sender gets a "call waiting" beep while the two are in a phone conversation and he/she does not complete the message.
          • Actual noise (sounds) interfere with the discussion and important parts of the message are lost.
          • Another person enters the conversation and the sender gets distracted/sidetracked.
        Verbal Semantic
          • The message is being conveyed verbally by the sender, but his/her body language is sending other messages.
          • The sender uses words that the audience does not understand.
        Physical Psychological
          • A military trained special forces agent may feel that the police officer he is working with is does not have enough training with hand signals. So he/she uses less effective, simpler signals to the police officer and the communication and resulting action is not efficient.
        Physical Physical
          • Being physically hindered to perform an action can result in miscommunication. Only having one hand available and trying to sign or trying to give someone a hand gesture while clapping may be a barrier for effective communication.
          • Having some physical ailment (like Bell's Palsy) may make your body language appear one way to an audience when your physical gestures are saying something else.
        Physical Semantic
          • The sender tries to use sarcasm or tone through body language; however, the audience does not pick up on or understand how the tone is being   conveyed.

          

        Transmission:

        Other noise presents itself when a message is being transmitted (or moved) from the sender to the receiver (audience). It is important to note that, in most cases, the sender and receiver have little control over the transmission noise because it is part of the situational context, and not necessarily the message itself. Control over transmission is usually a choice about which transmission method to use (e.g., mail, fax, face to face, etc.). The following table explores some of the noise that can occur as the message is being transmitted.

        TYPE OF MESSAGE TYPE OF NOISE EXAMPLES:
        Physically Written Psychological
          • N/A
        Physically Written Physical
          • The post office could lose a mailed letter.
          • A written letter could fall off the desk of a colleague after the sender leaves it there.
        Physically Written Semantic
          • N/A
        Digitally Written Psychological
          • N/A
        Digitally Written Physical
          • The message could get lost in cyberspace - "I never got your text/email/etc."
          • The sender does not have the proper settings on his/her social media account. As a result, the audience does not have access to read the message that was intended for him/her/them.
          • The email could have been inappropriately marked as SPAM and gone into the recipient's/audience's junk folder.
        Digitally Written Semantic
          • N/A
        Verbal Psychological
          • The sender is embarrassed about the content of the message and therefore lowers the volume of his/her voice. Some of the words are not heard by the audience.
        Verbal Physical
          • Actual noise (sounds) interfere with the discussion and important parts of the message are lost.
          • Cellphone reception cuts in and out causing parts of the message to be lost.
        Verbal Semantic
          • N/A
        Physical Psychological
          • N/A
        Physical Physical
          • Other objects or people pass between the sender and audience causing the transmission of the message to be interrupted or parts of the message to be lost.
          • Poor room lighting may make it difficult to see the sender.
        Physical Semantic
          • N/A

        Reception:

        Noise can also obstruct the recipient (audience) from properly accepting the message. Note that reception noise specifically hinders the recipient from obtaining the message. Thus, it is normal for this type of noise to prevent the audience from ever seeing, reading, or hearing all or parts of the message. The following table explores some of the noise that can occur when the message is about to be received.

        TYPE OF MESSAGE TYPE OF NOISE EXAMPLES:
        Physically Written Psychological
          • The audience believes that the senders job is unimportant. He/she does not take the time to read the message in its entirety.
          • The audience does not like the sender and does not even look at the message before discarding it.
        Physically Written Physical
          • The audience loses the document that was placed on his/her desk.
          • The audience spills coffee on the letter and cannot read parts of it.
          • The audience is not in the vicinity of the sky written message.
        Physically Written Semantic
          • The letter is addressed to "All Staff Members" and the intended recipient is a contract worker and does not feel like a member of the staff, he/she may not begin to read it.
        Digitally Written Psychological
          • The audience feels the sender does not post valid information and has blocked the sender on his/her social media pages.
        Digitally Written Physical
          • The audience's mail server is down and he/she does not receive the message.
          • The sender does not have the same social media account and does not get the message that was posted.
        Digitally Written Semantic
          • The email has a subject line "Want Success in Q4? Read this" and the audience does not know what Q4 is, so he/she deletes the email without reading the valuable message in it.
          • A colleague sends a message from his/her personal account. The audience does not recognize the email address and thinks the email is a virus. The audience deletes it without reading it.
        Verbal Psychological
          • The audience is going through a rough time with his/her spouse. He/she is constantly thinking about his/her problem and not listening to his/her colleague.
          • The audience believes does not like his/her colleague and does not listen to when he/she has to say.
        Verbal Physical
          • The audience is playing Solitaire on the computer while on a conference call and does not hear about some valuable information.
          • Two people are trying to talk to the audience at one time and he/she chooses to listen to one over the other.
          • Another person enters the conversation and the audience gets distracted/sidetracked.
        Verbal Semantic
          • The sender uses words that the audience does not understand and the audience stops listening.
        Physical Psychological
          • The audience may have been hurt or deceived by the sender in the past and will ignore the sender's attempts to send signals via body language.
        Physical Physical
          • The intended recipient may have a sight impairment (blindness) and cannot see the gestures that the sender is giving.
        Physical Semantic
          • The audience may not have the knowledge of the sign language gestures that are being sent to him/her and so he/she gives up reading the message.

        Translation:

        Noise during the translation stage usually surrounds the audience. This type of noise generally prevents the audience from taking what he/she has heard, read or viewed in order to process the information. The following table explores some of the noise that can occur as the message is being translated.

        TYPE OF MESSAGE TYPE OF NOISE EXAMPLES:
        Physically Written Psychological
          • The audience believes that the sender does not like him/her. He/she reads the letter for underlying phrases or tone that proves his/her theory. The message is not translated in the audience's head.
        Physically Written Physical
          • The audience receives another message while reading the original message. The audience prioritizes the new message and responds to it. He/she never returns to properly translate the original message.
        Physically Written Semantic
          • The letter discusses B.A.D (Brand Advertising Development) Training which the company has been involved in for years. However, the letter fails to explain what B.A.D Training is (assuming everybody already knows) and a new employee (the audience) reads the training as a negative or bad thing.
        Digitally Written Psychological
          • The audience believes that the sender is trying to compete with him/her for a promotion. He/she reads the sender's email focusing on finding errors so that he/she can report the errors to management. The message is not translated in the audience's head.
        Digitally Written Physical
          • The audience has a number of email messages that he/she has to read quickly. He/she reads the sender's message but has little time to absorb it. The translation is done quickly and some information is lost.
        Digitally Written Semantic
          • An email was sent to employees of a software company that read, "Could all Mac users please ensure that your documents folder is not being compromised. To do this, please open up a terminal, change directories to documents and chmod all files to 644 (recursively of course). Then ensure that you chmod all directories to 755 so that you can open them. Thanks, management." The audience does not take the time to learn the technical language and the message is not translated.
        Verbal Psychological
          • The audience is going through a rough time with his/her spouse. He/she is constantly thinking about his/her problem and not listening to his/her colleague.
          • The audience believes does not like his/her colleague and does not listen to when he/she has to say.
        Verbal Physical
          • The audience hears the information on a conference call and when it concludes begins to make notes. He/she forgets some of the information discussed and cannot include it in his/her notes. The information that was forgotten does not get translated in the head of the audience.
          • While translating information during a face to face discussion, the sender begins a new message with the audience. The audience begins to listen to the next message coming through and does not complete translating the first message.
        Verbal Semantic
          • A boss tells his employees, "Yeah, we should be cleaning the toilets every time we use them." The audience thinks the sender is being sarcastic when talking about cleaning that needs to get done in the office bathroom. He/she thinks that the sender is saying the opposite of what the sender means. The translation is incorrect.
        Physical Psychological
          • The audience feels that the sender is always sending negative physical messages. When the sender sends the audience a positive message, the audience automatically translates it as negative because that is the norm.
        Physical Physical
          • The audience is at a conference and receives a sign language message from the sender. But he/she is immediately distracted by other people sending more sign language messages and neglects to translate the original message.
        Physical Semantic
          • The audience may not have the knowledge of the sign language gestures that are being made to him/her and translates the message the best he/she can using only parts of the message that he/she knows. The message is mostly lost in the translation.

        Response:

        Noise during the response stage of the communication process prevents the audience (recipient) of the original message from adequately sending a reply to the sender.  This can occur in a number of ways that may be sender, audience or situation driven. Regardless of the impetus for the noise, the end result is that a response does not make it back to the sender or the response is not properly received and translated by the sender. The following table explores some of the noise that can occur as the message is being responded to.

        TYPE OF MESSAGE TYPE OF NOISE EXAMPLES:
        Physically Written Psychological
          • The audience thinks the sender is too busy to read a response so he does not send one.
        Physically Written Physical
          • The audience begins to write a response but gets distracted by other work that needs to be done and never completes it.
        Physically Written Semantic
          • The audience perceives the tone in the letter to be sarcastic and sardonic. The sender closed the letter by saying, "I'll see ya when I see ya." The audience feels that sender does not care about a response and does not send one.
        Digitally Written Psychological
          • The audience knows that the sender gets a lot of emails and doesn't want to bother him/her with another informal response. So the audience refrains from sending a response.
        Digitally Written Physical
          • The audience's internet connection goes down while trying to create a response and he/she forgets about re-composing it when the internet is reconnected.
        Digitally Written Semantic
          • The sender ends the text conversation with "C U L8R". The African American audience reads this as a slang euphemism for "Colour" and thinks it is a derogatory remark. He/she does not respond to the sender or talk to the sender ever again. (C U L8R is short texting form for see you later)
        Verbal Psychological
          • The audience does not like talking to the sender and takes the first pause in the conversation to make an excuse and leave. There is no response to the sender's original message.
          • The audience has been hurt by the sender in the past. He/she does not want to get hurt again, so he/she does not offer any information to the sender.
        Verbal Physical
          • Actual noise interrupts the audience's response.
          • The sender leaves the conversation before a response can be given.
          • A third party enters the conversation before a response can be given.
        Verbal Semantic
          • The audience uses vague and incorrect words in communicating his/her feedback. The sender does not translate it.
        Physical Psychological
          • The audience feels his/her sign language is inferior to the sender and does not want to look bad or be embarrassed. So he/she decides not to send feedback.
        Physical Physical
          • There are physical obstacles that get in the way of the audience giving feedback.
          • After the original message, the audience loses sight of the sender in a crowded room and cannot offer feedback.
        Physical Semantic
          • The audience gives the North American standard sign for okay after being asked a question. The okay sign is touching the pointer finger to the thumb and making a circle. However, this sign to the sender means zero and the feedback is interpreted incorrectly.

          

         

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can explain the meaning of a barrier to communication and cite at least three examples.  

         I can list and explain the three "types" of noise.  

         I can identify the five different stages of communication in which there can be noise.

         I can give at least two examples of noise in each stage.  

          

        Perception in Communication

        In the picture below, what do you see? Two faces or a vase? Can you now see both images?

        Page 3-1D: Perceptions and How They Affect Communication

        Learning Goals

          • Analyze how personal perceptions can influence the interpretation of information and thereby affect decision making.

            

        What is perception?

          

        What do you see?

        Some of you will see an image quickly. Some of you will take longer, others won't see it at all, even though it is right in front of you.

        Highlight to the right of this sentence to see the answer. There's a lady walking in between two trees, and there is a man's face on the left, the arches are his eyes.

        Now do you see it? "Perception" describes how we see our world and how the world sees us. This can dictate how we act and make decisions. Here is a question to ponder: How might "perception" affect relationships in the  workplace? 

        Below is a video of an interactive activity for you to watch.

         

        Here is an example of perception in the workplace: You have just started with a new company and are being introduced to the manager for the first time. The manager, a very tall, nicely dressed man about 50 years of age, looks stern and officious. You are aware that he is in charge of several dozen employees. Your perception is that he is unlikable and that he will deal with you in an authoritative manner and be exceptionally demanding. You are completely taken aback when he welcomes you to the company and is extremely generous and kind, taking ten or fifteen minutes to get to know you and welcome you.

         

        Perceptual Tendencies

        What were the different perceptions in the example above? How did your initial perceptions influence how you spoke to him for the first time? Would it have affected what you said? How so? If not, why not?  

        Now, consider how perception can be a challenge in the workplace. Provide one example of how your initial perceptions of the manager above could have changed the way you worked in your first few weeks if you had not had the opportunity to speak at with him as you did.

        Below is a video of an interactive activity for you to watch.

         

         

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can explain what is perception is and how it relates to the workplace.

         I can identify and explain the various different theories of perception and their effect on people.

          

        Communication in the Workplace

        Having understood the communication process and just how easy it is to miscommunicate, how might we strengthen our communications skills?

        Page 3-1E: Improving Communication

        Learning Goals

          • Describe the techniques used to improve communication skills.

           

        Communication Skills in the Workplace

        In the process of communicating you may think that the messenger has to do all of the work.  But this is not true. The receiver, or listener, in the communication process needs to be as actively involved as the messenger or the process will fail. Studies show that we only remember between 25%-50% of what we hear. So think about this for a minute:  in a ten minute conversation we only remember about two and half to five minutes of the entire conversation. As a presenter, this fact has huge implications. What it boils down to is this:  If you have ten minutes to speak, you should formulate your key message(s), the central point of your presentation, in around two minutes and not much more. If your key message isn't short and focused, your audience has no hope of remembering what you said.

        Think about listening:  If you could remember more than 25%-50% of a conversation, you will have an edge over the average person. By becoming a better listener you will be more productive and your ability to influence, persuade, and negotiate will also improve.  As a manager it is essential to do these things, and do them well.  

        Improving Communication

        To overcome communication barriers and improve the communication process, various things can be done, including:

        • Active Listening
        • Constructive Feedback
        • Choosing Channels
        • Cross-Cultural Communication

        Let's explore each below.

         

        Non-verbal Communication

        When communicating, most people think about the words they say and the words they hear. However, the words you say and hear have only a 7% impact in communication. Much more of the message is communicated by how you say something and the body language that you use.

        Can you think of an example in your life where you noticed a difference between what you heard and what you perceived?  This dichotomy happens frequently in the workplace and it can greatly effect progress and productivity.   

        Five Elements of Active Listening

        How can one become a better listener? Below are five elements of active listening to which everyone should pay attention.   

         

        Pay Attention

        Give the speaker your undivided attention and recognize that what is NOT said is at times more important that what is said. You must be paying attention to see “what is said”. Look at the speaker directly and put aside any thoughts that might distract you. As you listen you shouldn't be formulating your rebuttal because, if so, you are not giving the speaker your full attention. If you have trouble concentrating, repeat their words in your mind as they say them. Avoid distractions from environmental factors and look at the messenger's body language.

         

        Show that you are listening

        Use your own body language and gestures to convey that you are paying attention. Nod and smile occasionally to show you are actively participating in the conversation. Make sure your posture is open and inviting. Make small verbal comments to encourage them. For example, say “Yes”, “Uh huh”, and “I see.”

         

        Provide Feedback

        Imagine two men in conversation. One man has his back to the viewer. The other man is facing the viewer and has a constantly puzzled look on his face.  Neither person can provide appropriate feedback.  Often our personal filters, assumptions, judgements and beliefs can distort what we hear and we reciprocate with feedback that hurts further conversation. To ensure that you are hearing the message as the messenger intends, reflect on what they say by paraphrasing. Try repeating your understanding. For example, you might say, “What I'm hearing is . . .”.  Periodically ask questions to clarify and summarize the speaker's comments.

         

        Hold off on Judgement

        Don't interrupt. It is a waste of time and it frustrates the speaker. Allow the speaker to finish their full message. When they have finished completely you may begin your counter arguments.  

         

        Respond Appropriately

        Active listening is a sign of respect and understanding. Attacking the messenger adds nothing to the conversation. Be candid, open, and honest in your response. It is fine to assert your opinion, but do so respectfully. Treat the messenger as you would want to be treated.

        Being an active listener is hard work, but it will payoff in the end. You will find that you will become a better communicator and that will help you be more successful.

        Constructive Feedback

        The process of telling other people how you feel about something they did or said, or about the situation in general, is called feedback. The art of giving feedback is an important skill, especially for managers who must regularly give feedback to their employees. There are ways to help ensure that feedback is useful and constructive rather than harmful. Some guidelines to giving constructive feedback include:

        • Give feedback directly and with genuine feeling and emotion.
        • Make sure the feedback is specific rather than general.  Use examples to support your points.
        • Give feedback at a time when the receiver seems most willing or able to accept it.
        • Make sure the feedback is limited to things the employee can do something about or can correct.
        • Give feedback in small doses.

        Think about a time when you received constructive feedback:  How did it make you feel? What did it do for you? Did you learn something about yourself?  Why is feedback important?

            

        Channel Selection

        As we explored previously, people use a variety of channels to communicate with others. Each channel has a different capacity to carry information in an effective manner. In the figure below, you can see that face-to-face communication is very high in richness and impact, enabling two-way interaction and immediate feedback. Communication in the form of written reports, memos, and text messages are very low in richness because of the impersonal, one-way interaction that offers limited opportunity for feedback. Managers (as well as employees) need to understand the limits of each channel and choose wisely when using them to communicate, knowing the strengths and limitations of each. 

         

         

        Cross-Cultural Communication 

        Communicating when the sender and receiver are from different cultures is a significant challenge, one that is well recognized by international business people and executives.  Simply put, it is hard to communicate when you don't speak each other's language. Further, messages get lost in translation, as classic advertising miscues such as these demonstrate:

        • A Pepsi ad in Taiwan intended to say "The Pepsi Generation" came out as "Pepsi will being your ancestors back from the dead".
        • A KFC ad in China intended to convey "finger licking good" came out as "eat your fingers off".

        Cultural differences are also common in nonverbal communication.  Everything from the use of gestures to interpersonal space can be misinterpreted. It becomes important to understand a culture before making assumptions.

        Improving Your Communication

        Consider the ways of improving communication we have discussed in this learning activity. Do some research about communication barriers and noise and find real world examples. For practice, choose one of the methods of improving communication and determine how you could improve the communication for someone facing the real world examples you researched. Share your research, real world examples, and communication improvement strategy with a partner. Provide each other constructive feedback on the strategy chosen.

           

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I understand the meaning of communication skills and can provide an example.

         I can define "listening" and it's importance. 

         I can explain verbal and non-verbal communication.

         I can state the five elements of listening and describe each one. 

         

        Vocabulary (Quizlet)

        Lesson Vocabulary

        For this lesson, focus on the following words:

          • Ambiguity
          • Channel Richness
          • Communication Barrier
          • Cultural Misunderstanding
          • Filtering
          • Hearing
          • Information Overload
          • Jargon
          • Listening
          • Noise
          • Perception
          • Projection
          • Stereotyping

        Learning Log: 3-1 (Target: 2 hours) — Questionnaire
        2
        3-2: Stress & De-Stressing (3 hours)
        Quizlet 3-2: Vocabulary Quizlet

         

         

        Lesson Vocabulary

        Quizlets

        Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

        For this lesson, focus on the following words:

          • Eustress
          • Distress
          • Optimal Performance Point
          • Stress
          • Stressor
          • Wellness Program
        Click on 3-2: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
        ▼
        Unfortunately, stress is both damaging and common in today's workplace. Hence, it is important for leaders to be able to cope with stress and learn how to de-stress themselves and the people whom they manage. Stress is extremely common in the workplace and it becomes essential that we understand how to manage it effectively. The central idea of this lesson is to understand stress - what is it, what causes it, and how it can be managed. Stress impacts both employees and employers, exacerbates conflicts, and lowers productivity.
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        The key idea of this lesson is to understand stress in our personal lives and the workplace; identify causes of stresses in the workplace; and explore the programs organizations are implementing to help reduce stress.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Evaluate the impact of personal and work-related stress on performance
          • I can define "stress"
          • I can identify stressors in my own life
          • I understand there are different techniques that can be used to reduce stress and I can outline three
        2. Describe the factors that contribute to stress and conflicts in the workplace
          • I have identified the major causes of stress in my life
          • I can define stress and stressors and give an example of each
          • I can explain the three types of stress and give an example of each
          • I understand how stress affects me in different ways
          • I can identify sources and give examples of stress in the workplace
          • I can explain eustress and distress
          • I can demonstrate using the stress and performance curve, the point of optimal performance
        3. Identify stress-reduction techniques used in organizations
          • I understand stress management and why it is necessary
          • I can explain three wellness programs offered by organizations and give a real life example of each
          • I can evaluate the impact of wellness programs on organizations and their productivity
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Critically analyze stress-reduction techniques
        • Self-assess personal level of stress and identify stressors and ways to manage them
        Factors that Contribute to Stress

        Your life is unique and you have experienced stress differently than others. This forum is intended for you to share your own personal experiences with stress and how you've managed it effectively.

        Forum 3-2A: Life Stressor Forum [CTA]

        Everyone has stress in their lives. In fact, a small amount of stress is healthy. But excessive stress and the inability to manage it is very damaging. Let's find out how stressed you are by taking this online test.

        Page 3-2B: Test your Stress

        Learning Goals

          • Describe the factors that contribute to stress and conflicts in the workplace.

           

        Test your Stress

        How much do you know about your own stress? Take an online test to find out: http://www.bemindfulonline.com/test-your-stress/. 

         

        What is Stress?

        What is Stress?

        Stress is a state of mental or emotional strain or tension resulting from adverse or very demanding circumstances.

        What is a Stressor?

        A stressor is something that creates stress for us. It can be a situation, person, thing or event that causes undue mental or emotional strain or tension. For students, one of the biggest stressors is academics, as you can see in the graphic below. 

        Three Types of Stress

        Acute Stress: This type of stress is the most common and is normally short term. It is usually based on one event or situation and is alleviated once the stressor is taken away. An example of acute stress is the tension one feels when his/her car runs out of gasoline on a busy road. The emotional strain or tension is removed in a short period of time - once you walk to a gas station, get some gas and find yourself back on the road again. This type of stress provides a quick burst of excitement or thrill but if it lasts too long, it can lead to exhaustion.

        Episodic Acute Stress: This type of stress occurs regularly over and over again. Someone who has a demanding job and works long hours day in and day out may suffer from episodic acute stress. It seems that they keep experiencing acute stress episodes over and over again in different ways. One of the more common forms of episodic acute stress can be found in people who constantly worry about everything. For these people, every situation creates tension or mental unrest for them and they are in a state of constant uneasiness. These types of people can seem overly aroused and tense all the time. Treatment is recommended for this type of stress as there are usually many levels to the problem and usually multiple stressors.

         
        Chronic Stress: This is a permanent stress that grinds away at people day after day and year after year. Where acute stress is exciting and thrilling, chronic stress is the opposite. Chronic stress is depressing and exhausting. Situations that can lead to chronic stress include: family deaths, separations, long term illness, poverty, feeling trapped in an unhappy marriage or job. Examples of chronic stress is the stress of war (for example, some parts of the Middle East); or the stress of being unjustly imprisoned. Often times, the person in chronic stress can see no way out of the stressful situation and it becomes toxic.

         

        How can Stress affect you?

        Prolonged or Chronic stress can affect you in many different ways. When you are stressed, watch out for these signs that affect your mind, body, emotions, and behaviour.  

         

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I have identified the major causes of stress in my life.

         I can define stress and stressor and give an example of each.

         I can explain the three types of stress and give an example of each.

         I understand how stress affects me in different ways.

         

        Stress in the Workplace

        How does stress impact people in the workplace?

        Page 3-2C: Stress in the Workplace

        Learning Goals

          • Describe the factors that contribute to stress in the workplace.

           

        Stress in the Workplace

        As we saw previously, people experience stress in many areas of their lives. For students, a major stressor is academics, while for employees, a major stressor is the work environment or demands of the job. 

        The word "stress" is often regarded as negative, though you may be surprised to learn that not all stress is bad for you. Theorist Hans Selye distinguishes between two types of stress - eustress and distress.

        Eustress vs Distress

        Eustress or "good stress" is any kind of challenging stimulus that stresses the individual but with the result that they feel energized, motivated, or wanting to act in a way that is beneficial. It is like the stress of healthy competition, or fear of an upcoming exam which can make you want to study harder, or a "wake up call" that motives one to change their lifestyle. The result of eustress is positive.

         

        Distress or "bad stress" is when stress, trauma, anxiety, and worry are not productive and instead cause the person to shut down. It paralyzes a person with fear, interferes with their ability to think or work clearly, or fulfill their daily obligations at home or work. The result is less action which can become a long-term problem.

         

        What can cause stress in the workplace?

        Difficult Bosses: Having a boss that does not appreciate you, belittles you, or makes you feel inferior, can add significantly to your stress levels. Watch the video below and consider the impact that negative and difficult bosses can have on an employees level of stress and dissatisfaction in their jobs.   

        Co-Workers: Often times co-workers can add stress to ones life. Here is an example of the things that our co-workers do that can add tension to our work day. 

         

        Working Conditions or Workload: Poor or unacceptable working conditions or excessive workload can lead to tension and stress. Remaining in negative working conditions can lead to acute and episodic acute stress.

             

        Commute: The commute to work can often be a stressor in people's lives adding undue stress to daily routine. Having to take and wait for public transit, being stuck in traffic for long hours of time lead to higher levels of tension in many people.

          

         

        The impact of stress on performance

        If eustress is good and distress is bad, what is the optimal performance point? Dodson and Yerkes showed that experiencing some pressure had a good effect on performance up to a certain point. We would define this as eustress.  Some pressure, properly applied, provided motivation for people to generate higher levels of production/performance. Pressure that is not overwhelming can push people to set higher goals and achieve them. However, there comes a point when pressure begins to become negative. If there is too much pressure on an individual, then it no longer acts as a motivator. Performance levels will deteriorate due to unhappiness or negative/overwhelming feelings. Optimals levels of stress are hard to determine, and will vary for everyone.  

         

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can identify sources and give examples of stress in the workplace.

         I can explain the difference between eustress and distress.

         I can demonstrate, using the stress and performance curve, the point of optimal performance and what that means.

         

        Stress Management

        Now that we have a better understanding of "stress", we will explore a number of techniques that businesses use in order to manage it.

        Page 3-2D: Stress Management

        Learning Goals

          • Identify stress-reduction techniques used in organizations.

          

        Stress Management

        As we saw in the previous section, stress can be both good and bad.  Part of the job of businesses in our day is to encourage eustress while minimizing distress.  Properly administered stress management can even turn a short term distress into a positive result. However, when stress is prolonged or worsened, fatigue and burnout are sure to follow.  In time, overall productivity will fall. Below we will investigate various different ways organizations are proactively managing their employees' stress levels. 

           

        Wellness Programs

        Wellness programs can include anything from fitness rooms to lifestyle programs to food and games.  All are considered "perks" that companies offer employees in order to promote wellness and healthy living. Watch the video below for some examples of wellness programs in businesses today.

        Team Building Opportunities

        Many companies try to reduce stress induced by co-workers by engaging employees in activities that develop team building exercises and teamwork. The main idea is to get employees to relate to one another outside of a work setting so that they can find commonalities and reduce the stress caused by interpersonal relationships. Examples of team building exercises include outdoor adventures (like portaging, rock climbing or white water rafting), group tasks (like escape rooms, marathons or triathlons), and social events (wine tastings, pub nights, etc.).

        Flexible Time and Work From Home

         

        Giving employees the option of setting their own work schedules is another way to reduce stress. This allows the employee some control over external factors that induce tension. For example, an employee may feel stressed about the long hours spent in rush hour traffic. He/she can now choose to come into work an hour earlier and leave an hour earlier and therefore decrease the amount of traffic he/she is used to driving in. Some examples of flexible work hours and work from home schedules that companies offer include:

        • Flex time - work 8 hours per day, but the hours you work are up to you.
        • Flex time - start work any time between 7 am and 10 am; work for 8 hours.
        • Four day work weeks - work 10 hours for four days and then get the fifth day off.
        • Work from home - work two days per week from home.

        Netflix has taken flex time to a whole new level. The company does not track vacation days, when people are working or even how often they come into the office. Netflix treats its employees as adults giving them ultimate autonomy over their schedules. They have assumed an extremely high "theory Y" attitude (McGregor's Theory X and Theory Y). As long as employees are completing work in a timely manner, no questions are asked about their scheduling. This policy is very high risk, but also high reward if employees buy into it. It can reduce their stress, increase morale, and ultimately increase productivity.

        Daycare Services

        Some companies even offer daycare services for employees to help decrease the stress of new parents. Many new parents experience anxiety and stress about leaving their children at a daycare for an entire workday. With in-company day care, parents can visit their children throughout the day. This helps decrease stress and anxiety.

         

        Extended Leaves and Vacation Time

        Companies offer time off for leisure and family. We call this vacation time. Some companies increase vacation time as the employee's tenure with the company increases. Time away from work is seen as an important aspect of healthy living. Most companies embrace this notion and even give employees paid vacation. When difficult times occur in an employee's life, some companies will also grant them extended leaves. Most extended leaves are without pay; however, some companies offer full pay or partial pay while employees are off of work. Extended leaves can occur for a number of reasons including: mental or physical health issues, a death in the family, time off to take care of an ill family member, etc.

        Why provide Wellness Programs?

        Wellness programs can be expensive, from the added costs of daycare or allowing employees additional time off, so why would companies offer wellness programs? Many companies report that increased employee well-being results in better engagement and higher productivity. Examine the infographic below to see how wellness programs can benefit organizations. 

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I understand stress management and why it is generating so much attention by businesses.

         I can explain three wellness programs offered by organizations and give a real life example of each.

         I can evaluate the impact of wellness programs on organizations and their productivity.
