        Quizlet 3-3: Vocabulary Quizlet

         

         

        Lesson Vocabulary

        Quizlets

        Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

        For this lesson, focus on the following word:

          •  Conflict Management Style
        Click on 3-3: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
        ▼
        As we discussed in the previous lesson, stress can create and exacerbate conflicts in the workplace. Conflict between colleagues is not uncommon. But conflict must be managed. Mismanaged and unaddressed conflict can lead to a toxic workplace. There are many different conflict management styles which we will learn about in this lesson. Further, we will examine how stress can be a source of conflict in the workplace.
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        Understanding conflict and different means of conflict resolution is the central theme of this lesson.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Identify common causes of conflict in the workplace and its impact
          • I can state the most common causes of conflict in the workplace
          • I can identify the impact of conflict on businesses
          • I have researched at least three examples of conflict in the workplace (from recent news articles)
        2. Evaluate conflict management styles and their impact on a situation
          • I can state the different categories of group members and their types
          • I can explain the role each type of member plays in a group
          • I can explain at least one advantage and one disadvantage of each type of group member
          • I understand how different types of group members will interact to create an effective team
          • I can apply my understanding of conflict management to different situations
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Apply your learning to different situations and contexts where there is conflict
        Factors that Contribute to Stress

        When communication breaks down or stress levels increase excessively, conflicts will arise. Let's explore the most common causes of conflict in the workplace and their costs.

        Page 3-3A: Common Causes of Conflict

        Learning Goals

          • Identify common causes of conflict in the workplace and it's impact.

           

        Common Causes of Conflict

        What are the main sources of conflict in the workplace?  Why do people end up in disagreements with people with whom they care about? Let's begin by examining the most common causes of conflict in the workplace.  As we will see, many of these are common to conflict in general. Each of these affect relationships, the basis and source of much of the conflict that we will encounter in our personal and working lives.

        TASK: Find an example of workplace conflict in the news. Share it in detail with a partner.

            

        Why care?

        Why should an organization care about conflict in the workplace? Simply put, there is a huge cost to conflict. Read the U.K. infographic below and note the staggering costs of stress and conflict in the workplace.

         

        It is clear that businesses need to find ways to reduce stress (Unit 3-2) and conflict (Unit 3-3) in the workplace. 

        In the video below, let's take a look at how managers at Google managers resolve conflict.  

        Clearly, Google has a number of unique ways of resolving workplace conflicts (and preventing them!).  Explain what is meant by Liane Hornsey's comment about "honest dialogue" and its value in resolving conflict.  Why exactly is it effective?  Provide one example from the video.  What does Google offer employees in order to prevent conflict before it arises? 

        In the next learning activity, we will learn about different conflict management styles.

            

        Further Reading

        To explore more about the common causes of conflict in the workplace, read the following article - click here.

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can state the most common causes of conflict in the workplace.

         I can identify the impact of conflict on businesses.

         I have researched an example of conflict in the workplace from the recent news.

        Conflict Management Styles

        As we just learned, conflict in the workplace can be extremely costly. Every conflict reduced or removed will have benefits on a company's bottom line. Given that, how do managers and employees minimize conflict?

        Page 3-3B: Conflict Management Styles

        Learning Goals

          • Evaluate conflict management styles and their impact on real life situations. 

        Conflict Management

        It is important for business leaders to be able to manage conflict. Whether it's an overbearing boss who is strenuously arguing that things should be done her way, or co-workers disagreeing on the best way to complete a project, there are many types of conflict that can arise in the workplace. The good news is that there are many different solutions to many workplace conflicts. One example is to simply follow the conflict resolution process which we will discuss later in this learning activity.

        Now let's take a look at the video below which discusses conflict management in the workplace. It also provides tips that leaders understand before deciding which type of conflict management style to use.

        Conflict Resolution Process

        The conflict resolution process is a great tool managers should use when trying to resolve conflict. The first step is to explore the issues. It is always important to understand the problem before jumping to conclusions. Once you have a clear understanding of the issue, begin the conversation. It is essential to address all parties to the conflict and try to get a sense of everyone's point of view. As you continue the conversation, try to find common ground with the opposing party. If possible, try to compromise with the conflicting individual(s). Then, work together toward potential solutions. Some key points to remember when following the conflict resolution process is to actively listen to the opposing side and make the entire process transparent.

        The four steps of the conflict resolution process are:

        • Explore the issues
        • Start the conversation
        • Find common ground
        • Discover solutions

        The two key points are:

        • Make the process visible
        • Listen

         

        Conflict Management Styles

        There are many different ways of resolving conflicts as we have discussed earlier in the learning activity.  Everyone has a different style. Some people are more aggressive while others take a more relaxed and calm approach. The five conflict management styles we will be discussing are: avoiding, competing, collaborating, compromising, and accommodating. Each has its advantages and drawbacks.  As you will see from the chart below, certain styles are more appropriate in specific scenarios.

        Conflict Management Style Description Advantage/Disadvantage Appropriate Time to Use Style
        The Competing Shark
        • Sharks use a forcing or competing conflict management style
        • Sharks are highly goal-oriented
        • Relationships take on a lower priority
        • Sharks do not hesitate to use aggressive behavior to resolve conflicts.
        • Sharks can be autocratic, authoritative, and uncooperative; threatening and intimidating.
        • Sharks have a need to win; therefore others must lose, creating win-lose situations.

        Advantage: If the Shark's decision is correct, a better decision without compromise can result.

        Disadvantage: May breed hostility and resentment toward the person using it.
        • When conflict involves personal differences that are difficult to change.
        • When fostering intimate or supportive relationships is not critical.
        • When others are likely to take advantage of noncompetitive behavior.
        • When conflict resolution is urgent; when decision is vital in crisis.
        • When unpopular decisions need to be implemented.
        The Avoiding Turtle
        • Turtles adopt an avoiding or withdrawing conflict management style.
        • Turtles would rather hide and ignore conflict than resolve it; this leads them uncooperative and unassertive.
        • Turtles tend to give up personal goals and display passive behavior creating lose-lose situations.

        Advantage: May help to maintain relationships that would be hurt by conflict resolution.

        Disadvantage: Conflicts remain unresolved, overuse of the style leads to others walking over them.
        • When the stakes are not high or issue is trivial.
        • When confrontation will hurt a working relationship.
        • When there is little chance of satisfying your wants.
        • When disruption outweighs benefit of conflict resolution.
        • When gathering information is more important than an immediate decision.
        • When others can more effectively resolve the conflict.
        • When time constraints demand a delay.
        The Accommodating Teddy Bear
        • Teddy Bears use a smoothing or accommodating conflict management style with emphasis on human relationships.
        • Teddy Bears ignore their own goals and resolve conflict by giving into others; unassertive and cooperative creating a win-lose (Bear is loser) situation.

        Advantage: Accommodating maintains relationships

        Disadvantage: Giving in may not be productive, Bear may be taken advantage of
        • When maintaining the relationship outweighs other considerations
        • When suggestions/changes are not important to the accommodator
        • When minimizing losses in situations where outmatched or losing
        • When time is limited or when harmony and stability are valued
        The Compromising Fox
        • Foxes use a compromising conflict management style; concern is for goals and relationships.
        • Foxes are willing to sacrifice some of their goals while persuading others to give up part of theirs.
        • Compromise is assertive and cooperative-result is either win-lose or lose-lose.

        Advantage: Relationships are maintained and conflicts are removed.

        Disadvantage: Compromise may create less than ideal outcome and game playing can result.
        • When important/complex issues leave no clear or simple solutions.
        • When all conflicting people are equal in power and have strong interests in different solutions.
        • When there are no time restraints.
        The Collaborating Owl
        • Owls use a collaborating or problem confronting conflict management style, valuing their goals and relationships.
        • Owls view conflicts as problems to be solved, finding solutions agreeable to all sides (win-win).

        Advantage: Both sides get what they want and negative feelings eliminated.

        Disadvantage: Takes a great deal of time and effort.
        • When maintaining relationships is important.
        • When time is not a concern.
        • When peer conflict is involved.
        • When trying to gain commitment through consensus building.
        • When learning and trying to merge differing perspectives.



           

        Further Reading

        Situational Based Resolutions - Best Used at different times

        Further Reading

        If you would like to learn more about the different conflict management styles, visit http://www.astridbaumgardner.com/blog-and-resources/articles/conflict-management-styles-the-start-of-effective-conflict-management/

         For PDF version, click here

         

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can outline the five main conflict management styles and explain each.  

         I can explain when it is advantageous (or not) to utilize each of the styles outlined above.

         I can explain why the Honda Corporation likes conflict in their design management teams.

        Having explored the various conflict management styles and which are best suited to certain situations, we will now discover your own personal, predominant, conflict management style.

        Assignment 3-3C: Conflict Management Styles Application and Assessment Activity [GTA]

        3-3C: Conflict Management Styles Application and Assessment Activity

        This formative assignment will be assessed by your Grading Teacher in order to provide you with descriptive feedback essential to a future assignment.

        Overall Expectations & Learning Goals

        • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2)  
        • Evaluate the strategies used by individuals and organizations to manage stress and conflict. (C2)  

         Assignment Overview


        In this assignment, you will determine your conflict management style and address questions that can accurately demonstrate the application of these conflict management styems in a hypothetical work setting. 


        Task  
         
        Step 1:  Complete the Quiz 
        One strategy to determine your personal conflict management style is to take one of the many quizzes that exist.  In order to answer the questions in this task, begin by completing the quiz below. When taking quizzes such as these, be honest in your answers. There is no “Right” answer – it is more about understanding how you would behave or respond in certain situations.  

         

        Conflict Management Style Quiz  

        Listed below are 15 statements. Assign each statement a numerical value based on the following scale:   
         
        1 = Always 
        2 = Very often 
        3 = Sometimes 
        4 = Not very often 
        5 = Rarely, if ever.

        _____ a. I argue my case with peers, colleagues, and coworkers to demonstrate the merits of the position I take. 

        _____ b. I try to reach compromises through negotiation.
        _____ c. I attempt to meet the expectation of others.
        _____ d. I seek to investigate issues with others in order to find solutions that are mutually acceptable.

        _____ e. I am firm in resolve when it comes to defending my side of the issue.
        _____ f. I try to avoid being singled out, keeping conflict with others to myself.
        _____ g. I uphold my solutions to problems.
        _____ h. I compromise in order to reach solutions.
        _____ i. I trade important information with others so that problems can be solved together.
        _____ j. I avoid discussing my differences with others.
        _____ k. I try to accommodate the wishes of my peers and colleagues.
        _____ l. I seek to bring everyone's concerns out into the open in order to resolve disputes in the best possible way.
        _____ m. I put forward middle positions in effort to break deadlocks.
        _____ n. I accept the recommendations of colleagues, peers, and coworkers.
        _____ o. I avoid hard feelings by keeping my disagreements with others to myself.

        There are 5 management style categories. Each category has three statements related to it as outlined below.  For each statement in the category, record the numerical value you assigned to the statement above. Calculate the total for each category. 
         
        Scoring: The 15 statements to which you just responded are sorted below into the five conflict style categories. To score your quiz, follow the instructions below.  
        • For each statement (a-o), record the numerical value you assigned to it in the quiz. 
        • Calculate the total value for all 3 statements in each category.  
        Ex. Competing:  a) 3   e) 1   g) 5   TOTAL: 9 
         
        Competing/Forcing Shark:  a._____ e. _____ g. _____  TOTAL:_____ 
        Collaborating Owl: d. _____ i. _____ l. _____ TOTAL:_____ 
        Avoiding Turtle: f. _____ j. _____ o. _____ TOTAL:_____ 
        Accommodating Teddy Bear: c. _____ k. _____ n. _____ TOTAL:_____ 
        Compromising Fox:  b. _____ h. _____ m. _____ TOTAL:_____ 
         
        Analysis: Use the totals from above to complete the analysis of your conflict management style. 
        My dominant style is:  _________________  (Your lowest score) 
        My second highest rated style is:  __________________ (Your second lowest score) 
        The style which least matches my personality is:  _______________ (Your highest score). 

         

        Step 2:  Reflect on your results 

        1. Write down your results and the analysis from the quiz in a neat and organized manner.  

        1. From the results, identify your most dominant conflict management style and your least dominant conflict style. Reflect on the results. Do these results reflect what you think is your actual conflict management style?  Are these results expected or surprising? Justify your answers with an explanation of how/why they do or do not match what you think about your conflict management style. Use evidence from the different styles to support your answers.  

        1. For each of the following scenarios, decide whether the most appropriate and effective management style would be your most dominant conflict management style or your least dominant conflict management style. For each, identify the style that you think is most appropriate and effective and justify your choice with a detailed explanation and reference to details of the style.  

        • Separating two employees involved in a loud altercation/ argument 
        • Terminating an employee 
        • Communicating bad news to the whole staff 
        • Handling a customer dispute 

          

        Submission Requirements  

        • Upload your written work as a Word or PDF file 

         Success Criteria

        You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

        1. I can determine my most dominant and least dominant conflict management styles using a quiz and reflect on the results. (C2.4) 
        2. I can evaluate and explain how my most dominant and least dominant conflict management styles can appropriately and effectively be used in workplace scenarios. (C2.4) 
        3. I can use business-related terminology effectively. (A2.1; A2.4)    
        4. I can present my ideas in an organized and logical sequence (A2.1; A2.4) 

         

          How to Submit

          • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
          • Click on the button below when you are ready to begin writing your assignment.

        In this activity, you will apply what you learned about the different kinds of conflict management styles to real life business situations.

        Assignment *3-3D: Conflict Management Case Study 5%

         
        *3-3D: Conflict Management Case Study [5%]

        This activity will be counted in your final grade

        Learning Strands & Expectations

        • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 
        • Demonstrate an understanding of the communication process within the workplace. (C1) 
        • Evaluate the strategies used by individuals and organizations to manage stress and conflict. (C2) 

         Assignment Overview

         

        The following case study assignment will assess your ability to apply the concepts you have learned to a hypothetical real-world scenario. You are to only use the LMS and the case study in answering your questions. Outside research is not required.  

         

        Task

        Step 1:  Read the Case Study 

        Read the case study carefully. You may find it helpful to make note of any key facts, issues, and information you come across in your reading. 

        Case Study
        Robin has been the manager of a local restaurant for the past two years.  Robin has a hard-working, loyal, and friendly staff.  As a result, the day-to-day operations of the restaurant are quite smooth and business is generally successful.  A big part of the restaurant’s success is owed to Robin’s initiatives.  Robin conducts weekly impromptu wellness checks and maintains an open-door policy for any communication needs the staff has. Once a month, Robin also organizes staff-wide events to promote employee bonding.   
         
        This summer, the city is hosting a heritage festival which will attract a lot of tourists. The festival, combined with the increase in restaurant dining in the summer months, means that the restaurant is expected to be busier than usual. Robin has decided to promote a staff member to an assistant position and has almost finalized the promotion. Sam, Robin’s first hire as manager, is the leading choice for the position.  While most staff think Sam is a good choice due to their reliability, expertise, and charisma as a worker, Charlie, an employee of five years, recently spoke to Robin and stated that, while they’re happy to see Sam receive this promotion, they felt that their own experience working at the restaurant was overlooked. Charlie went on to suggest that Robin gave preferential treatment to Sam because Sam was Robin’s first hire.   As a result of this conversation, Robin feels that Charlie may be unhappy and is second-guessing their decision to promote Sam to the assistant position.   
         
        What can Robin do to resolve this conflict? 
         

        Step 2:  Answer the Questions 
         
        Answer the following questions: 
         
        1. Identify and describe 2 causes of conflict that Robin is facing from the case study. [K]
        2. Using information from the case regarding Robin's management style, identify and define two (2) conflict management styles from the course that she would likely use to resolve this conflict. [K]
        3. Select and identify 1 conflict management style you would use from the 2 choices you provided in Q2 if you were Robin.  Explain how the style chosen could be applied in this case by using the four steps of the conflict resolution process. Be specific and make logical inferences. [I]
        4. Reflect on your personal experiences:
          • Describe how you approach conflict in your life. Support your answer with 2 personal examples. In your description, identify your conflict management style.
          • Describe what type of manager you would be in the workplace and the conflict management style you would use. Explain how you know. [A]
         
        Step 3:  Write your report 
        • Organize your ideas in to a report format using sub headers. Write a report which answers the questions above. 
        • Proofread and format your report  

        Submission Requirements  

        • Upload your written work as a PDF file . Submission should be 350-500 words. 

         Success Criteria

        You will be assessed on the success criteria listed below:

         
        1. I can identify and describe a conflict and its causes (C2.2)  
        2. I can identify and define at least 2 different conflict management styles. (C2.4)  
        3. I can identify and explain how which conflict management style I would use to solve a conflict.C2.4)  
        4. I can explain the correct steps of the conflict resolution process to resolve the identified conflict (C1.2)  

        a. I can identify the most important facts in the case (A3.1) 

        b. I can identify and evaluate the most relevant and important ethical issues in the case study (A3.1) 

        c. I can outline the individuals, stakeholders, or entities being harmed (A3.1) 

        d. I can identify a series of choices that could resolve the issue (A3.1) 

        e. I can outline all possible consequences for each choice (A3.1) 

        f. I can develop and justify an action to address the issues of this case. (A3.1) 

        5. I can use business-related terminology effectively. (A2.1; A2.4)   
         
        6. I can present my ideas in an organized and logical sequence (A2.1; A2.4)  
         
        7. I can reflect on personal experiences to explain the type of manager I would be and what conflict management style I would use. (C2.4) 
         
        8. I can reflect on personal experience to explain how I approach conflict in my life (C2.4)   
         

        How to Submit

          • This activity is meant to be completed by you in your own words. It is meant to bring out your own thoughts and ideas. Please ensure that you keep citations to a minimum and that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.

          • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.

          • Submit your completed assignment using the "Add Submission" button located at the bottom of this page.
        Vocabulary (Quizlet)
        Conflict Management Style
        Learning Log: 3-3 (Target: 2 hours) — Questionnaire
        4
        3-4: Motivation (2 hours)
        Quizlet 3-4: Vocabulary Quizlet

         

         

        Lesson Vocabulary

        Quizlets

        Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

        For this lesson, focus on the following word:

          •  Motivation Theory
        Click on 3-4: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
        ▼
        One of the most important skills of an effective leader is the ability to motivate and inspire a team to reach their full potential. When employees do not feel motivated, often their manager is to blame. The central goal of this lesson will be to explore motivation and the various theories of motivation that help us understand the relationship between individual needs and maximizing workplace performance. We will also analyze motivational strategies and theories that expand on the relationship between motivation, reward, and performance.
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        The central goal of this lesson is to understand the contemporary theories of motivation and compare and contrast their advantages and disadvantages.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Explain how various theories of motivation contribute to an understanding of the relationship between individual needs, productivity, and performance
        2. Analyse various motivational strategies used by specific organizations
        3. Explain the relationship between motivation, rewards, and job performance
          • I can explain the main theories of management and give a real-life example of each theory
          • I can describe each motivation theory and explain it in detail
          • I can provide at least two advantages and two disadvantages of each motivational theory
          • I can compare and contrast at least two motivational theories and clearly explain their similarities and differences
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Analyze different motivational theories
        Motivation Theories

        What motivates employees? We will explore some well-known motivation theories.

        Page 3-4A: Motivation Theories

        Learning Goals

          • Explain how various theories of motivation contribute to an understanding of individual needs, productivity, and performance.

        Motivation Theories

        In this activity, students will learn about different theories of motivation and how people are motivated to perform based on needs and wants.

        Maslow
        Alderfer
        Herzberg
        McClelland
        Locke
        Adams
        Skinner

        Maslow's theory is called "The Hierarchy of Needs". It was developed in the 1940s and assumes that people will be motivated by their lowest unfulfilled need(s) on the hierarchy (seen in the picture on the right). Therefore, before a person is motivated by belonging (i.e., the need to be part of a team or group), he/she will first need to fulfill psychological needs (like getting food, shelter, water and clothing) as well as safety needs (like having a job, health, etc.)

        Managers can motivate employees by understanding the needs that they have. For instance, if many of your employees are at the esteem level of needs, then offering rewards based on belonging will not work. An example of this is when employees feel the need for recognition of work (achievement) and positive feedback. A manager who is rewarding these employees with social nights and team building exercises is trying to motivate through belonging. However, these needs are already fulfilled for the employees as many of them will already have friends and social circles. Therefore, the motivation may not work to improve performance.

        However, if the manager above were to offer promotions or positive appreciation, he/she may find that this type of reward is more motivating for his/her employees.

        Some considerations for Maslow's theory include the fact that not all needs can be filled all the time. For instance, having access to basic education is a safety need. It will ensure safety and security for your future. This is the second level of needs according to Maslow. However, it would be absurd to postulate that you would not be motivated to go to work (employment) because you have not had sex yet (which is one of the physiological needs that is lower on the hierarchy).

        Another consideration is that some needs cannot be satisfied and therefore, people may move up the hierarchy and be motivated by other needs first. For instance, a person with poor health (cancer for instance) may forgo this safety need. He/she still needs love and belonging, self esteem, confidence and achievement. For this person, the employment, health and resources in the safety tier of needs is not as important (at times) as other needs like family, friends and self esteem.

        Regardless of the considerations, Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs is still the basis, or starting point, for most other theories of motivation and behaviour. This theory is generally accepted as a good explanation of motivations and behaviours.

        Original Source for Image

        Alderfer:

        Alderfer's theory is called the "ERG Theory" and was published in 1969. It is called ERG theory based on its three categories that motivate people. Alderfer theorizes that people are motivated by:

        1. Existence Needs
        2. Relatedness Needs
        3. Growth Needs

        Existence needs are those things that people need in order to survive or exist. These include food, water, clothing, a home, health, employment, security and other material needs (i.e., a car, appliances, etc.). Relatedness needs are those things that promote or improve our relationships with others. These include things like belonging in a family, circle of friends, team or group. Relatedness needs also include things like being accepted and approved of at work and achieving goals and attaining status. The growth needs are more internal to a person and focus on personal growth. These needs include self esteem, creativity, life long learning and religion.

        Unlike Maslow, who used a hierarchy, Alderfer's theory is more of a separation of needs. Although he categorizes in much the same way that Maslow does, Alderfer notes that a person's needs are specific to time and situation. In  certain situations, growth needs may supercede related and existence needs. Furthermore, Alderfer notes a regressive quality to his theory, stating that if higher order needs are not met, then the person will put even more focus on the lower level needs in an effort to attain higher level needs. An example of this is when self esteem needs are not met. People who cannot achieve self esteem may focus more on belonging at work in order to achieve more esteem from others. This focuses on the relatedness needs because the growth needs are not or cannot be met.

        Original Source for Image

        Herzberg's theory is called "The Two Factor Theory" and was published in 1969. It states that there are only two motivating factors that affect human behaviour - they are hygiene factors and motivators. Hygiene factors cause dissatisfaction in the workplace when they are taken away. Hygiene factors; however, do not act as motivation to improve job performance. Thus, hygiene factors are things that employees expect to have, but are disappointed by their absence. Examples of hygiene factors include: basic wages, general benefits, job security and job safety. These are not motivators in the sense that you do not generally motivate employees by offering them job security. For example, a manager wouldn't motivate employees by offering basic wages in order to increase performance. However, if basic wages were taken away from employees, there would be immense dissatisfaction.

        Motivators are factors that create positive performance and encourage employees to increase production/efficiency. They often promote personal growth and include things like appreciation for work done, recognition, and achievement. The presence of motivators will lead to higher performance. However, the removal of motivators does not lead to job dissatisfaction (like hygiene factors). If motivators are removed, performance may decrease but employees will not generally become dissatisfied with their jobs.

        Both hygiene factors and motivators must be managed by leaders in order to encourage positive employee performance. Hygiene factors and motivators can be present at the same time and should be utilized by managers in motivation employees. The goal is to create a situation where there is high hygiene (hygiene factors are present) and high motivators (motivation to do better for intrinsic reasons is present).

        Because there are two factors, a workplace will fall into one of four categories:

          1. High hygiene, high motivators: This is an ideal situation where employees are satisfied with their jobs and they are motivated to perform.
          2. High hygiene, low motivators: This is a situation where employees are not complaining, but there is no motivation to do better. Perhaps a good union provides great working conditions, but employees are not interested in personal growth.
          3. Low hygiene, high motivators: This is a situation where employees have a lot of complaints about the job (low wages, no job security) but are motivated to do a good job because they like the work are are interested in personal growth. In many countries, teaching fits into this category. Wages are low and some working conditions are poor, but employees are still interested in getting better and performing at a high standard.
          4. Low hygiene, low motivators: This is a situation where employees are dissatisfied with their jobs and working conditions. They have no motivation to do a better job and so they do the bare minimum not to get fired.

        Original Source for Image

        McClelland's theory is also known as "Needs Theory". This theory was developed in the 1960s after Maslow's theory but was more specific to workplace motivation and managerial approaches to leading employees. McClelland suggests that needs are driven by personal life experiences and the opinions of the individual's culture. This is true for everyone regardless of age, sex, religion, social status or culture. He breaks the types of needs into three categories:

          1. The need for Achievement: in workplace settings, this is the need to succeed. It is the need to be recognized and become accomplished. This type of employee enjoys tasks that are successful based on effort and tends to avoid high risk projects due to the idea that luck has a role to play in the outcome.
          2. The need for Affiliation: in workplace settings, this is the need to belong, The need to feel needed by your colleagues, and the need to feel part of the company. This company will tend to not rock the boat, choosing collaboration over competition.
          3. The need for Power: in workplaces settings, this is the need for status. It is also the need to influence, teach or encourage others. There is a focus on personal prestige and competition with others is often seen as a win-lose scenario.

        Original Source for Image

        Locke presented the "Goal Setting Theory of Motivation" in the 1990s. The basic principle was that individuals were motivated to perform tasks based on having proper goals set up. Part of the goal would also include feedback and recognition. Thus, if goals were set properly, then employees would be motivated to achieve the goals and performance would increase.

        Locke would define good goals based on the following factors:

        1. The goal must be Clear: there should be some objective standard by which the goal can be measured. An example of an unclear goal is, "to increase sales". This is vague and unmeasurable - is a $0.01 increase in sales considered a success? A more clear goal would be, "to increase sales by 20%".
        2. The goal must be Challenging: if the goal is not challenging, then the motivation to perform the goal decreases. A challenge ensures that some sort of achievement is obtained at the end of the goal. If something is not challenging, then the worker will not feel achievement.
        3. The goal must contain Commitment: The employee must be a part of the goal setting process. If he/she is involved in setting the goal, he/she will be more committed to accomplishing it.
        4. The goal must contain Feedback: In order to further motivate, the process must include some sort of feedback and appraisal so that the employee can feel accomplished or set new goals to reach if he/she is off track.
        5. The goals must be Complex: the goal should be complex without being overwhelming and there must be considerations for time and enough resources to complete it.

        Today, we have converted Locke's theory into "SMART goals" this stands for:

        1. Specific: goals should be clear and specific
        2. Measurable: goals should have some quantifiable measurement
        3. Attainable: goals should be achievable
        4. Realistic: goals should be reasonable for the team/person
        5. Timely: goals should have a deadline or timeframe

        An example of a good SMART goal would be: to complete the BOH4M1 course and earn a grade above 80% before June 21st of this year.

        If you analyze the above SMART goal you will see that it is specific (it dictates a course and a mark), it is measurable (you can measure completeness and above or below 80%), it is attainable (the mark and timeframe are possible), it is reasonable for the person (assuming the student has attained 80% before and the current date is not June 19th), and it is timely (there is a definite date or time period attached).

        An example of a poor SMART goal would be: to try hard in my courses and get good grades.

        This SMART goal is not specific (what constitutes trying hard?), it is not measurable (how do you measure a good grade?), and it is not timely (there is not time period attached).

        Original Source for Image

        J. Stacy Adams introduced "Equity Theory" in the 1960s. Instead of basing motivation on needs or achievements like other theories, Adams bases equity theory on the individual's perceptions of the rewards. If the reward of an action is perceived as being high, then the employee will be motivated to perform at a higher level. People's perceptions of rewards are mostly based on the rewards that others get for doing similar things. Therefore, rewards are given value based on relative ratios to other rewards.

        An example of this can be seen in bonus structures. If employee A gets a 10% bonus this year, will he/she be motivated to work harder next year? While many of us will answer yes, we have to consider the perceptions of employee A. What if employee A received his/her 10% bonus and saw employee B receive a 20% bonus for doing the same job? Will employee A be demotivated? Will employee B be twice as motivated as employee A?

        These are all questions that can only be answered by looking at the employees' perceptions. Perhaps employee A perceives employee B to be a far superior worker and is content with a 10% bonus. Since we use perceptions to gauge rewards based on what we see others getting, it is often difficult for managers to create rewards based on perceptions.

          1. Perceptions are usually based on incomplete data - employees gather rewards data based on gossip, rumours, inferences and incomplete information.
          2. Perceptions are unique to individuals - one person may be more sensitive to fairness and equality and another may not.
          3. Perceptions are made over time - some individuals may not feel demotivated in employee A's situation if they believe that in the long run, things will work out for them.
          4. Perceptions are unknown to managers - it is not possible for a manager to know what an employee has seen, heard or is aware of.

        Original Source for Image

        In the 1930s, Burrhus Frederic Skinner coined the term "operant conditioning" which basically means changing one's behaviour by the use of reinforcement after a desired behaviour is shown. There are four types of operant conditioning:

          1. Positive Reinforcement: This strengthens the behaviour. It is the addition of a positive stimulus after a behaviour is shown. An example is getting a bonus after reaching a certain number of sales.
          2. Negative Reinforcement: This strengthens the behaviour. It is the removal of a stressor or negative stimulus after a behaviour is shown. An example is taking away the title "Rookie Salesman" after a salesperson reaches a certain amount of sales.
          3. Positive Punishment: This weakens the behaviour. It is the addition of a punishment for negative behaviour. For instance, if your boss takes one vacation day away from you every time you show up late for work, he is practicing positive punishment.
          4. Extinction: This weakens the behaviour. This occurs when there is no reward for positive behaviour. If an employee always cleans up the office kitchen and never receives thanks or appreciation or anything from his/her boss or colleagues, then eventually, he/she will stop the behaviour.

        Click on one of the tabs above to view the content.

          

        Examples of Motivation Theories

        Below is one example of Skinner's Operant Conditioning Model.

        This video humorously demonstrates and discusses the difference between positive punishment and negative reinforcement. Remember, negative reinforcement is a removal of a stressor (negative stumulus) after a behaviour is shown. On the other hand, positive punishment is the addition of an aversive consequence for negative behaviour. Clearly, the characters in the video were using positive punishment as they punished anyone who went off topic to prevent the group from getting distracted.

        The following video below discusses Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs. It explains each level of the hierarchy in great detail and provides examples of each major type of need. In addition, it explains a brief history behind the hierarchy.  Please watch:

           

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can explain the main theories of motivation and provide a real-life example of how each works.

        In this activity you will compare the different motivation theories.

        Assignment 3-4B: Motivation Theories Analysis [CTA]

        3-4B: Motivation Theories Analysis [CTA]

        This is a CTA Activity.  

         Learning Goals

          • Compare and contrast different theories of motivation;
          • Explain how various theories of motivation contribute to an understanding of individual needs, productivity, and performance;
          • Analyse various motivational strategies used by particular organizations.

         Assignment Overview

         

        The following activity is designed to ensure that you understand the various theories of motivation. Further, it will ensure that you are able to analyze and describe the advantages and disadvantages of each theory.

         

        Download the assignment below and fill in: 

            • A brief description of each theory.
            • Strengths of the theory (your own or those listed in the readings); and
            • Weaknesses of the theory (your own or those listed in the readings).
            • Do further research where necessary. 
            • Compare and contrast two different theories of motivation and outline and explain their similarities and differences.

         

        Complete the chart using Microsoft Word and discuss with your class.

         

         Success Criteria

        You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

        I can describe each theory of motivation and explain what it is.

        I can provide at least two strengths and two weaknesses of each theory of motivation.

        I can compare and contrast two different theories of motivation and explain their similarities and differences.
        Vocabulary (Quizlet)
        Motivation Theory
        Learning Log: 3-4 (Target: 2 hours) — Questionnaire
        R
        3-5: Unit 3 Highlights (Review)
        ▼
        These unit highlights will summarize the main concepts from the lessons of Unit 3. You can also use this page to check if you understand all of the concepts covered in Unit 3 and prepare for the unit test.
        3-1: The Communication Process

        Barriers to Effective Communication

        • Vocabulary: Communication, Sender, Receiver, Message, Feedback, Barriers, Deception, Distractions, Jargon, Ambiguity, Gestures
        • Explain the different steps in the communication process: Message Creation, Transmission, Reception, Translation, and Response
        • Identify the barriers to communication: Perception, Filtering, Language, Information Overload, and Cultural Misunderstanding
        • Understand the three types of noise: Psychological Noise, Physical Noise, and Semantic Noise

        Perception in Communication

        • Vocabulary: Perception, Kanizsa Triangle, Fundamental Attribution Error, Self-Serving Bias, Erroneous Judgements
        • Explain the importance of perception when making decisions
        • Understand attribution theory of perception (Selective Perception, Halo Effect, Contrast Effect, Projection, Stereotyping, etc.)

        Communication in the Workplace

        • Vocabulary: Non-Verbal Communication, Verbal Expressiveness, Body Language, Posture, Listener
        • Describe techniques to improve communication skills (Active Listening, Constructive Feedback, Channel Selection, Cross-Cultural Communication)
        • Explain the five elements of Active Listening: Pay Attention, Show that you are listening, Provide Feedback, Hold off on Judgement, and Respond Appropriately
        3-2: Stress & De-Stressing

        Factors that Contribute to Stress

        • Vocabulary: Stress, Stressor, Emotions, Behaviour
        • Explain the three types of stress: Acute Stress, Episodic Acute Stress, Chronic Stress

        Stress in the Workplace

        • Vocabulary: Eustress, Distress, Optimal Performance Point
        • Explain the differences between Eustress and Distress
        • Identify the sources of stress in the workplace (Difficult Bosses, Co-Workers, Working Conditions or Workload, Commute)

        Stress Management

        • Vocabulary: Wellness Programs, Stress Management
        • Understand stress management and stress reduction techniques
        • Explain wellness programs with real life examples
        3-3: Conflict & Its Management

        Factors that Contribute to Stress

        • Vocabulary: Conflict, Preferential Treatment, Internal Conflict, Managerial Criticism
        • Identify common causes of conflicts in the workplace (Lack of Communication, Stress, Overworked Employees, Poor Management, etc.)

        Conflict Management Styles

        • Vocabulary: Conflict Resolution Process, Conflict Management Style, Harmony, Outgunned, The Competing Shark, The Avoiding Turtle, The Accommodating Teddy Bear, The Compromising Fox, The Collaborating Owl
        • Explain the conflict resolution process
        • Understand the five conflict management styles: Avoiding, Competing, Accommodating, Compromising, and Collaborating
        3-4: Motivation

        Motivation Theories

        • Vocabulary: Motivation Theories, The Hierarchy of Needs, Existence Needs, Relatedness Needs, Growth Needs, The Two Factor Theory, Hygiene Factors, Motivators, Affiliation, Measurable, Attainable, Realistic, Timely, Equity Theory, Positive Reinforcement, Negative Reinforcement, Positive Punishment, Extinction
        • Understand motivation theories: Maslow's theory, Alderfer's theory, Herzberg's theory, etc.

        3-8: Motivation Case Study
        ▼
        The following case study assignment will assess your ability to apply the concepts you have learned to a hypothetical real-world scenario.
        Assignment *3-8: Motivation Case Study 5%

         
        *3-8: Motivation Case Study [5%] 

        This activity will be counted in your final grade.

        Learning Strands & Expectations

        • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 
        • Compare theories of how to motivate individuals and teams in a productive work environment. (C3) 
          •  

        Assignment Overview

        The following case study assignment will assess your ability to apply the concepts you have learned to a hypothetical real-world scenario.  You are only to use the LMS and the case study in answering your questions. Outside research is not required.

         

        Task  
         
        Step 1:  Read the Case Study 
        Read the case study below and make notes of the key facts or ideas from the case. 
         
        CASE STUDY 
        Rosedale Industries was featured in a business magazine aiming to shed light on modern-day business culture.  In preparation for the feature, the magazine spent several weeks documenting the daily workings of the business.  To gather perspective on Rosedale Industries, the magazine observed employees as they worked and conducted interviews with many of the company’s personnel. After weeks of observation, the business magazine was able to learn a lot about Rosedale Industries. 
        In terms of everyday life at the business, the magazine observed that Rosedale Industries started every Monday morning with a team meeting to debrief the previous week’s performance and provide a breakdown of the week to come.  During these team meetings, recognition and feedback were provided to team members. If feedback needed to be provided to an individual about their performance, a private meeting was set up with the individual where the managers could take time to outline the issue and improvements needed. Interestingly, during the team meetings, the managers always allocated time for employees to share any thoughts or stories. Employees would take this time to share any feel-good moments or raise any concerns or questions, and it was evident to see that communication was open, transparent, and welcoming.   
        During a typical day, employees were permitted multiple breaks, including extended time for lunch. They were also permitted appropriate accommodations for any religious or spiritual purposes.  Such breaks meant that employees were generally focused on their tasks. Managers would seldom have to remind employees to stay focused or return to their tasks. Management had also established open-door policies to address any urgent or concerning matters. 
        Through interviews with employees and managers, the magazine discovered many key features of the company.  Employees seemed to share a common sense of purpose and belonging.  Moreover, when employees were asked about what they appreciated about their employer, many employees unanimously mentioned the competitive salaries offered, the numerous benefits awarded in their contracts (paid vacation time, paid sick days, dental insurance, etc.), and even the introduction of a mental health day. Both employees and managers also mentioned the role of the company-wide group chat that was formed recently, stating that it allowed opportunities for building rapport and improving work relationships among staff.  According to one employee, the group chat offered “a way to understand my peers and co-workers that I might not have been able to during work hours”.  Similarly, one manager shared that the chat could act as a tool to quickly relay any urgent communication, as well as provide insights into employee interests to plan for future work events. 
        The most fascinating discovery by the magazine was the discovery that, at the request of employees during a scheduled Monday meeting, numerous programs and initiatives were being developed to improve and advance the careers of employees and managers. The most notable of these initiatives was the Rosedale Industries Lifelong Education initiative, designed to provide employees with the opportunity to enroll in a variety of courses to improve existing skills, add new skills, and develop new competencies.  This initiative was designed to allow for smoother and more apparent mobility within the company and to assist employees in enhancing their personal curriculum vitae.  A second popular initiative, the Rosedale Gives Back initiative, aimed to provide opportunities for employees and managers to become more involved with their communities through volunteer and charitable work.  When asked about these programs and initiatives, a few employees expressed their gratitude and excitement for the opportunities and specifically mentioned that they appreciated having their ideas heard and reflected in company programs. 
        Overall, the business magazine wrote a favorable feature about Rosedale Industries and was grateful for their decision to shadow Rosedale Industries.  They believed that their feature demonstrated a positive example of how modern businesses should aim to build a work culture and model employee/ manager relationships. 
         
        Step 2:  Reflect on the Case 
        1. Reflect on your knowledge of motivation and motivation theories.  Decide, using your knowledge of the case, which motivation theory listed below was best demonstrated and applied by Rosedale Industries.  Explain your decision and justify with at least 2 pieces of evidence and/ or examples from the case. 
          • Alderfer’s ERG Theory 
          • McClelland’s Needs Theory 
          • Adam’s Equity Theory 
        2. Define and describe Herzberg’s Two-Factor Theory.  Explain how Rosedale Industries applies this theory by identifying 2 examples of each factor from the case.   
        3. Define and describe Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs.  For each level of the pyramid, explain how the methods that are adopted by Rosedale Industries motivate its workers.   
        4. Reflect on the working conditions described at Rosedale Industries.  If you were an employee of Rosedale Industries, do you think that you would be motivated to work for them?  Explain your decision and justify with 2 pieces of evidence or examples from the case and 1 piece of evidence/ example from your personal life. 
         
        Step 3:  Write your Report 
        • Organize your answers into a report that answers the questions above. Use sub headings to organize your ideas.  
        • Proofread and format your report. 
          
        Submission Requirements
        • Upload your written work as a PDF file
         

        Success Criteria Checklist

        You will be assessed on the success criteria that are listed here:

        1. I can reflect on the case study and decide which motivation theory is best demonstrated and applied. (C3.1; C3.2) 
        2. I can define and discuss Herzberg’s Two-Factor Theory and explain how it is applied in the case study. (C3.1, C3.2) 
        3. I can define and describe Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs and make connections between each level of the pyramid and the case study. (C3.1, C3.2) 
        4. I can use business-related terminology effectively. (A2.1; A2.4)  
        5. I can present my ideas in an organized and logical sequence (A2.1; A2.4)  
        6. I can reflect on working conditions and personal experience to make a conclusion and justify whether I would be motivated to work for the business described in the case study. (C3.3) 

        How to Submit

          • This activity is meant to be completed by you in your own words. Please ensure that you use citations according to the activity requirements and follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract. Be sure to always incorporate your own thoughts and ideas.
          • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.
          • Submit your completed assignment using the "Add Submission" button located at the bottom of this page.

        M
        Midterm Reports and Reflection
        ▼

        Take a few minutes now to reflect on your work habits, your experience in the course, and the support you received from teachers.

        Feedback Reflection 2 [Work Habits, Learning Experience, and Teacher Support]
        4
        Planning & Controlling
        6 Lessons + Reflection + Unit Highlights + Unit Test • Sections 29-38
        ▼
        Welcome to Unit 4. In this unit, students will learn how "planning" plays an important role in business success. Students will be able to demonstrate proper planning techniques in a variety of leadership situations. Students will study strategic planning from an organizational view point and will analyze how leaders respond to internal and external pressures to enact change. Finally, we will study how "control" is an important concept and how it is used properly by management.

        Overall Expectations / Learning Objectives:

        • Analyse the importance of planning to the success of an organization
        • Demonstrate an understanding of appropriate planning tools and techniques in a variety of situations
        • Analyse the relationship between strategic planning and the success of an organization
        • Analyse how companies respond to internal and external pressures for change
        • Assess the importance of control in management
        1
        4-1: The Importance of Planning (2 hours)
        ▼
        Planning plays an important role in business success. It should always be one of the first steps when formulating a business strategy. Arlene Dickinson, Canadian investor and CEO of Venture Communications, talks about the importance of planning. As you just learned, leaders must first put in place a strategy and plan before beginning the tactical procedures of running and building a business. Without a well-written plan, employees have nothing to follow.
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        The central learning in this lesson is an understanding of the importance of planning and the five steps in the planning process. You will then be called upon to apply your understanding to real life examples by planning an event.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Explain the importance of individual and group creativity in planning
        2. Demonstrate how creativity is an important part of the planning process
          • I can explain the importance of planning in the management process
          • I can explain why creativity is important in the planning process
        3. Identify different steps in the planning process
        4. Describe the planning process and its benefits to the organization
          • I can identify and explain the five steps in the planning process
          • I can describe the planning process in a business organization
        5. Apply different problem-solving strategies to a variety of management planning challenges
        6. Communicate strategies and apply planning tools to management problems
          • I can apply the planning process to a real life situation
          • I can give an example of how the planning process can be used to achieve a goal
        7. Apply the planning process to a real life management situation
        8. Describe the organizational benefits of good planning
          • I can apply the planning process to a real life management situation
          • Describe at least three to five organizational benefits of planning
          • Effectively communicate in 200-500 words the benefits of good planning
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Critically analyze and evaluate the benefits of planning
        • Apply your planning skills to a real-life event
        The Importance of Planning

        From an organizational and business standpoint, what do we mean when we say "planning"? And why must a business leader know how to plan effectively? In this lesson we will explore one of the fundamentals of business success: effective planning.

        Page 4-1A: The Importance of Planning

        Learning Goals

          • Analyse the importance of individual and group creativity in planning.
          • Demonstrate how creativity is an important part of the planning process.

          

        What is Planning? 

        As you learned in Lesson 1-2B, the management process was described as having the following fundamental components: planning, organizing, leading, and controlling. The first of these functions, "planning", sets the stage for the other fundamentals by providing a sense of direction. It is a process of setting goals or objectives and determining how best to accomplish them. Planning involves deciding exactly what you want to accomplish, creating strategies to achieve these goals, and organizing the tasks and schedules that are necessary to accomplish them. 

        The Importance of Planning 

        When planning is done well, it creates a solid platform on which management functions can build. The importance and centrality of planning in management is shown in the figure below.

          

        Simon Sinek on the Importance of Planning

        In this video below, Simon Sinek discuss the importance of planning and why planning should be a continuous process rather than a once-a-year event. He concludes by recalling the words of American President Dwight D. Eisenhower that, "Planning is everything, the plan is nothing".  Unlike much of the corporate world, the military is always planning, adjusting plans, and looking for contingencies if something were to go wrong.  In this sense, good leaders should be like the military and use a never-ending process of planning and strategizing.

         

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can explain the importance of planning in the management process.

        I can explain why creativity is important in the planning process.

         

        The Planning Process

        In today's fast paced world, it is essential that businesses stay organized and one step ahead of the competition. Effective planning allows companies to do both. So, what are the keys to effective planning?

        Page 4-1B: The Planning Process

        Learning Goals

          • Identify the different steps involved in the planning process.
          • Describe the planning process and its benefits to the organization.

           

        The Importance of Planning

        The planning process involves a set of steps that business leaders use to plan events, activities, budgets, corporate strategies, etc. Setting goals and objectives, determining current position, forecasting future situations, analyzing alternatives, choosing strategies, implementing strategies, and evaluating results are all integral components of a plan. Planning should focus attention on objectives that identify the specific results or desired outcomes. Planning should also create a real, concrete plan that includes a statement of action steps to be taken in order to accomplish objectives. 

        Definition

        The most important step in the planning process is the definition of goals and objectives. Goals, like targets, need to be hit. Without properly formed goals, the rest of the planning process will not have sufficient structure or direction. When planning, it is important to make goals as specific as possible. Following the SMART Goal format is encouraged to ensure that goals have been clearly defined.  It is also important to focus on a few goals rather than many.  As you increase the number of goals, you increase the complexity of the plan and the strategies needed to achieve success.

         

        What is the SMART Goal Method?

        SMART is an acronym that you can use to guide your goal setting. To make sure your goals are clear and reachable, each one should be:

          • Specific (simple, sensible, significant).

          • Measurable (meaningful, motivating).

          • Achievable (agreed, attainable).

          • Relevant (reasonable, realistic and resourced, results-based).

          • Time-bound (time-based, time-limited, time/cost limited, timely, time-sensitive).

        Take a look at the infographic below for specific examples of SMART Goals: 

        Position

        After you have properly defined goals and objectives, business leaders need to determine where they stand in relation to their goals.  This is known as a "current position". This involves determining what the company has been, what factors are still needed to achieve outstanding goals, what barriers lie between the company and these goals.  Clearly defining a current position will enable managers to better create strategies. In the end, if a manager or leader does not clearly know both where the company is today and where it is going in the future, it will get lost and likely fail.  

        Prediction

        Predicting involves forecasting ideas about what could happen in the future. Predicting future situations, barriers, paradigm shifts, reactions, etc. will help leaders develop strategies that will prepare for unexpected scenarios. In this stage of the planning process, leaders will hypothesize about future conditions and situations that can occur and create contingency plans. Predictions do not have to be absolute, they just have to be probable or reasonable.

        Option

        The option stage is where strategies are generated.  Each strategy is called an option. Each option is based on predictions that have been made about the likelihood of an event occurring. Some people call these options contingencies. A contingency is an action that occurs based on some other situation happening. Options should always be written down and properly prepared, even if you decide not to use them; options are valuable to have in case they are actually needed later or the situations or scenarios suddenly change again.

        Decision

        This stage involves evaluating all of the options (strategies) developed in the previous stage and choosing one with which to move forward.  Leaders will then make the decision to "action" the strategy. This does not mean that a leader will follow this strategy, and only this strategy, going forward.  In fact, a contingent strategy may have to be used at any time.  Whether or not that becomes necessary, the important point to remember is that leaders must determine the best course of action and make a decision to move forward with the best option available.

        Implementation

        In this stage, leaders and managers will implement (put into action) the strategy or strategies that have been decided upon.  They will create schedules and assign tasks to people. This is where the work on the plan gets accomplished. Often times, managerial teams will continue to work back and forth between the option, decision, and implementation stages as situations change. When in the implementation stage, however, it is important to ensure that the work being done is contributing to the overall plan goal(s)/objective(s).

        Evaluation

        This stage is used to assess the success of the plan. Once the implementation begins, it is important to begin the evaluation process as well. This means gathering data, information and other resources that will help determine how successful the plan is developing and what changes need to be made along the way. During this process, it is always important to link the success of the plan to the overall goal(s) and objective(s). If the plan is to be successful, a proper evaluative measure must be put in place that can easily identify success or failure. If a plan is about to fail, or does fail, it is the work done in the evaluation stage that should identify why things did not work out.

        The Planning Process

        The planning process involves five steps as explained above, they will be summarized here:

        1. Define your objectives.
        2. Determine where you stand in relation to objectives - position.
        3. Develop premises regarding future conditions - prediction.
        4. Analyze alternatives and make a plan - Option & Decision.
        5. Implement the plan and evaluate the results - Implementation & Evaluation.

        The planning process just described seems simple and straightforward. But remember, planning is not something managers do while working alone in quiet rooms, free from distractions, and at scheduled times. When carried out properly, it is an ongoing process, often continuous, even while dealing with an otherwise busy and demanding work setting.  Like other decision-making in organizations, the best planning is done with the active participation of those people whose work efforts will eventually determine whether or not the plans are successful. 

             

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can identify and explain the five steps in the planning process.

        I can describe the planning process in a business organization.

          

        Following the planning process is key to organizational success. Now, we will apply what we have learned about the planning process to some sample scenarios.

        Page 4-1C: The Planning Process: An Example

        Learning Goals

          • Apply different problem-solving strategies to a variety of management planning challenges;
          • Communicate strategies and apply planning tools to management problems.

        ▼
        There are many planning tools and techniques that leaders can use when developing company strategy. Scenario planning is an example of a planning technique that you will learn about in this lesson. Scenario practice helps employees to tackle difficult situations while their manager can offer insights and feedback in real time. Scenarios are a very useful tool to plan, and prepare for, on-the-spot contingencies.
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        The primary learning in this lesson centers around the various tools and strategies used in the planning process. Students will critically analyze the advantages and disadvantages of each tool or strategy in the planning process.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Describe tools and strategies used in the planning process
          • I can describe the main tools and strategies used in the planning process
          • I can provide at least one advantage and one disadvantage of each tool or strategy
        2. Explain and demonstrate the use of effective short-term and long-term planning tools
          • I can explain and demonstrate the use of effective short- and long-term planning tools
        3. Create a long term plan
        4. Demonstrate proper use of short-term and long-term planning tools
          • I can create a long-term plan
          • I can demonstrate proper use of short-term and long-term planning tools
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Explain the use of effective short- and long-term planning tools
        • Critically analyze the advantages and disadvantages of each of the tools and strategies
        Planning Strategies & Tools

        There are many different ways to plan in business. Companies use a variety of strategies to help them with planning. Let's explore some common planning strategies.

        Page 4-2A: Planning Strategies

        Learning Goals

          • Describe tools and strategies used in the planning process.

           

        Planning Strategies

        Managers use strategies and tools when they partake in the larger planning process. In this lesson, we will study some of the strategies (like participatory planning, contingency planning, scenario planning and benchmarking) and some of the tools (like tactical plans, operational plans, strategic plans, budgeting and forecasting) that managers use to aid them in the planning process.

        Participatory Planning

        This type of planning strategy has its roots in urban planning (land and how it is used). It involves all the stakeholders of an issue coming together to plan the best course of action. In a business, it involves all the relevant employees having a say in the planning process. Therefore, if a business were planning to change its brand, all of the advertising, marketing and probably sales employees would be involved in the planning process. This strategy allows everyone to have a voice or say in the matters at hand. On the positive side, it can generate a lot of ideas and alternatives. It is a very thorough process and it empowers lower level employees to be a part of larger business decisions. On the negative side, it can be very time consuming and it can become cumbersome and difficult to accommodate everyone's opinions and ideas. Furthermore, it is susceptible to "group think" which describes a situation in which members of a group tend to think alike and agree for the sake of group harmony.

         

        This video below displays a real life example of participatory planning. As you will see, employees from different departments come together and collaborate as they try to determine the best course of action for the company as a whole.

         

         

        Benchmarking

        This is the process of comparing your company to other companies or an industry standard. Businesses will set up "targets" for itself based on information from other businesses or standards in the industry. Usually, targets are set up based on times, quality, costs or profits. For example, if Company A was budgeting for next year, it may benchmark other companies' profits (Company B, Company C and Company D) in order to plan what its profits next year may be. Similarly, if the industry standard is 200 days to produce an airplane, then an airplane manufacturer like Bombardier may plan to manufacture an airplane every 190 days - because that slightly beats the industry benchmark. An advantage of benchmarking is that it encourages performance improvement. Since you are constantly comparing your business' output to others, it can increase competition and efficiency. A negative aspect of benchmarking is that it can lead to complacency. If your business is constantly only reaching the benchmark, there may be no motivation to be better or even more efficient - a business can become happy with meeting the industry standard or average, which rarely leads to long-term success.

        Coca-Cola and Pepsi are two real life examples of companies who use benchmarking as a planning tool. Competitors like Coca-Cola and Pepsi often monitor each others performance and try to outperform each other by creating a better and/or cheaper product. Below is a Pepsi commercial showing the company trying to top whatever Coca-Cola does.

          

        Scenario Planning

        This strategy involves creating simulations (sometimes games) in which employees can participate. The scenarios are used to practice different events or contingencies that could occur. Then, when the actual events happen, the planning has already been done (in the simulations) and make it easier to choose the best course of action. In businesses, scenario planning is done in stock market simulations, emergency situations, product failure recalls, public relations activities, etc. Companies like insurance companies and finance companies use scenario planning all the time to help assess the risk of new ventures/clients. One major advantage of this strategy is that it prepares employees for difficult situations within the safety of a simulation so that they can better handle future events. One disadvantage is that it can create a false sense of security and preparedness as most simulations do not occur the same way in real business situations.

        Contingency Planning

        This strategy is very similar to scenario planning except it usually does not involve simulations; rather a discussion or formation of a list of alternatives. Contingency planning is based on "what if..." scenarios. Businesses will make different plans based on different circumstances. An example is a contingency plan for a dinner fundraiser. If 100 people register, we will rent out Hall A that can hold up to 150 people. But if 500 people register we will rent out Hall B that can hold up to 650 people. However, if 1000 people register, we will rent out Hall C that can hold up to 2000 people. All of the plans are contingent on the number of registrations. An advantage of contingency planning is that you are prepared for many different scenarios. A disadvantage is that it takes a lot of time to create multiple plans for situations knowing that many of them will not come to fruition. This time may better be spent focusing on improving the primary plan.

         

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can describe the main tools and strategies used in the planning process.

        I can provide at least one advantage and one disadvantage of each tool or strategy. 

          

        Leaders must know how to plan for both the short and long term. Let's find out how we can use different planning tools to help with organizational strategy and its implementation.

        Page 4-2B: Planning Tools

        Learning Goals
