        Strategic planning and establishing company culture are two of the key responsibilities of organizational leaders. McDonalds CEO, Steve Easterbrook, discusses why he recently changed McDonald's motto, a key reflection of a company's corporate strategy. This connects to the central learning in this lesson which is to understand the levels and types of strategic plans that businesses use in order to build success.
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        The central goals of this lesson are to explore various types of strategic plans and how organizations use them to meet their overall mission. You will then research the strategic plans of various businesses and how effectively they have been executed.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Understanding the levels and types of strategic plans that businesses use
          • I can explain the levels and types of strategic plans that businesses use to carry out their mission statement
        2. Explain the importance of the strategic planning process and describe the levels of strategic planning in an organization
        3. Discuss which types of strategic planning are best suited for each level
          • I can explain the importance of the strategic planning process and describe the levels of strategic planning
          • I can explain types and examples of strategic planning best suited for situations in each level
        4. Describe the types of strategic plans used by specific organizations
          • I can describe examples of strategic plans used by real life organizations
          • I can find and research one company that uses each type of Strategic Plan
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Critically analyze different types of strategic plans
        • Evaluate the strategic plans of companies
        Mission Statements

        What is a mission statement? Why do companies have mission statements? Let's start by learning about the characteristics and components of a mission statement.

        Page 4-3A: Mission Statements

        Learning Goals

          • Understanding the levels and types of strategic plans that businesses use in order to better carry out its mission statement.

           

        Mission Statements

        A mission statement is a company's description of its main purpose or "raison d'etre". It states why the company exists and what it is trying to accomplish. It is a long standing and often well established phrase that rarely changes and always helps to guide the company toward the fulfillment of its goals.

        Characteristics of a Mission Statement

        A mission statement will usually have some or all of the following characteristics:

          1. Vision: The main goal of the mission statement is to provide vision for the business. It directs the employees and acts as a guide to attain its goals. When the vision is properly communicated, it enables others to work to help achieve the vision and goals. So mission statements frequently contain wording such as "to be the best", "the highest quality", and "better than the competition".
          2. Broad Scope: The mission statement should be stated using general terms and ideas. There should not be any timelines, reference to specific operations, or talk of product/service names, as all of these are subject to change. Instead, the statement should talk about longstanding goals and ideals.
          3. Simplicity: The mission statement should be easily understood by employees, customers, and the public in general. A business should try not to use elaborate or highly technical terms when describing its purpose.
          4. Realistic: The goals in the statement need to be attainable and realistic. Having unattainable vision may lead to a perception that the business is not credible. Your goals need to be direct and achievable.
          5. Short and Concise: A mission statement is usually only one or two sentences long. It provides an overview of vision and goals and it does not need to go into any detail about process. Employees and even the public should be able to easily remember it.
          6. Inspirational: The mission statement illustrates the company's philosophy to the employees and public. If it is inspirational, people will remember it and want to be involved in the company. If employees attach themselves to the company's mission, they are more likely to work to help achieve its goals.

         Components of a Mission Statement

        There are many discussions about what should actually be put into a mission statement. You may see as few as one component or as many as a dozen.  As a general guideline, four components that are deemed most important should be addressed:  

          1. Vision or Goal: What does the company believe, and where is it going?
          2. Unique Position: What strengths or unique position does the company have?
          3. Survival: Does the statement show a willingness for growth?
          4. Customers and Employees: Does the statement show concern for customers and employees?

        The video below will recap and summarize the characteristics and components of a mission statement that we have discussed in this lesson.

          

        Mission Statement Examples

        Apple

        Apple designs Macs, the best personal computers in the world, along with OS X, iLife, iWork and professional software. Apple leads the digital music revolution with its iPods and iTunes online store. Apple has reinvented the mobile phone with its revolutionary iPhone and App Store, and is defining the future of mobile media and computing devices with iPad.

         

        Nike

        To bring inspiration and innovation to every athlete* in the world. (*If you have a body, you are an athlete)

         

        Walmart

        We save people money so they can live better.

         

        Rosedale Academy

        The mission of Rosedale Academy is to invoke students’ curiosity and inspire them to think critically in the process of developing a deep understanding of the complexities of our world. Our school believes that providing a rich and engaging learning environment will stimulate students to become active partners in their learning journey with us.


        Google

        Google’s mission is to organize the world’s information and make it universally accessible and useful.

         

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can explain the levels and types of strategic plans that businesses use in order to better carry out its mission statement.

         

        Strategic Planning

        In order for businesses to be successful, some strategic planning must occur at all levels of corporate structure.

        Page 4-3B: Levels of Strategic Planning

        Learning Goals

          • Explain the importance of the strategic planning process and describe the levels of strategic planning in an organization.
          • Discuss which types of strategic planning are best suited for situations in each of the levels of strategic planning.

           

        Levels of Strategic Planning

        Remember from lesson 4-2 that strategic planning describes overall planning; it usually is long term and it is developed according to the mission statement goals and objectives. In this activity, we will further break down strategic planning into three levels: corporate, business unit, and functional.

        Corporate Level Strategic Planning

        At the corporate level, upper management will make decisions about the entire business' goals, directions and actions. Corporate level planning generally deals with the entire scope of business operations strategy, competition and overall efficiency.  Upper level managers will tend to look at the following:

          • Business Reach: Management will ask questions like: Should we expand our markets? Should we expand our product/service line? Should we create more business units? Should we partake in international trade?
          • Managing People and Units: Upper management will coordinate all of the middle business units to ensure information is flowing between them. They will also try to ensure that the company is as synergetic as possible. Finally, they will determine ways that people are to be managed:  Will the company use a centralized or decentralized form of management?
          • Budgets: One of the most important aspects of corporate level planning is the corporate budget. Upper management will  determine how much money each department is allocated. They will also determine where the money is to be spent and invested. Will profits be put into expansion, infrastructure, raises/bonuses, higher dividends, or company stock buybacks, etc.?

        At the end of the day, the corporation's upper management is responsible for the overall direction of the company and creating value/growth.

         

         Business Unit Level Planning

        The business unit (also known as departments or divisions in the company) will also have to do some strategic planning. Its job is to use the corporate level plan and implement a business unit plan that will support the corporate strategic plan and vision. The business unit will deal with competition, products and services.

          • Competition: Upper and middle management is concerned with the business' position in the competitive market. Questions they ask may include: Should we target competition? Where should we localize our competitive efforts? What unique selling propositions should we push? How should we position ourselves against our competition?
          • Products and Services: Managers will forecast changes in supply and demand, changes in technology, changes in consumer trends (fads) and will modify business unit plans to enhance success. They may also integrate business activities in the marketing process in order to be more efficient.
          • Budget: Business unit levels must also plan budgets. Their budgets are more concerned with marketing/advertising, lobbying, research and development and minimizing costs in production and employee salaries.

        Where the corporate level plan deals more with the institution and how it runs, the business level plan deals more with the money - how to get it and use it efficiently.

         

         Functional Level Planning

        Functional level planning occurs with middle managers and lower managers usually within business units (departments or divisions). Most of the strategies here are created in order to support the business unit plans and the corporate level plans. In fact, the functional strategies that are put in place are usually done to create information or input for the higher level planning strategies. Thus, functional plans are done with the greater business plans and corporate plans in mind. Functional planning strategies can basically be broken down into two types:

          • The execution of business and corporate directives/plans: this includes creating tactical plans and strategic plans in order to carry out decisions that have been made in the business unit and corporate level plans.
          • The planning of strategies that can gather information or act as inputs for business level and corporate level plans: this may include planning programs that gather data, document information and execute trials of strategies to determine best practices/efficiencies.

        The functional plans are most closely related to tactical plans; however the difference is that they are usually linked to the business unit and corporate level plans. If you can see a direct link to corporate or business strategy in a low level plan, it is most likely the result of functional planning. Functional planning will also include tactical plans at times when the execution of corporate and business level directives are needed.

         

        Example

        The video below outlines how strategic planning is divided within different levels of a corporation:  corporate, business unit, and functional level strategy.

         

          

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can explain the importance of the strategic planning process and describe the levels of strategic planning in an organization.

        I can discuss which responsibilities are associated with each type of strategic planning.

         

        A wide variety of strategic plans are used in different situations and levels. Some plans are used to help grow or stabilize a company, while others are used to reduce the activities of a company.

        Page 4-3C: Types of Strategic Plans

        Learning Goals

          • Describe the types of strategic plans used by specific organizations.

           

        Types of Strategic Plans

        There are three types of strategic plans that businesses use. They are growth, stability, and retrenchment. The following is an excerpt taken from http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/management/Or-Pr/Planning.html

        Growth Strategies

        Growth strategies are designed to expand an organization's performance, usually as measured by sales, profits, product mix, or market coverage. Typical growth strategies involve one or more of the following:

        Concentration Strategy

        The firm attempts to achieve greater market penetration by becoming very efficient at servicing its market with a limited product line.

        Vertical Integration Strategy

        The firm attempts to expand the scope of its current operations by undertaking business activities formerly performed by one of its suppliers (backward integration) or by undertaking business activities performed by a business in its distribution channel.

        Diversification Strategy

        The firm moves into different markets or adds different products to its mix. If the products or markets are related to its existing operations, the strategy is called concentric diversification. If the expansion is in products and markets unrelated to the existing business, the diversification is called conglomeration.

         

        Stability Strategies

        When firms are satisfied with their current rate of growth and profits, they may decide to employ a stability strategy. This strategy basically extends existing advertising, production, and other strategies. Such strategies typically are found in small businesses in relatively stable environments. The business owners often are making a comfortable income operating a business that they know, and see no need to make the psychological and financial investment that would be required to undertake a growth strategy.

         

         

         

        Retrenchment Strategies

        Retrenchment strategies involve a reduction in the scope of a corporation's activities. Retrenchment strategies can be subdivided into the following:

        Turnaround Strategy

        Firms undertake a temporary reduction in operations in an effort to make the business stronger and more viable in the future. These moves are popularly called downsizing or rightsizing. The hope is that a temporary belt tightening will allow the firm to pursue a growth strategy at some future point.

        Divestment

        A firm elects to spin off, shut down, or sell a portion of its business. This strategy would commonly be used with a business unit identified as a dog by the BCG Model (You will study this in the next lesson). Typically, a poor performing unit is sold to another company and the money is reinvested in a business with greater potential.

        Liquidation Strategy

        The most extreme form of retrenchment, liquidation, involves the selling or closing of the entire business operation, usually when there is no future for the business. Employees are released, buildings and equipment are sold, and customers no longer have access to the product. This generally is viewed as a strategy of last resort, and is one that most managers work hard to avoid.

        The full article can be found at: http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/management/Or-Pr/Planning.html#ixzz3QDuQquVu

            

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can describe the three types of strategic plans used by organizations.

         

        Review your understanding of the main planning concepts in 4-1, 4-2, and 4-3. Key themes: The importance of planning, the Planning Process, planning strategies, planning tools, types of strategic plans.

        Quiz 4-3D: Planning Concepts Self-Check

        Step 1: Review the Concepts 
        Review your understanding of the main planning concepts in 4-1, 4-2, and 4-3.  Key themes to focus on:  The importance of planning, the Planning Process, planning strategies, planning tools, types of strategic plans 
         
        Step 2:  Complete the Quiz 
        Answer the multiple-choice questions below to test your knowledge of the planning concepts.

        Vocabulary (Quizlet)
        Business Reach Concentric Diversification Conglomeration Growth Strategy Mission Statement Retrenchment
        Learning Log: 4-3 (Target: 2 hours) — Questionnaire
        4
        4-4: Analyzing Organization's Strategic Plans (4 hours)
        Quizlet 4-4: Vocabulary Quizlet

         

         

        Lesson Vocabulary

        Quizlets

        Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

          • BCG Matrix
          • Cash Cow
          • PEST Analysis
          • Question Mark
          • Star
          • SWOT Analysis
        Click on 4-4: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
        ▼
        Analysis tools for strategic plans are almost as important as the plans themselves. By properly analyzing strategic plans, businesses are better able to adapt, mitigate future failures, and increase future successes. There are many advantages to SWOT analysis and other types of analysis in the process of developing a strategic plan.
        Lesson Overview — Key Idea

        The central goal of this lesson is to have students understand a variety of analytical tools that are used to create and assess strategic plans. Some of these include: SWOT analysis, P.E.S.T. analysis, the BCG Matrix, and Porter's Five Forces. You will learn about each of these tools and then apply your understanding in the summative evaluation for a real life case study.

        Learning Goals & Success Criteria
        1. Analyse organizational strategic plans using a variety of management tools
        2. Make suggestions as to how a company can improve its strategic plan
          • I can explain what a SWOT analysis is, what it is used for, and how to complete one
          • I can explain and perform a PEST analysis
          • I can explain and use Porter's Five Forces Model to analyze the market and create a strategic plan
          • I can explain and perform a BCG Matrix for a company's products
          • I can apply my understanding to a real life example
          • I can evaluate a company's BCG Matrix and make recommendations for a strategic plan
        3. Analyse the two levels of corporate culture and describe the relationship between corporate culture and strategic planning
          • I can analyse the two levels of corporate culture and describe the relationship between corporate culture and strategic planning
        Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
        • Critically think about management tools and their use
        • Evaluate the strategic plans of companies
        Management Tools

        There are many different ways of analyzing organizations' strategic plans. One of the most common is the "S.W.O.T. Analysis" - Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats.

        Page 4-4A: S.W.O.T. Analysis

        Learning Goals

          • Analyse organizational strategic plans using a variety of management tools.

           

        SWOT Analysis

        A SWOT analysis (alternatively SWOT matrix) is a structured planning method used to evaluate the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats involved in a project or in a business venture. A SWOT analysis can be used on a product, place, industry or person. It involves specifying the objective of the business venture or project and identifying the internal and external factors that are favourable and unfavourable to achieve that objective.

        SWOT analysis addresses internal strengths and weaknesses relative to the external opportunities and threats. These are classed as being either "Internal" of "External".

        Internal

        Strengths Weaknesses
          • Company’s  competitive advantage
          • Excellent employees
          • Strong market share
          • Reputation
          • New products and technologies
          • Good financing
          • Old equipment and technology
          • Minimal R&D
          • Poor planning
          • Reputation
          • Poor management


        External

        Opportunities Threats
          • New markets
          • Economy
          • Poor competition
          • Growth strategy
          • Possible new technology
          • New competitors
          • Lack of resources
          • Government regulations
          • Substitute products
          • Changing market preferences



        Take a look at the following infographic for examples of a SWOT Analysis for three companies:

         

           

        Success Criteria

        Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

        I can explain what a SWOT analysis is and how to complete one.

         

        Similar to the SWOT analysis, a PEST analysis focuses on political, economic, social, and technological factors.

        Page 4-4B: P.E.S.T. Analysis

        Learning Goals

          • Analyse organizational strategic plans using a variety of management tools.

           

        P.E.S.T. Analysis

        PEST analysis includes the remote external environment elements such as political, economic, social and technological (PESTLE adds legal/regulatory and ecological/environmental) factors that can impact decision-making. A PEST analysis is best described simply as an analysis of the external environment.

         

        Politics

        • Levels of Government
        • Rules and Regulations (laws, taxes, permits, accounting, etc.)
        • Crown corporations
        • International governments

         

                                                                                               

        Economics

        • Country's economic state (boom, recession, growth, etc.)
        • Borrowing interest rates
        • The current dollar exchange or value of the dollar
        • Inflation rate
        • Unemployment rate
        • Supplier power
        • Buyer power
        • Stage in product life cycle

          

        Social

        • Demographic changes
        • Lifestyle changes
        • Social values
        • Current trends/fads

         

         

         

          Technology

          • Available technology
          • Ability to create new technology
          • Use of information technology

          Success Criteria

          Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

          I can explain and perform a PEST analysis.

           

          We will continue to build on our analytical toolbox by learning about Porter's Five Competitive Forces Model.

          Page 4-4C: Porter's Five Competitive Forces Model

          Learning Goals

            • Analyse organizational strategic plans using a variety of management tools.
            • Make suggestions as to how a company can improve its strategic plan.

             

          Porter's Five Competitive Forces Model

          Porter's five forces demonstrate the competitiveness of an industry.  Businesses can judge the potential for profit based on the level of competitiveness. The main job of managers is to align the business corporate strategy with Porter's model in order to find ways to modify the competitive forces in order to improve the business' competitive position. Management should use Porter's model to make decisions about how to influence or take advantage of different parts of their industry.

           

          Threat of New Entrants

          Competition in an industry will be increased if it is easy for new businesses to enter the industry. New businesses can change the nature of the industry by increasing supply, changing customer loyalty, adding new technologies, etc. The thread of new entrants is basically determined by the barriers to entry. Factors that affect the threat of new entrants include:

            • Whether or not start up costs are high
            • Whether or not customer loyalty is well established
            • Whether or not there is an availability of resources needed to produce products or offer services
            • Whether or not there is sufficient access to raw materials
            • Whether or not there is access to distribution channels
            • Whether or not there is a lot of legislation or government control

            Bargaining Power of Customers

          Increased competition can arise based on how much power the customers have to control the prices (and therefore the profits) of the businesses in the industry. For instance, the customers have very little influence in the petroleum industry in Canada. The major oil companies set the price of gasoline and customers buy it. However, customers have a lot of say in the price of fast food as they can easily switch to other substitutes or make food themselves if fast food prices get too high. Factors that affect customer bargaining power include:

            • Whether or not they buy in large volumes.
            • Whether or not there is a concentration of buyers in a local area.
            • Whether or not the product/service can be easily substituted for something else.
            • Whether or not customers have tolerance for price changes.
            • Whether or not customers can produce the product or perform the service themselves.
            • Whether or not the customer knows the cost of production.

            Bargaining Power of Suppliers

          Suppliers are other businesses that offer inputs for your organization. These inputs could be materials, services, processed goods, etc. Factors that affect suppliers' bargaining power include:

            • Whether or not there are few suppliers that can control a lot of the competition based on who they sell to and for how much money.
            • Whether or not the supplies are easily substitutable.
            • Whether or not the supplier can vertically integrate and do the work of your business itself.
            • Whether or not the supplier makes proper use of economies of scale.

          Threat of Substitutes

          Substitutes are products or services that the customer could purchase as a replacement for your company's product/service. If your product/service is easily substituted for something else, it is likely that you are in a more competitive environment. An example of substitution can be seen when the price of butter increases quickly. Customers will substitute butter for cheaper vegetable oil or margarine. Thus, butter is in a competitive industry because the thread of substitutes is quite high. Factors that influence the threat of substitutes include:

            • Whether or not the customers have strong brand loyalty.
            • Whether or not it costs a lot to change over to the substitute.
            • Whether or not there is a substantial price difference for substitutes.
            • Whether or not consumer tastes change quickly or not (are the customers susceptible to trends, fads or novelty?)

          Existing Rivalry Between Competitors

          This force measures how competitive the industry is with the current businesses in it. When competition is high, there is a lot of pressure for companies to produce profits. This holds true for all businesses in the industry. Factors that influence competitive rivalry include:

            • Whether or not all the competitors are the same size.
            • Whether or not companies can create growth without stealing it from competitors.
            • Whether or not there are a lot of differences between the products produced or services offered.
            • Whether or not the competition are using similar strategies.

          Please read about Porter's Five Competitive Forces model at the following webpage: http://www.themanager.org/2015/11/porters-five-forces/. Most of the information on this page is a summary of this article. For PDF version, click here.

           Example of Porter's Theory

          Please click here to open if it does not load.

            Success Criteria

          Before moving on to the next section, make sure you can do the following:

          I can explain and use Porter's Five Forces Model.

          I can make suggestions as to how a company can improve its strategic plan using elements of Porter's Model.

            

          What is a BCG-matrix and how would you use one?

          Page 4-4D: BCG Matrix

          Learning Goals

            • Analyse organizational strategic plans using a variety of tools.

             

          BCG Matrix

          The BCG-matrix, (Boston matrix, Boston Consulting Group analysis, portfolio diagram) is a chart that was created by Bruce D. Henderson for the Boston Consulting Group in 1970 to help corporations analyze their business units.

          The matrix helps the company to allocate resources and is used as an analytical tool specifically with brand marketing, product management, strategic management, and portfolio analysis.

          The BCG matrix method is based on the product life cycle theory that can be used to determine what priorities should be given in the product portfolio of a business unit. To ensure long-term value creation, a company should have a portfolio of products that contains both high-growth products in need of cash inputs and low-growth products that generate a lot of cash.

          How to Use the BCG Matrix

          The matrix has two dimensions: market share and market growth. The basic idea behind it is that the bigger the market share a product has, or the faster the product's market grows, the better it is for the company.

            • Cash Cow - a business unit that has a large market share in a mature, slow growing industry. Cash cows require little investment and generate cash that can be used to invest in other business units.
            • Star - a business unit that has a large market share in a fast growing industry. Stars may generate cash, but because the market is growing rapidly they require investment to maintain their lead. If successful, a star will become a cash cow when its industry matures.
            • Question Mark (or Problem Child) - a business unit that has a small market share in a high growth market. These business units require resources to grow market share, but whether they will succeed and become stars is unknown.
            • Dog - a business unit that has a small market share in a mature industry. A dog may not require substantial cash, but it ties up capital that could better be deployed elsewhere. Unless a dog has some other strategic purpose, it should be liquidated if there is little prospect for it to gain market share.

           

           Limitations

            • High market share is not the only success factor.
            • Market growth is not the only indicator for attractiveness of a market.
            • Sometimes Dogs can earn even more profit than Cash Cows.

           Example

          The BCG Matrix method can help understand a frequently made strategic mistake: having a one-size-fits-all-approach to strategy, such as a generic growth target (9 percent per year) or a generic return on capital of say 5.5% for an entire corporation. In such a scenario:

          A. Cash Cows Business Units will beat their profit target easily; their management have an easy job and are often praised anyhow. Even worse, they are often allowed to reinvest substantial cash amounts in their businesses which are mature and not growing anymore.

          B. Dogs Business Units fight an impossible battle and, even worse, investments are made now and then in hopeless attempts to 'turn the business around'.

          C. As a result (all) Question Marks and Stars Business Units get mediocre size investment funds. In this way they are unable to ever become cash cows. These inadequate invested sums of money are a waste. Either these SBUs should receive enough investment funds to enable them to achieve a real market dominance and become a cash cow (or star), or otherwise companies are advised to disinvest and try to get whatever possible cash out of the question marks that were not selected. 

          Application - Coca-Cola

          Below is a diagram showing the BCG Matrix for Coca-Cola.  Research Coca-Cola and determine whether you agree or disagree with the matrix below.  In what way do you differ?  With what, specifically, do you agree?

           

          Extension 

          Compare your comments and research of the BCG Coca Cola matrix (above) with a partner.  In what areas did you agree?  In what areas do you disagree?

          Success Criteria

          Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

          I can explain what a BCG Matrix is and how it is used to develop a strategic plan.

          I can apply my understanding of a BCG Matrix to a real business.

          I can evaluate a company's BCG Matrix and make recommendations of change.

           

          Theories of Corporate Culture

          A business' corporate culture can greatly impact an organization's strategic plans. In this next section, we will examine the relationship between corporate culture and strategic planning.

          Page 4-4E: Theories of Corporate Culture

          Learning Goals

          Analyse the two levels of corporate culture and describe the relationship between corporate culture and strategic planning.

             

          Theories of Corporate Culture

          Corporate culture describes observable traits and core (invisible) traits of that make up a corporation's core identity.  Corporate culture plays a large role in how management sets strategic plans. More specifically, culture is also enormously important in the creation of corporate strategy, business unit strategy, and functional strategic plans. The following presentation describes four major theories that address corporate culture:

           

           

          Examples

          Various company's culture and values differ greatly.  However, many companies do share similar core values. Compare and contrast ideas surrounding the core values of Apple and LinkedIn that are shared in the short videos below. 

          Success Criteria

          Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

          I can explain corporate culture and provide connections between corporate culture and how that would influence a company's strategic planning.

           

          Assignment 4-4F: Planning Frameworks Graphic Organizer [GTA]
          4-4F: Planning Frameworks Graphic Organizer

          Learning Strands & Expectations

          • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 
          • Analyse the relationship between strategic planning and the success of an organization. (D3) 

           

            This formative assignment will be assessed by your Grading Teacher in order to provide you with descriptive feedback essential to a future assignment.

             Assignment Overview

            Task   
            Step 1:  Review the Management Tools of Lesson 4-4 
            • Review lessons 4-4A (SWOT Analysis), 4-4B (PEST Analysis), 4-4C (Porters Five Competitive Forces), and 4-4D (BCG Matrix).  Make note about any of the key ideas or information that needs to be included when using each planning framework.  
             
            Step 2:  Compare and Contrast the Frameworks 
            • Download the 4-4: Planning Frameworks Graphic Organizer. 
            • Compare and contrast the different planning frameworks. Record your information in the provided graphic organizer. For each framework: 
              • Describe the framework in 2-3 sentences.  
              • List 3 advantages of the framework. Explain how they are advantages.  
              • List 2 disadvantages of the framework. Explain how they are disadvantages.  
              • Identify and explain 2 real-world business scenarios where this framework would be the most appropriate to apply. 
            • Submit your complete graphic organizer as a pdf.

             

            Submission Requirements  

            • Upload your graphic organizer as a PDF file.  

             Success Criteria

            You will be assessed on the success criteria listed below:

            1. I can explain how to use and apply management tools and planning frameworks to help with strategic planning. (D3) 

              • I can describe each planning framework. 
              • I can list and explain at least 3 advantages of each framework. 
              • I can list and explain at least 2 disadvantages of each framework. 
              • I can identify and explain at least 2 different real-world scenarios for each planning framework and where it would be appropriately applicable. 
            2. I can use business-related terminology to explain my ideas. (A2.1; A2.4)    
            3. I can present my ideas in an organized and logical sequence (A2.1; A2.4) 
             

              How to Submit

              • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
              • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.
              • Submit your completed assignment using the "Add Submission" button located at the bottom of this page.
            Evaluation

            After studying the theory from 4-2, 4-3 and 4-4, you will be conducting your own SWOT analysis on Kanata Leisure Center and make suggestions for a plan of action.

            Assignment *4-4G: SWOT Analysis 4%

             
            *4-4G: SWOT Analysis [4%]

            This activity will be counted in your final grade

            Overall Expectations & Learning Goals

            • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 
            • Analyse the importance of planning to the success of an organization within the workplace. (D1) 
            • Demonstrate an understanding of appropriate planning tools and techniques in a variety of situations. (D2) 
            • Analyse the relationship between strategic planning and the success of an organization. (D3) 
            •  

             Assignment Overview

            In this assignment, you will examine a case and perform a SWOT analysis in order to provide recommendations to the business owner. You will need to be familiar with 4-4, specifically the SWOT Analysis, while also having a strong overall understanding of planning and types of plans through concepts from 4-1, 4-2, and 4-3. No outside research is required. 

            Task  
             
            Step 1:  Read the Case 
            • Read the case study.  
            • Take notes on the key facts as you read.  
             

            Case Study 

            Recently, a clothing boutique based out of Milan, Italy started exploring the possibility of expanding its business by opening its first international location (and second location) in Toronto, Canada.  While the boutique is quite confident their new venture will be fruitful due to their previous success, they have asked you – a prestigious planning specialist – to audit their business and assess the feasibility of this potential business decision. 
             
            After conducting your own research and consulting with the owner of the boutique, you have learned the following: 
             
            1. According to a local survey conducted last year, the boutique ranked 19 out of 125 in gross sales and 23 out of 125 in net sales among competing clothing retailers. 
            2. In their ten years of operations, the owner of the boutique has hired more than ten different individuals for the floor manager position and has seen an above average turnover rate among sales employees. 
            3. The proposed location in Toronto is situated in an affluent neighbourhood known for its multiethnic community, its love of art, and its appreciation for culture. 
            4. A personal contact of the owner, who lives in Toronto, works in the field of supply chain logistics.  
            5. According to market research, 59% of Canadian consumers prefer to buy their clothing items through online shopping and online distributors. 
            6. A successful social media content creator, known for their clothing hauls and style advice, is based out of Toronto. 
            7. Over the years, customer reviews have typically praised the generous return policies of the boutique. 
            8. Two blocks away from the proposed location, construction is ongoing to develop a new commercial plaza, which is set to be completed in six months. 
            9. The inventory management system used by the boutique has not been updated in three years and two new versions of the software have since been released in that time frame. 
            10. A popular metro station is within a two-minute walking distance of the proposed location. 
            11. Four years ago, the boutique received recognition for their efforts to reduce carbon emissions from an Italian environmental organization.  
            12. According to a study, post-secondary institutions in Toronto have seen increased enrolments in disciplines such as fashion design, fashion commerce, and retail management. 
             
            Step 2:  Complete a SWOT Analysis 
             
            • Download the 4-4G: SWOT Analysis Graphic Organizer.  
            • Using the information from the case, perform a SWOT analysis for the clothing company.  
            • Assess each fact through the SWOT lens. Identify whether each fact represents a strength, weakness, opportunity, or threat.  Record your assessment in the organizer. 
            • Justify and explain your assessment for each fact using specific evidence from the case in 1-2 sentences.   
            • Summarize the results of your SWOT Analysis by adding up and recording the number of strengths, weakness, opportunities, and threats.  
             
            Step 3: Analyse the Results 
             
            • Analyse your results. Using the results of your SWOT analysis, determine which of the following options makes the most sense for the owner of the clothing boutique:  
              • Option A:  Continue with the expansion plan 
              • Option B:  Re-consider components of the expansion plan 
              • Option C:  Abandon the expansion plan 
            • Select the best option and write a 150-250 word report that clearly identifies your recommendation and explains why this is the best recommendation. Use 4 relevant and specific facts from the case to support and explain your choice. 
             
            Step 4: Planning for Challenges 
            Securing all of the required permits to open a business and work in new country can sometimes take time. Suppose the owner of the boutique has an issue with securing their Canadian work permit, exactly one month before the boutique is set to open in Toronto.  At best, the permit will be received in one week, but at worst, the permit may take more than two months to be received.   
            • Identify what type of planning strategy the boutique owner should use to ensure an eventual successful launch of the new boutique if they do not receive their work permit in time.  
            • Explain how this identified strategy will help them launch the boutique successfully. Suggest 2 possible outcomes of the identified planning strategy that would be beneficial to the boutique owner. 
             
            Step 5:  Write your Report 
            • Organize your answers to Step 3 and Step 4 into a business report that answers the questions above in a logical manner. Use headings to organize your ideas.   
            • Proofread and edit your report for spelling, grammar, and overall clarity.  
            • Format your report so that it looks professional and is easy to read.  
            • Submit your report and the completed graphic organizer in a single document as a pdf.  
             
            Submission Requirements  
            • Upload the graphic organizer and report in a single pdf file.
             
             
             
             
             
             
             

             Success Criteria

            You will be assessed on the success criteria listed below:

            1. I can perform a SWOT analysis to analyse a scenario or case.  
            2. I can identify the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats of a specific scenario. (D1.2; D1.3; D3.3) 
            3. I can justify and explain my assessments in the SWOT framework by using evidence from the case. (D3.3) 
            4. I can identify and justify a recommendation for the business based on the results of my SWOT analysis and my knowledge of course concepts. (D3.3) 
            5. I can present my ideas in an organized and logical sequence. (A2.1; A2.4) 
            6. I can use business-related terminology to explain my ideas. (A2.1; A2.4)    
            7. I can identify and explain a planning strategy and the outcomes that can address planning challenges. (D1.2; D2.1; D2.2) 

              How to Submit

              • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
              • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.
              • Submit your completed assignment using the "Add Submission" button located at the bottom of this page.

            BCG Matrix Cash Cow PEST Analysis Question Mark Star SWOT Analysis
            Learning Log: 4-4 (Target: 4 hours) — Questionnaire
            5
            4-5: Planning for Change (2 hours)
            Quizlet 4-5: Vocabulary Quizlet

             

             

            Lesson Vocabulary

            Quizlets

            Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

            For this lesson, focus on the following word:

              • Chunking 
            Click on 4-5: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
            ▼
            Businesses are dynamic and vulnerable to constant change. Managers must recognize that some employees fear change and it is their responsibility to facilitate the acceptance of change. In this lesson, we will discuss factors that create organizational change, attitudes that generate change, and strategies a leader can use to respond to internal and external pressures of change.
            Lesson Overview — Key Idea

            The central goal of this lesson is to analyze change in organizations, the elements that bring change, people's attitudes to change, and the strategies used by managers to bring change and its acceptance.

            Learning Goals & Success Criteria
            1. Analyse the elements that bring about change in an organization
            2. Communicate major changes that are occurring in today's businesses world
              • I can analyze the elements that bring about change in an organization
              • I can communicate major changes that are occurring in today's businesses and discuss what caused the change
            3. Analyse reasons for various attitudes towards change
              • I can analyze reasons for various attitudes towards change
            4. Evaluate different strategies used by managers to bring about acceptance of planned change
              • I can evaluate different strategies used by managers to bring about acceptance of planned change
              • I can analyze employees' reactions to the change and how managers can facilitate it
            Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
            • Critically think about change
            • Evaluate managers' strategies for facilitating change
            Factors that Create Organizational Change

            What causes organizational change? There are many factors and in this next section, we will analyze them.

            Page 4-5A: Factors that Create Organizational Change

            Learning Goals

              • Analyse the elements that bring about change in an organization.
              • Communicate major changes that are occurring in today's business world and discuss what you think causes it.

               

            Factors that Create Organizational Change

            There are a number of elements that bring about change in an organization. We will study three of them: developments in information technology; the implementation of growth plans; and the evolution of organizational culture.

            Change in Organizations

            Take a look at examples of how change is created in organizations.

            Video Script

            Click here to view a copy of the video script.

            There are many elements that can bring about change in a business and business leaders need to be aware of these catalysts of change. The first factor that can create change is a new technological development. 

            One of the first major technological developments after the industrial revolution was the sewing machine. The invention of the sewing machine by Elias Howe in 1846 made it possible to mass manufacture clothing. Before the sewing machine, clothes were hand sewn and put out into the market. With the introduction of the sewing machine came the introduction of the sweat shop.

            The Willimantic Linen Company was one of the first companies to benefit from this new technology, eventually building their very own new granite mill for the sole purpose of manufacturing sewing machine thread.

            Today, technological developments like Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Youtube have changed the ways that businesses advertise. Most advertising is now done online with Google heading a cost per click advertising initiative. Businesses will pay for ads based on each time a user clicks on the ad. The word insurance companies pay the highest CPC rate at over $50 every time a Google user clicks their ad. 

            The second catalyst of change occurs when a company implements a growth plan. Companies can grow in many ways. They can expand their reach by building new stores, expand their product line by introducing new products, expand their market by branding and advertising to new demographics, vertically integrate their products and services or directly invest in other countries.

            A company that implemented a growth plan exceedingly well is Shopify from Ottwaw, Ontario. The company started out selling snowboards, but soon came to realize that their e-commerce site was one of the best. They grew their business by offering their e-commerce model to other sites. Today, Shopify is one of the best e-commerce solutions ranking 3rd on Deloitte’s technology fast 50 list in 2014 with a revenue growth of over 16,000%.

            Another way to enact change in a business is to further evolve the organizational culture within the organization. This type of change will require business leaders to shift their way of thinking within the business. Often times, a managerial theory or strategy needs to be changed in order to effectively improve organizational culture.

            3M is a company that grew their organizational culture and, in doing so, grew their business. 3M stands for Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company and when it first started operations, its core competency was mining corundum. But the company was unsuccessful in mining enough corundum to stay afloat. So the founding members, turned to other materials and products to help increase sales and make money. They changed their culture from a mining company to a culture of invention. The founders supported innovation and employees were encouraged to work on their own projects and research. Today, 3M has over 60,000 products that we use on a daily basis. From masking tape, to sticky notes, to reflective tape, to aircraft protection plates, 3M manufactures materials for every walk of life.

             

            Success Criteria

            Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

            I can outline and explain the elements that bring about change in an organization.

            I can communicate major changes that are occurring in today's business world and intelligently discuss the three primary drivers of change.

             

            Attitudes Towards Change

            In general, some people fear change, while others embrace it. This also applies to the world of business and the workplace. It is important that business leaders work effectively with these different attitudes and steer the company towards its strategic objectives.

            Page 4-5B: Attitudes Towards Change

            Learning Goals

              • Analyse reasons for various attitudes towards change.

               

            Attitudes Towards Change

            This learning activity will focus on the positive and negative attitudes towards change. In an organization, it is important for managers to understand why people are hesitant to accept change and why others embrace it.  In understanding these concepts, managers and leaders can better implement organizational changes that are needed to achieve the organizations strategic goals.  

            Why Do Individuals Fear Change?

            Individuals will fear change for a number of reasons:

              1. Fear of the Unknown: If employees are not properly informed of expected outcomes of a potential change, then they are more likely to fear the change and not accept it simply because of the fear of the unknown.  Generally, people will only move forward (change) if the risks of standing still outweigh the risks of moving forward. Therefore, if employees are comfortable with the status quo and uninformed about the benefits of change, they will prefer to stay put.
              2. Misunderstanding the Effects of the Change: If employees do not understand why the change is needed or do not see how the change will help the employees and/or the company, then they will be more likely to reject changes. Employees will not want to change if they do not fully understand how the change will help. Furthermore, if employees feel that the change is just a fad (or change for the sake of change) then they will be more likely to reject proposed changes.  
              3. Distrust: If employees have been harmed in the past by an organizational change, then moving forward they may fear new changes based on their past experience.
              4. Employee Input: If employees were never consulted about the change, they may reject the change because they were not a part of the consultation process. They may feel that because of a flawed process and lack of consultation, change will result in a loss of power or control.  Worse, they may feel that the change is being forced upon them and are therefore less likely to support it without having any input.
              5. Change in Routine: Employees do not like surprises. Often times with organizational change, employees are required to do things differently or take on more work. This can cause a change in employees' routines and out of their comfort zone. Often times the negative association with a changing routine is enough to conjure up fear and result in a lack of support.

            Mnemonic Device: F.I.R.E.D. (Fear, Input, Routine, Effects, Distrust)

             Why Do Individuals Embrace Change?

            Individuals may also embrace change due to a number of reasons:

              1. The Change is Rational: When employees see that there is a logical need for change (e.g., new technology because old technology is slow or obsolete), then there is a greater chance that the change will be embraced.
              2. Growth and Opportunities: Employees will embrace change if they feel that the company will grow or they will experience personal growth and/or opportunities. If the change encourages employees to be better and grow as workers, then many employees will embrace the change.
              3. Progress and Improvement: If the goal of the change is properly communicated to the employees and it promotes progress and improvement, then employees are more likely to embrace the change. Employees generally like to work in successful environments and are willing to accept change if the end goal is success.
              4. Employee Input: When employees have been previously informed about the change and they have had adequate input into the process, they will likely be more accepting of the change. It is important to note that leaders must show that employee input is valuable and that the employee input was not discarded or not considered.
              5. Ease of Stress or Workload: When change eases employee stress or the volume of work required (helps employees become more efficient), then workers will be more accepting of the change.

            Mnemonic Device: G.R.I.P.E. (Growth, Rational, Input, Progress, Ease)

              Success Criteria

            Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

            I can analyse reasons for various attitudes towards change.

             

            Leadership Strategies to Facilitate Acceptance of Organizational Change

            One of the responsibilities of a leader is to facilitate the acceptance of organizational change. Executives and managers must prepare their teams for change and encourage them to accept and embrace it.

            Page 4-5C: Leadership Strategies to Facilitate Acceptance of Organizational Change

            Learning Goals

              • Evaluate different strategies used by managers to bring about acceptance of planned change.

               

            Leadership Strategies to Facilitate Acceptance of Organizational Change

            Leaders and managers use many different strategies to help employees embrace and accept organizational change. By implementing strategies that mitigate employee resistance to change (F.I.R.E.D) and promote employee acceptance of change (G.R.I.P.E), business leaders try to make the change process as seamless as possible.

            Education

            Providing information and learning around the organizational change will help to mitigate some of the barriers that employers face when implementing change. When employees are educated about the change, there are fewer "unknowns" and the fear/anxiety that the employees feel will decrease.  

             

            Coaching with Simulation

            Some companies hire coaches to help employees transition through organizational change. In a simulation, employees are put into a controlled environment that mimics the organizational change. Coaches provide help and motivation to help employees adapt to the new environment. Once the employees are comfortable performing in the simulation, the change can be implemented and the employees will feel more comfortable in the new environment.

            Shared Power

            Leaders can involve employees in the change process and essentially share some of the power associated with the change. When employees feel empowered, they are more likely to embrace the change (employee input is honoured). If workers feel that they are a part of the change process, then they begin to own the change and, most importantly, want the change to succeed. Power can be shared with employees in many different stages of the change process from the planning stage right through to the implementation and evaluation stages.

            Negotiation

            Negotiating with employees means bargaining with them and coming to a compromise that is beneficial for both parties. When management negotiates with employees about the different aspects of a new organizational change (e.g., planning, implementation, training, evaluation, etc.) then the employees are once again involved in the process. The negotiation process gives the workers a sense that they were involved in creating parts of the change and they may take ownership of the transformation.

            Chunking

            This process refers to implementing the change in small little stages spread out over time. This gives the employees the chance to adapt to the change slowly and in little pieces - not all at once. Employees who are given changes in small doses will likely be less fearful of the unknown as the risks that they need to take at each stage of the change are less drastic.


               

            Success Criteria

            Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

            I can evaluate different strategies used by managers to bring about acceptance of planned change.

             

            Current Change in Businesses

            This forum is designed to help you share your thoughts and opinions about organizational change based on research that you will undertake.

            Assignment 4-5D: Current Change in Business [CTA]

            4-5D: Current Change in Business [CTA]

            This is a CTA Activity.   

             Learning Goals

              • Evaluate different strategies used by managers to bring about acceptance of planned change

             Assignment Overview

             

            Step 1: Research your article 
            • Individually, in partners, or as a class, locate a recent article that details an organization currently undergoing a major change. 
             
            Step 2:  Complete the Organizer 
            • Using the article you have found, complete the following organizer. 

            Name of Business 

             

            Brief Summary 

            In point-form notes or short sentences, summarize the key events and facts of the article 

             

            The Major Change 

            Outline the major change and the reasons behind it 

             

            The Strategy 

            Identify and describe the strategy you believe is most appropriate to help employees accept the ongoing change.  Justify your choice 

             

            References 

            List your source using APA format. 

             
             
            Exemplar: 

            Name of Business 

            Spotify 

            Brief Summary 

            In point-form notes or short sentences, summarize the key events and facts of the article 

            Spotify announced they would be centralizing their engineering and product work to allow CEO, Daniel Ek, to return to areas of the business he was more familiar and comfortable working.  A long-time executive, Dawn Ostroff, would be departing the organization because of these changes.  Moreover, the company would be downsizing to become more cost-efficient.  Terms of severance were defined.   

            The Major Change 

            Outline the major change and the reasons behind it 

            I believe the main reason for the changes were to allow the CEO to return to familiar work, while also becoming more efficient as a company in the long run.  To do so, costs needed to be cut and jobs were sacrificed to facilitate this change. 

            The Strategy 

            Outline the strategy you believe is most appropriate to help employees accept the ongoing change.  Justify your choice 

            I believe the best strategy to implement would be Education.  According to 4-5, Education is described as providing information and learning around organizational change to mitigate barriers employers face when implementing change.  Such an approach helps to clear “unknowns” and calm any fears or anxiety.  In this case, it would be helpful for employees to understand why this is going on beyond the announcement given to them.  If they are demonstrated specific reasons as to why these changes are necessary, they will be better prepared and equipped in future cases where organizational change may come.  In my opinion, good employers owe it to their employees to be transparent and to keep them informed of the business operations. 

            References 

            List your source using APA format. 

            Naomi. (2023, January 23). An Update on January 2023 Organizational Changes — Spotify. Spotify. https://newsroom.spotify.com/2023-01-23/an-update-on-january-2023-organizational-changes/ 
             

             Success Criteria

            You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

             I can communicate major changes that are occurring in today's businesses and explain the reasons for the change(s);
            I can analyze employees reactions to change in a researched article and offer a strategy that managers/executives could use to foster acceptance of the change..

            Quizlet 4-6: Vocabulary Quizlet

             

             

            Lesson Vocabulary

            Quizlets

            For this lesson, focus on the following words:

              • Acceptable Situation
              • Control
