              • Increased Autonomy
              • Input Standards
              • Opportunity Situation
              • Output Standards
              • Performance Based Compensation
              • Problem Situation
              • Progressive Discipline
            Click on 4-6: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
            ▼
            Being able to effectively control employees and resources is an integral role of leadership. Leaders need to be aware of both internal and external control measures. A good leader will encourage people with appropriate feedback that bolsters a sense of confidence. This confidence feeds self-motivation. Leaders also need to be able to relate to their employees and communicate proper expectations and model upstanding behaviours.
            Lesson Overview — Key Idea

            The key idea of the lesson is to understand what specific processes and strategies leaders and managers can use in their organizations.

            Learning Goals & Success Criteria
            1. Describe the steps one can take to gain control and increase productivity
              • I understand the steps in the Standards Control process and how it can be used to improve employee performance
            2. Describe the impact of internal and external control measures on a business
              • I can describe the impact of internal and external control measures on employee performance
            3. Describe progressive discipline and its impact on employees
            4. Apply the theory of progressive discipline to a workplace scenario
              • I can describe progressive discipline and its impact on employees
              • I can apply the theory of progressive discipline to a workplace scenario
            5. Explain the types of control systems used by organizations
            6. Demonstrate an understanding of the importance of control measures and systems
              • I can explain the three types of control systems: Feedforward, Concurrent, Feedback
              • I can demonstrate an understanding of the importance of control measures and systems
            7. Describe various ways that managers can exert "control" in the workplace
              • I can set goals using the SMART method
              • I can critically evaluate the mission and objectives and think through key points for SWOT
              • I can produce a well-organized report using my own words
              • I have applied my learning from the course, using specific theories or examples
            Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
            • Critically think about control in organizations
            • Evaluate managers' strategies for control in their organizations
            Steps in the Control Process

            Being able to control employees is a valuable skill for business leaders. There are many steps to effectively controlling employees. Let's start by examining the steps in what is called the "control process".

            Page 4-6A: Steps in the Control Process

            Learning Goals

              • Describe the steps one can take to gain control and thus increase productivity and job satisfaction.

               

            The Importance of Control

            In order for a business leader to be effective, he/she must have control over themselves and their work.  The video below discusses how having control can also overcome stress and feelings of helplessness.  

              

            Steps in the Standards Control Process

            There are four steps that one can take to ensure that they have control of the workplace.  All are equally important to ensuring that one has effective control of employees, resources, and work tasks.

            Set Goals and Standards

            Leaders need to set goals (preferably goals that follow the SMART guideline) and effectively communicate these goals to employees. Employees should be given the appropriate training, tools and information to meet their goals. An example of a goal for a sales employee is to sell $40,000 of product by March 31st. Furthermore, managers and leaders need to set standards for employees. Standards are levels of achievement that the employees are expected to meet. There are two types of standards:

              1. Output standards: communicates the standard in terms of results based on quantity, quality, cost, time, etc.
              2. Input standards: communicates the standard in terms of the work that goes into the performance task based on quantity, quality, cost, time, etc. and does not consider the output.

            An example of an output standard for electricians is that all of their work must at the very least be “up to code”. An example of an input standard is that all electricians work at least 20 hours per week on a specific job.

               

             Measure Results (Actual Performance)

            Managers/Leaders need to gather both quantitative data and qualitative data. Quantitative data involves gathering objective numbers that judge performance. These numbers can be useful for statistical analysis that paints a black and white picture. Qualitative data on the other hand involves gathering subjective information that uses human feedback based on the five senses. This type of data may include keeping information about an employee's appearance, how they relate to others, workplace performance reviews, colleague feedback, etc.

               

             Compare Results with Expected Standards

            Comparing quantitative data is quite easy in this step. When we compare our actual performance to our expected results one of three situations can occur.

              1. Problem Situation: performance below expected levels
              2. Acceptable Situation: performance matches expected levels
              3. Opportunity Situation: performance exceeds expected levels

            Comparing qualitative data is a little more difficult. If we collected data from performance reviews and one assessment states that the employee is always self motivated and reliable and another assessment says the employee lacks self regulation, then the manager will have to try to determine what is actually occurring.

               

             Take Necessary Action

            Once the leader/manager compares results, he/she can take the next step in the control process. Two situations can arise from the results comparison:

              1. Problem Situation: the leader should take corrective measures, implement contingency plans, retrain employees, or re-evaluate goals and standards.
              2. Opportunity Situation: leader should determine and learn about what can be done in the future to achieve this level consistently.

            Regardless of which situation arises, the next step will lead us right back to step one. If in a problem situation, we restate or create new goals and standards and begin to measure employee performance again. If in an opportunity situation, we create new goals and try to attain them going forward.

             

            Success Criteria

            Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

            I understand the steps in the Standards Control process and how it can be used to improve employee performance.  

             

            Control Measures

            There are many components that affect a leader's ability to be in control. These control measures will have an impact on a business.

            Page 4-6B: Control Measures

            Learning Goals

              • Describe the impact of internal and external control measures on a business.

               

            Control Measures

            One aspect of controlling requires identifying deficiencies in employee performance and taking the corrective measures to ensure progress toward the specified goals and standards. Another aspect of controlling involves identifying performance that exceeds the expected goals (proficiencies) and standards and replicating/improving the process in the future. In order to help identify deficiencies/proficiencies and take the best action, managers rely on internal and external control measures.  

            Internal Control Measures

            When individuals and groups can exercise their own self-discipline in fulfilling the job expectations. Internal controls are self-administered by employees for employees and require a great amount of trust by the leader. Internal controls require subordinates to participate in setting goals and standards. Some common aspects of internal control include:

              1. Self-Discipline: employees are encouraged to reflect on their performance and regulate themselves accordingly to meet the goals and standards that they help set. For example, this may mean staying late and not being compensated for work that the employee has committed to completing by a certain date.
              2. Personal Goal Setting: employees are encouraged to set personal job goals as well. This helps them to stay organized and focused on their job/project. When they find that they are not working toward both company and personal goals, they can take corrective action to perform better.
              3. Colleague Assessment: employees can increase the quality of work by having peers assess their performance before management does. This could include having peers evaluate/assess presentations or reports before they are submitted to management. 

             

            External Control Measures

            When employees are corrected and regulated by management and leaders, they are being controlled by the external environment. This is a more autocratic style of management control that often tries to condition employees using operant conditioning (adding/removing stimuli based on performance). Some common aspects of external control include:

              1. Performance Based Compensation: giving bonuses for exceptional work (positive reinforcement) and decreasing pay for substandard work (negative punishment) are ways that some leaders try to extract better performance from workers. This strategy can work when employees are motivated by money and the work is not that conducive to personal growth.
              2. Progressive Discipline: using increasing punishments to correct negative behaviour in employees is a form of external control that some leaders will enact to correct bad behaviour (negative punishment). You will read more about progressive discipline in the next learning activity.
              3. Increased Autonomy: as an employee’s performance increases, managers may begin to give them more autonomy. For example, managers may decrease (take away) the amount of check-in meetings that the employee has with the manager, allowing the employee more independence (negative reinforcement).  

            Success Criteria

            Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

            I can describe the impact of internal and external control measures on employee performance.

             

            In the previous activity we introduced the concept of external control measure of progressive discipline. We will further this by investigating how progressive discipline can be used in the workplace.

            Page 4-6C: Control Measure Spotlight: Progressive Discipline

              

            Learning Goals

              • Describe progressive discipline and its impact on employees.
              • Apply the theory of progressive discipline to a workplace scenario.

               

            Progressive Discipline

            Progressive discipline is a system of control that uses increasing levels of management response to try to correct negative behaviour in employees. While the goal is to try to be less punitive and punishing, the end result is a form of positive punishment (in terms of operant conditioning). This form of discipline has been gaining popularity with business leaders as it encourages employees to increase performance. This system is indicative of the current move from Theory X to Theory Y techniques.

               

            How Does Progressive Discipline Work?

            Progressive discipline dictates that, rather than terminating employees when they do not meet goals and standards, leaders should implement a system of progressive responses that can help curb the negative behaviour. 

            Example: assume your employee continually shows up late for work. A leader may try some form of progressive discipline:

              1. A Verbal Warning: the manager may sit down with the employee to discuss the tardy behaviour and review the standards with the employee.
              2. A Written Warning: the manager will then formally write a notice to the employee reaffirming the previous conversation and include this notice in the employee’s file. The manager may give further consequences and/or future consequences if the behaviour persists.
              3. Suspension or Demotion: the manager may then demote the employee or suspend him/her for a time being so that the behaviour can improve. This may also result in a decrease in pay for the employee.
              4. Termination/Firing: if all else fails and the behaviour does not improve, the manager may have to terminate the employee (release him/her from employment).

              

              Employee Rights

            This section has been taken from the government of Newfoundland and Labrador's website: http://www.exec.gov.nl.ca/exec/hrs/working_with_us/discipline.html. For PDF version, click here.

            In each of the steps of progressive discipline, an employee should be informed of the following:

              • A description of the incident(s), including evidence or the results of any investigation and the date of the incident(s);
              • An explanation of why the behaviour is problematic;
              • Any previous discipline for the same or related conduct;
              • The expectations for performance and conduct;
              • Any supports available to assist the employee to correct the behaviour; and
              • The consequences of failing to correct the undesired behaviour

             

            Application

            The introduction of progressive discipline has impacted and will continue to impact employees in Canadian corporations. Suppose you were an employee of one of those major corporations. Answer the following questions in a journal entry below:

            1) What are possible positive impacts (benefits) of implementing a progressive discipline policy? 

            2) What are possible negative impacts (drawbacks) of implementing a progressive discipline policy?

              

            Success Criteria

            Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

            I can describe progressive discipline and its impact on employees.

            I can apply the theory of progressive discipline to a workplace scenario.

              

             

            Control Systems

            Businesses use a variety of control systems. Effective control systems should provide employees with continuous feedback. We will learn about three types of control: feedforward, concurrent, and feedback.

            Page 4-6D: Control Systems

            Learning Goals

              • Explain the types of control systems used by organizations.
              • Demonstrate an understanding of the importance of control measures and systems by using the theory to explain a solution to a problem.

               

            Control Systems

            A control system is the overall process that managers use to control employee behaviour and performance. Managers will use different control measures within the system to try to achieve the best possible employee performance. Where the measures are the actions taken by leaders to help them control, the system is the overall theory of how the manager should engage in "control".

            Good control systems will provide employees with feedback at all stages of work. If a project is being implemented, then the control system should have room for feedback/assessment at all three stages: before, during and after the project is done.

            Feedforward Control

              • Employed before work begins.
              • States clear objectives and goals.
              • Establishes proper directions for employees.
              • Makes the necessary resources available.
              • Focuses on quality of inputs.
              • Tries to solve problems before they occur.

             

            Concurrent Control

              • Employed during the working process.
              • Monitors operations to ensure the directions are being followed properly.
              • Clarifies procedures that must be stopped, started, and continued.
              • Increases efficiency by stopping wasteful processes/actions during work instead of after the work is done.
              • Solves problems as they occur.

             

            Feedback Control

              • Employed after work is completed.
              • Focuses on the quality of the work that was done.
              • Evaluates positive and negative aspects of the work.
              • Provides useful information for improving future operations.
              • Solves problems after they occur.

              

            Success Criteria

            Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

            I can explain the three types of control systems used by organizations:  Feedforward, Concurrent, Feedback.

            I can demonstrate an understanding of the importance of control measures and systems.

             

            Evaluation

            This evaluation will be submitted for grading. Students will progress through the control process and implement the progressive discipline strategy. The student will develop a letter and script in dealing with a problem employee.

            Assignment *4-6E: Leadership Control 5%

             
            *4-6E: Leadership Control [5%]

            This activity will be counted in your final grade

            Learning Strands & Expectations

            • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 
            • Analyse how companies respond to internal and external pressures for change. (D4) 
            • Assess the importance of control in management. (D5) 

            •  

             Assignment Overview

            In this assignment, you will assess organizational behaviour and demonstrate your knowledge of organization control.   

              
            Task  
            Step 1:  Read the Case 
            • Read the case study. 
            • Make notes on the key facts and details of the case.  
             
            CASE STUDY 
            After a long interview process, the company of Dale Rose Manufacturing finally offered you the manager position.  As part of your new role, you are responsible for overseeing the day-to-day operations, ensuring that manufacturing quotas are met, and importantly, ensuring that workplace behaviour is orderly and professional.  You have learned that the previous manager left this position due to their struggles with maintaining control of the employees. 
            To better understand the situation with the employee behaviour, you have done some research. You have spoken to key people at the head office, current and former employees. In addition, you have reviewed video footage.  From this research, you have made the following observations:  
            • Employees often clock in and clock out of work at incorrect and inconsistent times. 
            • Employees use personal devices near dangerous machinery. 
            • Employees have been stealing lunches from the refrigerator, often because labels are not put on food or beverages. 
            • Employees often speak to each other in unprofessional language and do not communicate with each other in a professional manner.   
            • Communication with management seems to be mostly professional. 
            Dale Rose Manufacturing hopes to correct many of these issues and see tangible improvements in the workplace in the next 3 months.  As the manager, it is your job to create new goals and standards and find methods to better maintain control in the workplace.  
             
            Step 2:  Analyse the Case 
            1. Define and describe what a “SMART” goal is.   
            2. Develop 4 SMART Goals that could be used to address the behavioural issues listed in the case.  For each goal, briefly explain how it meets the SMART criteria.  
            3. For each goal, identify 1 strategy that you will implement in order to achieve the goal. Explain how the strategy will be effective in correcting undesired behaviour in the workplace. 
            4. Suppose your new strategies have been implemented, but an employee named Taylor choosing to ignore them.  Describe how you would apply the stages of progressive discipline to correct Taylor’s behaviour in a professional manner. Provide specific examples of the actions at each stage that you would take.  
            5. Identify and briefly explain 1 internal measure of control and 1 external measure of control that could be implemented to help address the employee's behaviour in this case. 
            6. As you implement your new strategies and goals, your employees may show resistance or uncertainty.  Identify and explain 2 strategies that you could use be used to facilitate change among you employees at Dale Rose Manufacturing. 
             
            Step 3:  Write Your Report 
            • Organize your answers into a report that answers the questions above. Use headings to organize your ideas.   
            • Proofread and format your report. 
             
            Submission Requirements  
            • Upload your written work as a Word or PDF file 
             
             
             

             Success Criteria

            You will be assessed on the success criteria listed below:

            1. I can define and describe a SMART goal. (D4.1) 
            2. I can develop SMART goals to address a specific challenge or issue. (D4.1) 
            3. I can propose strategies that will address undesired behaviour in the workplace. (D4.1) 
            4. I can identify and explain strategies to assist employees in adapting to organizational change. (D4.3) 
            5. I can identify and explain measures of control that can address undesired behaviour in the case (D5.3)  
            6. I can use business-related terminology effectively. (A2.1; A2.4)    
            7. I can present my ideas in an organized and logical sequence (A2.1; A2.4 
            8. I can apply the stages of progressive discipline to address continued undesired behaviour in the workplace (D5.2)  

              How to Submit

              • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
              • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.
              • Submit your completed assignment using the "Add Submission" button located at the bottom of this page.
            Vocabulary (Quizlet)

            Learning Log: 4-6 (Target: 3 hours) — Questionnaire
            R
            4-7: Unit 4 Highlights (Review)
            ▼
            These unit highlights will summarize the main concepts from the lessons of Unit 4. You can also use this page to check if you understand all of the concepts covered in Unit 4 and prepare for the unit test.
            4-1: The Importance of Planning
            • Vocabulary: Planning, Structures, Corrective Action, Strategizing, SMART Goal, Budgets, Corporate Strategies, Barriers, Paradigm Shifts, Objectives
            • Describe the four functions of management: Planning, Organizing, Leading, and Controlling
            • Explain the importance of planning in the management process
            • Identify and explain the five steps in the planning process: Definition, Position, Prediction, Option and Decision, and Implementation & Decision
            4-2: Planning Tools and Techniques
            • Vocabulary: Urban Planning, Targets, Group Think
            • Explain the planning strategies: Participatory Planning, Benchmarking, Scenario Planning, and Contingency Planning
            • Explain the use of short term and long term strategies and plans
            4-3: Strategic Planning
            • Vocabulary: Mission Statement, Vision, Broad Scope, Simplicity, Realistic, Inspirational, Short and Concise, Goal, Unique Position, Survival, Strategic Planning, Business Reach, Budgets, Competition, Products and Services, Tactical Plans, Concentration Strategy, Vertical Integration Strategy, Diversification Strategy, Turnaround Strategy, Divestment, Liquidation Strategy, Conglomeration
            • Describe the levels of strategic planning: Corporate Level, Business Unit Level, and Functional Level
            • Understand the types of strategic plans: Growth Strategies, Retrenchment Strategies, and Stability Strategies
            4-4: Analyzing Organization Strategic Plans
            • Vocabulary: Cash Cow, Star, Question Mark, Problem Child, Dog, Pragmatic, Normative, Stories, Rites and Rituals, Core Values, Heroes, Symbols, Tangible, Hierarchy, Assumptions, Clan, Adhocracy, Market, Culture, Fortress
            • Explain S.W.O.T analysis, PEST analysis, Porter's Five Forces Model, and BCG Matrix
            • Describe Schein's three levels of culture: Artifacts, Values, and Underlying Beliefs
            • Discuss nine types of corporate culture theory (Academy, Club, Tough Guy, Process, etc.)
            • Understand Quinn and Cameron's Four Organizational Cultures
            4-5: Planning for Change
            • Vocabulary: Organizational Change, Fear, Input, Routine, Effects, Distrust, Growth, Rational, Progress, Ease, Simulation, Shared Power, Negotiation, Chunking
            • Explain the factors that create organizational change
            • Understand attitudes towards change (why individuals fear or embrace change)
            • Explain leadership strategies to facilitate acceptance of change
            4-6: Control Processes and Systems
            • Vocabulary: Control Process, Output Standards, Input Standards, Problem Situation, Acceptable Situation, Opportunity Situation, Human Feedback, Internal Control Measures, External Control Measures, Self-Discipline, Personal Goal Setting, Performance Based Compensation, Progressive Discipline, Increased Autonomy, Negative Reinforcement, Positive Reinforcement, Verbal Warning, Written Warning, Suspension, Demotion, Termination, Control Systems, Feedforward Control, Concurrent Control, Feedback Control
            • Describe the steps in the control process: Set Standards, Measure Performance, Compare Performance, Take Corrective Action
            • Understand internal and external control measures
            • Explain the three types of control systems: Feedforward, Concurrent, and Feedback Control
            T
            4-9: Unit 4 Test
            ▼

            You've reached the end of the unit! Review the skills you've learned throughout the recent lessons to prepare for your test and best ensure your success.

            Test Overview: This test is designed to be completed in 60-90 minutes. The test will remain open for 2 hours.

            Remember to read the questions carefully and be sure to check your work before pressing submit. Do not leave any questions blank.

            All responses will be graded according to the KICA Achievement Chart.

            Quiz *UT-4: Unit 4 Test 7%
            R
            Reflection 3
            ▼
            Moving Forward — Congratulations! You have completed over half of this course. Keep up your hard work! Now it is time for us to reflect and set goals to continue improving. Remember to have a growth mindset. Everyone is a work in progress!
            Feedback Reflection 3 [Work Habits, Learning Experience, and Teacher Support]
            5
            Organizing
            6 Lessons + Unit Highlights + Unit Test • Sections 39-49
            ▼
            Welcome to Unit 5. In this Unit of study, students will learn about the various organizational structures that can be put in place in order to manage and direct employees effectively. We will assess the ways that organizational structures have adapted and changed. Finally, students will evaluate the role that human resources play in an organization by looking at the relationship between the organization, its leaders, managers, and workers.

            Overall Expectations / Learning Objectives:

            • Demonstrate an understanding of the various organizational structures used to manage the workforce effectively
            • Assess the ways in which organizational structures have changed to adapt to the changing nature of work
            • Evaluate the role of human resources within an organization
            1
            5-1: Organizational Structures (3 hours)
            ▼
            Organizational structure is a fundamentally important factor which dictates how the workplace operates. Often organizational structures are so firmly entrenched in the company that they are difficult to change or improve. However, many companies like Microsoft have successfully changed their organizational structure to allow for greater productivity and effectiveness. Leaders are always looking to create structures in their organization that allow for efficient sharing of ideas. This furthers their goal of innovating new products faster, which leads to market leadership and more profit.
            Lesson Overview — Key Idea

            Organizational structure is an important factor in managing a workplace effectively. Often times, organizational structures are so firmly entrenched in the company that they can be difficult to change or improve. Leaders need to understand the different types of organizational structures because implementing changes to these can improve employee effectiveness and overall company efficiencies.

            Learning Goals & Success Criteria
            1. Analyze traditional and current organizational structures
              • I can analyze traditional and current organizational structures
            2. Compare and contrast the organizational structures of current organizations
            3. Explain the advantages and disadvantages of organizational structures for current organizations
              • I can compare and contrast the organizational structures of current organizations
              • I can explain the advantages and disadvantages of organizational structures for current organizations
            4. Assess traditional and current organizational structures
            5. Explain how well designed organizational structures increase business success
              • I can detail and explain an organizational structure that works effectively
              • I can identify appropriate organizational structures for a variety of diverse businesses
              • I can connect to other organizational structures that would work well
            Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
            • Critically think about organizational structures
            • Evaluate the appropriate organizational structures for businesses
            Organizational Structures

            What is an organizational structure and what are the different types of structures? Why do some structures better fit certain types of businesses?

            Page 5-1A: Organizational Structures

            Learning Goals

              • Analyze a variety of organizational structures.

               

            Organizational Structures

            There are many types of organizational structures. Below are some common organizational structures which are also referred to as "Org Charts".

            Now let us focus on a few of these structures. The first three (functional, divisional, and matrix) we will review are traditional. The last three (team, network and boundaryless) are contemporary, having developed in the early 21st century.

              

            Functional

            The functional structure is probably the most common organizational structure and uses a pyramid shaped hierarchy that separates employees into groups based on the function of their job. There is usually a CEO (Chief Executive Officer) that is responsible for overall vision and direction and then job functions are broken down below him/her in a vertical hierarchy. Generally, functionally organized business will have different departments like: sales, marketing, operations/production, human resources, finance/accounting, technology, research and development, etc. with a series of managers/leaders in each functional division and at various levels within each division.

             

             Divisional

            The divisional structure separates employees by divisions. The divisions can be based on product/service, geography, customer or process.

            Product/Service Structure: putting employees into groups based on the different products that your company offers (e.g., Apple might have iPhone, iTunes, iPod and iPad divisions).
            Geographical Structure: putting employees into groups based on geographical regions (e.g., IBM divides its business into the regions of North America, Latin America, Europe, Middle East and Africa, and Asia Pacific).
            Customer Structure: putting employees into groups based on the customers that they serve or the distribution channels (e.g., Coke-a-Cola may set up divisions based on the types of customers it distributes to: restaurants, vending machines, grocery/convenience stores, corporations, etc.).

            Process Structure: putting employees into groups based on the processes that they perform (e.g., hospitals have floors for different processes: maternity, emergency, oncology, fracture, etc.)

             Matrix

            The matrix structure separates employees into departments (functional) and projects (divisional). Each employee is designated to both a department and a project. Sometimes, employees can be assigned to more than one project. The end result is a matrix of employees, all of whom have multiple managers. A construction company will make use of the matrix structure. The departments will include: architecture, engineers, construction labour, electricians, plumbers, etc. And the projects may include: Houses, Stadium, Office Building, Airport, etc. Therefore, an engineer assigned to help build the airport will belong to both the engineering department manager and the airport project manager.

             Team

            The team structure separates employees into teams. The teams can be both functional and/or divisional in nature and can be both horizontal and vertical in structure. Employees join teams or are designated into teams based on their competencies and synergy levels with other members of the team. Thus, a person who likes programming, is creative, and enjoys numbers may be a part of the development team, the marketing team and the accounting team all at the same time. Google is a company that uses this type of structure.

            The video below discusses Deloitte's organizational structure change from a functional structure towards a network structure. Deloitte is a well-known multinational professional services network. Nicky Wakefield, Human Capital Leader for Deloitte, talks about the rise of creating teams to work on projects.

              

             Network

            The network structure is most concerned with quality, efficiency and cost. It will give jobs to the organizations or departments that can do the best job at the cheapest cost. Therefore, a lot of work in a network structure is outsourced to other businesses that specialize in the work that is needed. For example, a company that specializes in developing websites may outsource its marketing (advertising) to an advertising firm, its accounting to an accounting company and its customer service to a third party with a specialty in dealing with customer complaints, returned merchandise, etc.  

              Boundaryless

            This type of organizational structure is so closely related to its suppliers and customers that it is almost seamless. In many cases, it is unimportant to managers where suppliers end and customers begin. Many of these businesses may have very little physical space as people can work from anywhere and work takes place in many places (including virtual space). Amazon.com is a good example of a boundaryless organization. The company connects suppliers and customers so seamlessly that, other than its outward facing website, it’s difficult to see where the Amazon work gets done.

            Success Criteria

            Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

            I understand the three primary traditional organizational structures and the three primary contemporary organizational structures (often displayed in, or by, "Org Charts").

             

            Advantages and Disadvantages of Organizational Structures

            In this check-up activity we will explore the advantages and disadvantages of the various organizational structures discussed in 5-1A.

            Gallery 5-1B: Advantages & Disadvantages of Organizational Structures
            Practice

            In this practice assessment, you will evaluate different organizational structures.

            Assignment 5-1C: Assessing Organizational Structures [CTA]

            5-1C: Assessing Organizational Structures [CTA]

            This is a CTA Activity.  

             Learning Goals

              • Assess traditional and current organizational structures.

              • Explain how properly matched structures can increase business success.

             Assignment Overview

            Step 1:  Assess the Structure 

            Individually, in partners, or as a class, examine the following list of businesses below.  Based on the descriptions of the businesses, provide an assessment of which organization structure you believe the business is using. Answer key can be found below.
             
            1.  A major accounting firm 
            2.  An electronics manufacturing company with operations all over the world. 
            3.  A hospital 
            4.  A construction company overseeing multiple departments and projects. 
            5. An online shopping and distributing company 
            6.  A company that outsources its work to different specialists. 
             
            Step 2:  Reflect 
             
            Evaluate each structure. Identify the structure that you think is the most reliable for a business to use.  Justify your choice with an explanation using course concepts and vocabulary. 
             
            Possible answer:  I believe a functional structure is the most reliable structure for a business to use because it seems to be the most common and trusted among businesses throughout history.  Since it uses a top-down structure, the overall vision and purpose is disseminated clearly throughout the company, and functions of the company are broken down into clear roles and segments.  A functional structure likely offers clarity and works well to remove any ambiguity within the organization. 

               

               Success Criteria

              You can assess your work against the success criteria that is listed here:

              I can identify and explain proper organizational structure.

              I can create an appropriate organizational structure for each business with the correct information.

              I can connect to other organizational structures that would work well.

                Answer Key

              1. Functional 
              2. Divisional - Geographical 
              3. Divisional - Process 
              4. Matrix 
              5. Boundaryless 
              6. Network 
                Vocabulary (Quizlet)

                  •  Organizational Structures
