                2
                5-2: Organizational Design (2 hours)
                Quizlet 5-2: Vocabulary Quizlet

                 

                 

                Lesson Vocabulary

                Quizlets

                Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

                For this lesson, focus on the following word:

                  • Organic Organizational Structure
                Click on 5-2: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
                ▼
                While organizational structure is an important factor in designing a workplace for success, organizational design also involves setting up the chosen structure in a way that promotes employee productivity and satisfaction. Steve Jobs, former CEO and co-founder of Apple, discusses Apple's unique organizational structure. Apple wants their corporate structure to feel like a start-up (albeit, the world's largest). Apple uses their structure to promote trust and highly functioning teams right across the organization. In this lesson, we will learn how managers can use an organizational structure to promote a positive, successful, corporate culture.
                Lesson Overview — Key Idea

                The central lesson in this unit is to understand the five key organizational design features and how they help or hinder corporate culture.

                Learning Goals & Success Criteria
                1. Explain the role of the manager in dealing with trends in organizational design structures
                  • I can explain the role of the manager in dealing with trends in organizational design structures
                2. Explain how organizational design can support a positive corporate culture
                  • I can explain how organizational design can support a positive corporate culture
                3. Discuss how managers can use organizational design to improve the workplace environment
                  • I can describe five organizational design features
                  • I can explain the importance of each of the five design features
                  • I can create an organizational design structure that helps produce a positive corporate culture
                Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
                • Critically examine organizational design features
                • Evaluate positive corporate culture and elements that create it
                Organizational Design - The Manager's Role

                The role of a manager is continuously changing and one of the central reasons is that organizational structures are changing. We will start this unit by exploring new organizational features such as shorter chains of command, decentralization, increased individual empowerment, and organic structures.

                Page 5-2A: Organizational Design - The Manager's Role

                Learning Goals

                  • Explain the changing role of the manager given new trends in organizational design structures.

                   

                 Organizational Design - The Manager's Role

                In recent years, the manager’s role (especially the middle manager) has changed due to a number of factors.

                 

                 Shorter Chain of Command:

                As organizational structures flatten, and less middle management positions are created, the typical chain of command has become shorter. There are simply less and less managers between ground level employees and top management. Middle managers must therefore assume more and more roles and responsibilities. They are now responsible for more projects, teams/groups, and individual employees. Managers must be even more organized than before in controlling resources.

                 

                 Decentralization:

                The downward filtering of power in decision-making has also been more prevalent in business in recent years  as Theory Y management practices have been put into place. As such, middle and lower management have been charged with the task of making more and more important decisions. Since these managers are a lot closer to the workers than upper management (who were formerly responsible for these important decisions), it is assumed that these middle and lower managers will make decisions that better reflect the ideas and needs of all the workers in the organization. Managers are now expected to leverage their workers’ opinions and ideas when making such decisions. 

                 

                 Increased Empowerment:

                Along with decentralization, managers may need to delegate responsibility and even some decision making to their employees. As middle and lower managers experience increased authority themselves, they may require their workers to input their ideas/opinions/work into decisions. Managers must now take on an evaluation role where they assess the input given by employees and make judgments as to their validity and effectiveness.

                  

                 Move Toward More Organic Structures:

                As businesses move to more organic structures leaders find themselves managing people and the environment more and more and and managing processes and work less and less. In organic structures, group and team leaders usually arise based on the needs of the group or project. Many times these team/group leaders will have expertise or experience in previous similar projects or areas. The goal of the manager is to support these leaders and ensure that the workers (people) have the correct resources to succeed. Thus, the focus becomes less on what work is being done by whom, and more on providing the right resources and creating an environment where the team can succeed.

                  

                Success Criteria

                Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                I can explain the role of the manager in dealing with trends in organizational design structures.

                 

                Organizational Design - Supporting a Positive Corporate Culture

                The proper organizational design will promote a positive corporate culture. Communication channels, team structures, alternative work schedules, and employee empowerment all have an impact on a company's structure and atmosphere.

                Page 5-2B: Organizational Design - Supporting a Positive Corporate Culture

                Learning Goals

                  • Explain how organizational design can support a positive corporate culture.

                   

                 Organizational Design - Supporting a Positive Corporate Culture

                By utilizing the proper organizational structure, managers can effectively promote a positive corporate culture. There are many things that enrich employees’ workplace that can affect the culture of the organization. A positive corporate culture is highly sought after by businesses and organizations and, by having a clearly designed organizational structure, businesses can lay the foundations of what they hope will be a positive environment 

                Communication Channels

                Most structures implicitly dictate how employees communicate. In a functional structure, employees know to communicate issues, problems and concerns to the person who manages them. In team structures, communication is done at the group level and teams can communicate with each other rather easily.  In either case and when designing an organizational structure, managers should implement clear and defined communication channels. If employees understand the organizational structure, then communication channels are understood regardless of which structure is used. Thus, employees have a means to voice concerns, issues and problems and this almost always leads to a more positive corporate culture.

                 

                Team Structures

                Where organizational structures allow for teamwork, a more positive corporate culture can emerge. Teams generally promote synergy and a sense of belonging. By having teams (especially where there is some empowerment as to which teams employees can work with/on) a more positive corporate culture is developed.

                 

                Alternative Work Schedules

                If an organizational structure is designed in a way that allows employees to work flexible schedules, then a more positive corporate culture can be established. Allowing workers more control over their work schedule and hours can lead to more content and efficient workers. This can often mean that some employees can do at least a portion of the their work from home, saving both the time and cost of a long work commute.

                 

                Employee Empowerment

                Organizational structures that empower employees and treat them with more Theory Y management strategies will generally have a more positive corporate culture. When employees feel that management trusts and empowers them to work productively, then they are generally more satisfied with their work and work place. Allowing employees to join certain groups, set their own schedules, and even participate in negotiations are all ways to empower employees and add to a positive corporate culture.

                 

                Success Criteria

                Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                I can explain how elements of organizational design can support a positive corporate culture.

                 

                Vocabulary (Quizlet)
                Organic Organizational Structure
                Learning Log: 5-2 (Target: 2 hours) — Questionnaire
                3
                5-3: Organizing the Work Environment (3 hours)
                Quizlet 5-3: Vocabulary Quizlet

                 

                 

                Lesson Vocabulary

                Quizlets

                Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

                For this lesson, focus on the following words:

                  • Bankable Days
                  • Compressed Workweeks
                  • Contract Work
                  • Employee-Employer Relationships
                  • Flextime
                  • Job Enlargement
                  • Job Enrichment
                  • Job Rotation
                  • Job Sharing
                  • Job Simplification
                  • Off Site Work
                  • Psychological Contract
                  • Self-Managed Teams
                  • Shift Work Maximums
                Click on 5-3: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
                ▼
                Organizational leaders and managers need to understand how important the work environment is to their employees' overall job satisfaction. Given the onset of new technology and Theory Y management strategies, managers now have many more options at their disposal to create environments that are pleasing and satisfying for their employees. Good employer-employee relationships take time to foster. Trust is a critical component. When employees distrust management, the workplace can degenerate into a place of distrust, negative ambition, and disloyalty.
                Lesson Overview — Key Idea

                The lesson focuses on employee-employer relationships and job design.

                Learning Goals & Success Criteria
                1. Assess the relationship between the individual and an organization
                  • I can explain the four major types of relationships between employees and employers
                2. Communicate your ideas about how an employee's meaning of work, psychological contract, quality of work life and job satisfaction affect his/her relationship with the company
                  • I can communicate the main factors affecting employee-employer relationships
                3. Determine job designs and workplace settings that will help you succeed as an employee
                  • I can explain the five major principles of job design
                  • I can explain the four job design techniques
                4. Apply understanding of the five principles to create a job design
                  • I can create a job design for one of the three jobs listed
                  • I can apply the five principles of job design
                5. Compare alternative job design approaches
                6. Compare the advantages and disadvantages of various work settings
                  • I can compare alternative job design approaches
                  • I can compare the advantages and disadvantages of various work settings
                Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
                • Critically think about job design
                • Evaluate employee-employer relationships
                Employee-Employer Relationships

                The relationship between employers and their employees is significant to the functionality of any business. A great relationship tends to lead to excellent performance, while a weak/poor relationship can lead to stress and ineffective work.

                Page 5-3A: Employee-Employer Relationships

                Learning Goals

                  • Assess the relationship between the individual and an organization.

                   

                Employee-Employer Relationships

                There are four major types of relationships between employees and employers. They include:

                The Master/Slave Relationship

                This relationship is commonly seen in companies that have autocratic styles of leadership. All of the power and control is given to management and the employees are seen as slaves – those that do whatever the master wants. Employees will work in these types of jobs because they generally do not have any alternatives. The compensation is usually low and employees feel overworked and underpaid.

                   

                 The Symbiotic Relationship

                This relationship is characterized by mutual aid actions. Each party understands that their success and goals are more easily attainable with the help of the other party. The managers understand that the employees provide valuable work, without which the business would fold. And the employees understand that the business enables them to earn a living and help pay for life’s necessities. Therefore, they will work together in order to achieve better situations for themselves. 

                   

                 The Dual Exploitative Relationship

                In this relationship, both parties will try to exploit the other in order to get as much as possible out of the employee/employer relationship. Employers will generally try to squeeze work out of employees, requiring them to work maximum hours for as little pay as possible. On the other side, employees will try to exploit their employers to gain more benefits, compensation and job perks. They may refrain from doing extra work to help the company if their compensation terms are not met. This often leads to unproductive time as both sides expense time and effort trying to find ways to exploit the other party to get more out of the relationship.

                   

                 The Common Goal Relationship

                This relationship is fostered in businesses and employees that share common positive goals. When an employee’s goals align with his/her company’s goals, a common goal partnership can develop. This is where both parties work toward a goal as opposed to working for personal motives. An example of this type of relationship is the environmental lawyer that wants to help save the environment. He/she may take a low paying position with an environmentalist organization in order that they both might help save the environment together.

                Success Criteria

                Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                I can explain the four major types of relationships between employees and employers.

                 

                As we have learned, there are many types of employee-employer relationships. In this next activity we will learn about things an employer should focus on to foster strong and healthy relationships.

                Page 5-3B: Fostering a Good Employee-Employer Relationship

                Learning Goals

                  • Communicate your ideas about how an employee's meaning of work, psychological contract, quality of work life and job satisfaction affect his/her relationship with the company.

                   

                 Fostering a Good Employee-Employer Relationship

                There are many factors that can foster a good employee-employer relationship in a work environment. Some of the more common elements of fostering a good working relationship are examined below.

                 

                Meaning of Work

                When work is meaningful, employees can gain fulfillment from their job. This will create a sense of satisfaction and the employee may form a better relationship with the company (as opposed to if the work was not meaningful). Consider a truck driver who transports vehicles to and from the shipping dock each day. He/she may not find much meaning in the transport of vehicles; however, if the same truck driver were transporting food to needy families with starving children each day, he/she may form a better relationship with his manager/company because of the meaning of his/her work.

                 

                 Psychological Contract

                Unlike a formal contract, that outlines the duties/responsibilities of each party (employee/employer), the psychological contract is an unwritten contract that represents the informal obligations that each part has to one another. Where a formal contract will specify the amount of time the employee has to work each day (say 8 hours), an psychological contract might be made between manager and employee that, “as long as work gets done, the manager will not keep track of the time spent on the job.” Other examples of the psychological contract include the company’s willingness to keep snacks in the kitchen that employees can eat or the informal obligation of the employee to answer the company telephone when it rings.

                 

                 Quality of Work Life

                A better employee/employer relationship can emerge when the quality of the work life improves. If employees are engaged at work and have companions that they feel comfortable with, then the relationship between the employee and employer can improve. Generally speaking, if the employee enjoys work life, he/she is more likely to:

                  • Want to spend time at work
                  • Be motivated to work to keep his/her job
                  • Work to improve the quality of work life even further
                  • Improve the work life of others around him/her

                 

                 Job Satisfaction

                When employees are content with their jobs, it is more likely that they will look favourably on their employer. When this occurs, it is likely that the relationship between employer, management, boss, etc. and employee will flourish. There are many theories of how we determine job satisfaction. Some theories include:

                  1. Affect theory states that our job satisfaction can be determined by the size of the gap between what we want in a job and what we have in a job.
                  2. Dispositional theory states that we have certain individual tendencies and past experiences that tend to make our job satisfaction fairly stable regardless of the nature of the work/job.
                  3. Equity theory states that our satisfaction is highest when we see a fair relationship between what we put into the job and what we get out of it (things gained from things given).
                  4. Two factor theory states that satisfaction (and dissatisfaction) are driven by two factors – motivation and hygiene factors. Motivation is the inner force that drives people to do things to attain personal goals. Hygiene factors are external forces like pay, working conditions, etc.

                 

                 Personal Growth (Engagement)

                When employees grow as human beings and are engaged in their work, they are more likely to have a positive relationship with their employer. As an employee’s job starts to meet more and more of their needs (see Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs), they begin to experience more and more personal growth. This fulfillment of needs can improve the relationship with the employee’s employer.

                   

                Success Criteria

                Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                I can communicate the main factors affecting employee-employer relationships.  

                 

                Job Design

                An employee's job description and role is a key factor in their job satisfaction. Leaders must be able to design clearly defined jobs and roles that give employees a sense of meaning and role with their working peers.

                Page 5-3C: Job Design

                Learning Goals

                  • Acting as a manager, design job descriptions and roles that meet employee needs.  

                   

                Job Design

                Job design is also referred to as work design or task design. It’s main goal is to use principles of people’s behaviours and attitudes to try to improve job satisfaction.

                What is Job Design?

                Strong and healthy Job Design generally incorporates a combination of these nine major principles:

                1. Variety of Skills: jobs that require the employee to use a wider range of skills are likely more satisfying jobs.
                2. Task Identity: jobs that start and finish a process are more likely to be fulfilling. If the employee can see the completion of a whole piece of work, it is more satisfying than just performing one task (e.g., assembly line task).
                3. Task Significance: jobs that have an impact on a larger scale are typically more satisfying. When employees can see their job adding value to others or the company, it is more satisfying.
                4. Autonomy: when the individual employee is given more choice and decision-making in a job, it leads to more job satisfaction.
                5. Feedback: jobs that enable employees to get feedback about their performance from managers generally have an increased interest in doing a good job. This often leads, understandably, to increased job satisfaction.
                6. Job Rotation: can increase productivity by ensuring employees use different skills every time a rotation occurs.
                7. Job Enrichment: allows employees to increase their autonomy over their job by planning and executing their own work. Employees are given more responsibility and control over their work.
                8. Job Enlargement: is a process where individual workers determine their own pace and set their own timelines/deadlines (within the larger framework). They may also serve as their own inspectors and may even have the authority to take their own corrective measures to fix any problems on their own.
                9. Job Simplification: requires the work to be broken down into relatively simple tasks. This increases productivity and can reduce mental or physical effort. The classic example is of the assembly line. While this technique may seem counter intuitive to proper job satisfaction, it could be implemented in high stress, highly skilled jobs where burnout rates are high. To break down tasks to small manageable pieces may actually increase job satisfaction.

                 

                Success Criteria

                Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                I understand and can outline and explain nine major principles of job design that enhance employee satisfaction.

                 

                Business leaders must be able to develop an effective organizational design that enhances the workplace environment. In this activity, we will be applying what we have learned about organizational design and supporting positive corporate culture to different scenarios.

                Assignment 5-3D: Organizational Culture and Job Design [CTA]

                5-3D: Organizational Culture and Job Design [CTA]

                This is a CTA Activity.  

                 Learning Goals

                  • Discuss how managers can use organizational design to improve the workplace environment for his/her employees.
                  • Apply my understanding of the nine principles that create healthy and meaningful jobs.

                 Assignment Overview

                Step 1:  Form the Corporate Culture 
                You have decided to start your own cosmetics company.  As such, you will need to decide about how you will go about fostering a positive corporate culture.  
                Individually, with a partner, or a class, decide on the features that will you implement in your new company to bring about a positive culture.  Justify your choices using your knowledge of organizational design. 
                 
                Possible answers: 
                One idea I will implement is alternative work schedules.  In today’s business climate, it is no longer a pressing need to have all my employees always convene in a physical space.  To get the best out of my employees, I need to ensure they have a high morale, and to do so, I can implement a system where they can work from home and can work at hours more convenient and accommodating to them. 
                Another idea I have is to improve communication channels.  I will try to maintain an open-door policy so that employees feel free to voice concerns as they are happening and to allow for quicker resolution.   
                 
                Step 2:  Design the Job 
                Of course, in any organization, having clearly defined roles and positions is critical.  Identify and describe the features of job design that you will implement.  Using your knowledge of course concepts and organizational design to support your answer.  
                 
                Possible answers: 
                First and foremost, I believe autonomy is essential to include in any job in our organization.  If I want my employees to feel satisfied with working at my company, I need to ensure that they have freedom to make decisions in their job.  I believe that autonomy, in tandem with alternative work schedules, will complement this well.  Employees can use their autonomy to develop new products, pitch new designer lines, etc. 
                As well, I will look to use job enlargement as a feature.  To further provide flexibility to my employees, this feature of job design will allow for employees to set their own deadlines and have even more control of their day-to-day work. 
                Of course, employees need to see how everything will come together in our organization, therefore, task identity is very important to maintain in our operations.  Employees deserve to see the product of their efforts, so, this is something that needs to be accounted for. 

                 Success Criteria

                You will be assessed on the success criteria that is listed here:

                I can describe five organizational design features.
                 I can explain the importance of each of the five design features in an organizational structure.
                 I can create an organizational design structure that helps produce a positive corporate culture.

                I can create a job design for the job listed above.

                I can effectively apply some of the nine principles of job design. 

                Alternative types of work settings are becoming more popular. Flexible work hours and working outside of the traditional office is becoming increasingly popular in the 21st century.

                Page 5-3E: Alternative Types of Work Settings

                Learning Goals

                  • Compare alternative job settings.
                  • Compare the advantages and disadvantages of various work settings.

                   

                Alternative Types of Work Settings

                There are many types of work settings that managers can use to enhance organizational efficiency and employee productivity. Allowing employees flexibility in the way that they work or where they work can create more productive, satisfied workers. 

                The video below discusses the flexible work opportunities for employees of Ernst and Young, one of the largest multinational professional service firms in the world and one of the "Big Four" accounting firms.

                 

                  

                As you just watched, Ernst and Young allows their employees significant flexibility over when and where they work part of their schedule. This flexibility produces many benefits for their workforce which both empowers and satisfies their employees. Some of the alternative work settings that were introduced will be examined in more detail below. 

                 

                Job Sharing

                An employment arrangement that allows for two part time employees to share the job that normally one full time employee would perform. The wages are proportioned appropriately and the two employees collaborate to complete tasks.

                 

                 Self-Managed Teams

                This is an employee group that is given a task by management. Every aspect of the task is then decided by the group itself. The group controls the decision making and is responsible for the final outcome. After giving the task, management does not involve itself with the self-managed team as the team is accountable for all aspects of the work.

                 

                 Work Schedules

                There are many different work schedules that companies can offer their employees. The most popular include:

                  • Flextime – the employee works 8 hours per day, but the time of day is up to them. Sometimes, there may be certain hours (e.g., between 10 am and 2pm) during the flextime where employees are expected to be in the office.
                  • Compressed Workweeks – the employee works ten hours per day for four days each week and then has three days off.
                  • Bankable Days – the employee is allowed to bank days off based on overtime worked. An example is an employee that works nine hours per day over a five day work week, earning them one full day off every two weeks.  
                  • Shift Work Maximums – some employees will work long (sometimes over 24 hour shifts) until they hit a monthly maximum. When this occurs, they get weeks off until a new month starts (examples include firemen and pilots).

                 

                 Off Site Work

                In order to save on overhead, companies will allow employees to work from home or use a mobile office (in their car, at a coffee shop, etc.). This saves the employer overhead costs (electricity, water, furniture, etc.) and gives the employee more autonomy over where and when they work.

                 

                 Contract Work

                Instead of hiring full time employees, some companies will opt for contract workers. These workers sign a contract to work for the company for a specific amount of time. The company benefits because they do not generally offer contract workers benefits, nor are they obliged to renew the contract, so they can easily terminate the work.

                 

                Success Criteria

                Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                I can compare alternative job design approaches.

                I can compare the advantages and disadvantages of various work settings.

                 

                Vocabulary (Quizlet)
                Bankable Days Compressed Workweeks Contract Work Employee-Employer Relationships Flextime Job Enlargement Job Enrichment Job Rotation Job Sharing Job Simplification Off Site Work Psychological Contract Self-Managed Teams Shift Work Maximums
                Learning Log: 5-3 (Target: 3 hours) — Questionnaire
                4
                5-4: Human Resource Process (3 hours)
                ▼
                The Human Resource (HR) Department is in charge of the human element of the workplace. Overseeing such a critical and complex component means that HR plays a key role in the success of a business. One of the responsibilities of the human resource department is to inform employees of laws and rights related to their health and safety. The central learning in this unit is to understand the Human Resource Department and the critical role it plays in the workplace.
                Lesson Overview — Key Idea

                The key idea of this lesson is to understand the scope of work which is completed by the Human Resources Department. In addition, students should be able to comprehend legal considerations and how technology has changed traditional HR work.

                Learning Goals & Success Criteria
                1. Describe the human resource process
                  • I can explain the various processes involved in managing Human Resources
                2. Analyze the legal considerations that the human resources department must deal with
                  • I can explain the legal considerations regarding wages, employment equity, health and safety, employee rights, and bargaining agreements
                3. Apply understanding of Human Resources to an organization
                  • I can apply my understanding of the Human Resource Department to an organization
                4. Research current issues that human resource departments must deal with
                5. Define the roles that HR need to play to address issues
                  • I can research a company's current Human Resources roles, especially in light of rapidly changing technology
                Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
                • Critically think about Human Resources
                • Evaluate HR policies
                The Human Resource Process

                The Human Resource (HR) Department is in charge of the human element of the workplace. Overseeing such a critical and complex component means that HR plays a key role in the success of any business.

                Page 5-4A: Human Resources: What They Do

                Learning Goals

                  • Describe the human resource process.

                   

                The Human Resource Process

                The goal of the human resources department is to maximize employee performance within the confines of the employers’ strategic objectives. The work of the Human Resource department is important and complex.  

                 

                Recruitment

                This stage involves advertising job positions, selecting appropriate candidates and being involved in the interview and hiring process. Human resources will also execute contracts with new employees.

                 

                 Goal Setting

                Before inducting employees into positions, the human resources department may help the new employee set goals for his/her position with the company. Thus, both the company and employee will understand where the employee plans to be in the future and what avenues he/she is interested in.

                 

                 Training and Development

                Human resources will also help in the training of new recruits. Most HR training revolves around company policies and standards. New employees will learn about dress code, unwritten rules, and the general layout of the office/building/site. The Human Resources Department will also offer employees personal and professional development opportunities like conferences and seminars.

                 

                 Compensation and Benefits

                This stage involves paying the employee and informing him/her of the benefits he/she receives as an employee of the company. Often times, employees are unaware of the benefits that come with the job and so human resources employees spend a lot of time answering extended health, dental, and other contract/benefits related questions.

                 

                 Performance Appraisal

                Human resources will usually be involved in the evaluation process of all employees. Most performance appraisals (reviews) are filed with and kept in the human resources department. Human resources will also try to ensure that all employees are following legal and regulatory procedures. 

                 

                 Career and Leadership Management

                The Human Resources department is responsible for maximizing employee potential and satisfaction. As such, part of their process is to enhance employees’ career opportunities and improve their leadership skills. HR workers are tasked with continually grooming current employees to take on increasing roles and responsibilities within the company. This helps improve job satisfaction as employees can see a progression from their current careers. . Furthermore, human resources will also deal with dispute resolution cases. When employees have grievances against one another, it is the HR Department that will mediate a solution to the problem.

                 

                 Termination

                When employees are fired, laid off, declared redundant or retire, the human resources department is responsible for overseeing the process. Often times an exit interview will be conducted to help the employer with future cases. Once a position is vacated, the human resources department must begin the process over again beginning at the recruitment stage.

                  

                Success Criteria

                Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                I can explain the various processes involved in managing Human Resources.

                 

                Legal Considerations in the Human Resource Process

                One of the responsibilities of an HR employee is to be aware of legal considerations regarding employees. This includes wages, employment equity, health and safety, employee rights, and bargaining agreements.

                Page 5-4B: Legal Considerations in Human Resources

                Learning Goals

                  • Analyze the legal considerations which the Human Resources Department must handle.

                   

                 Legal Considerations in the Human Resources Process

                There are many legal considerations which HR must address. Some of these include wages, employment equity, health and safety, employee rights, and bargaining agreements.

                Wages

                Some legal considerations around wages include:

                  • Minimum wage – in the Province of Ontario it is $15 per hour for adults.  Other provinces inside of Canada will vary.  Other jurisdictions around the world may vary considerably. 
                  • If called in to work by an employer, you must be paid for no less than three hours.
                  • Vacation pay of 4% must be paid to employees.
                  • Employers can take government deductions like income tax, employment insurance and Canadian Pension Plan.
                  • Courts can order garnished wages for things like spousal and child support.

                 
                The video below talks about the ongoing debate of whether the minimum wage should be increased in certain provinces in Canada. It is important for HR to keep track of changes to the minimum wage and any other legal considerations associated with wages.

                 Employment Equity

                  • “Employment equity encourages the establishment of working conditions that are free of barriers, corrects the conditions of disadvantage in employment and promotes the principle that employment equity requires special measures and the accommodation of differences for the four designated groups in Canada.” - http://www.labour.gc.ca/eng/standards_equity/eq/emp/

                  • Applies to federally regulated industries, Crown corporations and other federal organizations with 100 or more employees.

                  • Four designated groups are: Aboriginals, Women, Persons with Disabilities, Visible Minorities.

                  • The following infographics provide details on the state of designated group representation in the Canadian core public administration:

                 
                 Health and Safety

                  • Employees have the right to refuse work if they feel their personal safety is at risk.

                  • Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations outline the numerous laws that companies must follow to ensure safety for their employees and customers. Everything from buildings to lighting to sanitation to first aid are included in the document (http://laws.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-86-304/index.html)

                  • At any workplace where there are six or more employees working at any time, the employer must ensure that there is a first aid attendant (someone with a basic first aid certificate).

                  • Every double-action swinging door that is located in an exit, entrance or passageway used for two-way pedestrian traffic or traffic involving wheelchairs or other similar devices shall be designed and fitted in a manner that will allow persons who are approaching from one side of the door to be aware of persons who are on the other side of it.

                  • No food waste or garbage shall be stored in a food preparation area.

                  • Each personal service room and food preparation area shall be ventilated to provide at least two changes of air per hour.

                 Employee Rights

                The following rights can be found under the Federal Labour Standards - http://www.labour.gc.ca/eng/standards_equity/st/index.shtml

                  • Canadian employees are entitled to a minimum of two weeks vacation annually after completing one year of employment with the same employer. After six consecutive years of employment, three weeks is allotted.
                  • Standard weekly work hours: 40 hours per week or 8 hours per day to a maximum of 48 hours per week.
                  • In Ontario for every five hours worked, an employee must receive a 30 minute eating period.
                  • There are a number of legal leave options – sick leave, long term disability, leave for work related illness and injury, maternity/paternity leave, compassionate care leave, bereavement leave, and other forms of leave that can be paid or unpaid but must guarantee the employee a position with the employer upon return from the leave.
                  • If the employer wishes to terminate an employee, they must either give two weeks notice or two weeks of regular wages.
                  • Employees have the right not to be subject to sexual harassment 

                 

                 Bargaining Agreements

                  • Sometimes collective union agreements will attempt to influence company policy. For instance, if the company has a policy that workers are to get a 30 minute eating break at 12pm every day in order to ensure that everyone is on break at the same time, the union may refer to the collective agreement with the company that stipulates breaks can be taken at the employees discretion.  In cases like this, companies will have to yield to their bargained agreement.

                  • Some bargaining agreements will stipulate a minimum wage – the NHL had a minimum salary of $525,000 USD in 2013 with that number increasing to $750,000 by 2023.

                Success Criteria

                Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                I can outline and explain several legal considerations that surround HR work in a company.  These may include, but are not limited to:  wages, employment equity, health and safety, employee rights, and bargaining agreements.


                 

                Organizational Goals and the Human Resource Process

                Making sure employees understand overall organizational goals is a fundamental role for HR. When planning, recruiting, and selecting employees, HR must always keep in mind the company's overall plans and strategy.

                Page 5-4C: Organizational Goals, New Technology, and Human Resources

                Learning Goals

                  • Apply my understanding of Human Resources and their work to the overall goals of an organization.

                   

                Organizational Goals and the Human Resource Process

                It is important that every piece of work done by HR aligns with overall organizational goals. Whether it is recruiting or goal setting, the HR department must ensure that they have a firm grasp of overall organizational goals and are constantly matching their work with this vision.

                The video below discusses how the role of HR has evolved and is continuing to change as a result of the development of social media and technology.  These new roles also must link with overall vision and direction of the company.  As you watch the video, consider how HR was originally enlisted with a straightforward, functional role, but has changed into a transformational role that includes brand building, analysis, communication, and motivation.   

                  

                Success Criteria

                Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                I can apply my understanding of Human Resource roles to an organization and include how technology has changed our understanding of these roles.

                 

                In this activity, you will select a company and describe the HR work that they do.

                Forum 5-4D: Exploring HR Work in a Major Company [CTA]
                Evaluation

                For this summative assignment, you will be able to apply all your knowledge and skills from lesson 5-4. There are many issues to which HR must deal with and respond. In this assignment, you will research a contemporary issue in the media, summarize, and analyze it.

                Assignment *5-4E: Human Resource Research Assignment 6%

                 
                *5-4E: Human Resource Research Assignment [6%]

                This activity will be counted in your final grade

                Overall Expectations & Learning Goals

                • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 
                • Evaluate the role of human resources within an organization. (E3) 

                •  

                 Assignment Overview

                NOTE TO CLASSROOM TEACHERS:

                On tasks where students have a choice of topic, as CTs, please ensure an equal and fair distribution of ALL topics among your students. In other words, if you have 10 students and students have 4 topics to choose from, ensure that not all 10 students are writing on 1 topic.

                This will help reduce the ACVs that arise due to lack of variety within the class.

                There are a number of strategies that you can use to distribute the topics to students:

                a) Place a limit on the number of students that can choose the same topic.  In this assignment, there are 5 topics. Divide the total number of students by the total # of topics. This is the maximum number of students that should do a specific topic. For example, if you have a class of 15, only 3 students should be writing on 1 topic.

                b) Ask students to select their topic on a first come first served basis up to the maximum number of students allowed per topic. 

                c) Randomly place topics in a hat, and allow students to draw their topic

                d) Assign students a topic (least preferred as it removes student choice)

                Remind students that all work should in their own words and their own thoughts. Failure to do so will result in an ACV violation  - which is often a zero on the assignment. 

                Please visit the CT Instructional Resource Centre for more instructional strategies.   

                In this activity, you will explore the legal considerations in human resources.  You will find a case that focuses on one of the legal considerations and analyze the roles and responsibilities that human resources take on to ensure these legal considerations are met. You will present your findings in a video PowerPoint presentation.    

                Step 1: Select a Consideration   
                  
                Select one of the HR legal considerations as the focus of your presentation:  
                • Wages 
                • Employment Equity 
                • Health and Safety 
                • Employee Rights 
                • Bargaining Agreements 
                  
                Step 2: Locate a Related Case  
                • Locate a recent article or case study online that deals with the legal consideration you selected. A good article or case study would be one that describes a scenario where the employer has not fulfilled their duty with regards to the HR legal consideration you have selected. You will use this case in your analysis. Your case should be published in the last 24 months. 
                • Download the Graphic Organizer.
                • Record the information required to cite your source using APA format in the organizer. Include in-text citations and a reference list.  
                 
                Step 3: Analyse the Case 
                • Analyze your case using the questions below:  
                • Summarize the main ideas of your case/scenario.  Identify and describe the Who, What, Where, When, Why, and How to guide you.  
                • Identify and describe the legal consideration that is at issue in your case. Support your description with specific details from your case.  
                • Reflect on your knowledge of the HR process. Identify the stages of the HR process that are directly involved with your issue. Explain how the stages are related to your issue.  
                • Describe how HR responded to the issue in your case.  
                • Analyze the response.  
                  • Identify any positive aspects of the HR response (i.e, what was done well/what actions or decisions were positive). Explain why you think they are positive aspects with details from the case.  If there are no positive aspects, explain why not.  
                  • Identify any negative aspects of the HR response (i.e., what was not done well/what actions or decisions were negative). Explain why you think they are negative aspects with details from the case.  If there are no negative aspects, explain why not.  
                • Evaluate the response. Describe which aspects of the HR response you agree with and which aspects you disagree with.  Justify your description with specific reference to the case. Propose at least 1 thing that you would do differently or improve if you were the HR manager.  Explain how this proposal would help resolve the legal consideration issue present in the case.   
                • Record your notes in the 5-4: Human Resources Research Organizer  
                • Submit your Graphic Organizer with your final presentation/report.  
                 
                Step 3: Organize and Present your Research.  
                • Use the information in your organizer to prepare your presentation.   
                • Follow the guidelines on the organizer to help you organize the number of pages/ slides.  
                 
                Step 4: Create your presentation. 
                • Record your presentation.   
                • Submit your Graphic Organizer and final Presentation video.  

                  

                Submission Requirements  
                • Compressed Video file  [3-4 Minute Video PowerPoint submission]
                • PPT (8-10 slides with in-text citations, last slide must be an APA formatted reference page) and Graphic Organizer as 1 compressed pdf 

                  

                Citation Guidelines    
                 
                 
                 
                 
                 
                 

                Citation Style  
                 
                 
                 
                 
                 

                APA  
                 
                 
                 
                 
                 

                Reference Page  
                 
                 
                 
                 

                This assignment requires you to complete an APA style reference page that should list the sources you consulted while conducting your research.  
                 
                 
                 
                 
                 

                In-Text Citation Requirement  
                 
                 
                 
                 

                Please supply in-text citations for researched information included in your responses.  
                 
                 
                 
                 
                 

                Sample citation for Reference Page  

                  
                 
                 
                 
                 

                Beck, C. B. (2010). An overview of plant structure and development. In An introduction to plant structure and development: Plant Anatomy for the Twenty-First Century (p. 11). essay, Cambridge University Press.  
                 
                 
                 
                 
                 

                Sample In-Text Citation  

                  
                 
                 
                 
                 

                Unlike humans whose capacity for growth stops after a certain point where cells begin replacing dead cells instead of adding tissue, vascular plants can continue to add new cells and tissues to the plant body for as long as they live. This can explain how extremely old vascular plants, like Redwood trees in California, have developed such massive trunks over time (Beck, 2010).  
                 
                 
                 
                 
                 

                For further details on How to Cite your work correctly, please consult the How to Cite page of the Academic Skills Module: Working with Information   
                 
                 
                 
                 
                 

                IMPORTANT NOTE:  It is expected that all text be in your own words. Research should be paraphrased rather than directly copied. Any text directly copied will be considered plagiarism and result in an academic integrity violation.  

                  

                Work submitted without any citations will automatically be given an Academic Integrity Violation and a Zero.  

                 Success Criteria

                You will be assessed on the success criteria listed below:

                1. I can summarize the facts of a case. (E3.1) (E3.4) 
                2. I can identify and describe HR legal considerations.  (E3.1) (E3.4) 
                3. I can analyze and organize my research using the given graphic organizer in the assignment. (A2.1) 
                4. I can reflect on the HR process and make connections between stages of the process and HR legal considerations.  (E3.1, E3.2) 
                5. I can analyze the HR response to a scenario and identify positive and negative aspects of the response. (E3.2) 
                6. I can use appropriate business vocabulary to explain my ideas. (A2.1) (A2.4)  
                7. I can present my ideas using effective presentation techniques.  (A2.1) (A2.4) 
                8. I can present without reading directly off my notes/script. (A2.1) (A2.4) 
                9. I can speak at an appropriate pace and tone (with inflection) (A2.1) (A2.4) 
                10. I can evaluate an HR response and propose recommendations to respond to issues that involve legal considerations. (E3.2) 
                11. I can identify and use credible sources for my research. (A2.1) 
                12. I can cite my sources using APA format.  (A2.1) 
                13. I can use in-text citations and a reference list to acknowledge my research sources (A2.1)  

                  How to Submit

                  • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
                  • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.
                  • Submit your completed assignment using the "Add Submission" button located at the bottom of this page.
