                Learning Log: 5-4 (Target: 3 hours) — Questionnaire
                5
                5-5: Human Resource Strategies (2 hours)
                Quizlet 5-5: Vocabulary Quizlet

                 

                 

                Lesson Vocabulary

                Quizlets

                Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

                For this lesson, focus on the following word:

                  •  Stay Interview
                Click on 5-5: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
                ▼
                There are a number of ways that the Human Resources Department can develop and retain quality employees. One way is to meet with employees on a regular basis to discuss their performance and to show appreciation for the work they do. Frequently meeting with employees offers the opportunity for both constructive feedback and positive reinforcement. Both of these are necessary to keep employees happy, productive, and meeting company objectives.
                Lesson Overview — Key Idea

                The key idea of this lesson is to learn various strategies to develop and retain quality employees.

                Learning Goals & Success Criteria
                1. Explain the strategies and concepts involved in developing and retaining a quality workforce
                  • I can explain various strategies involved in effective HR practices such as training, developing, and retaining employees
                  • I can describe at least two strategies to retain quality employees
                2. Describe current management opportunities and the education/training that these positions require
                3. Research and discuss current management opportunities
                  • I can research the education, training, skills, and experience related to a particular job
                  • I can critically assess a job posting
                Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
                • Assess strategies for retaining quality employees
                • Evaluate management opportunities
                Developing and Retaining Quality Employees

                Another key to operating a successful company is to develop quality employees. Employees, after all, are what keeps the business running.

                Page 5-5A: Developing Quality Employees

                Learning Goals

                  • Explain the strategies and concepts involved in developing and retaining a quality workforce.

                   

                Developing Quality Employees

                In this learning activity, students will learn about different ways that organizations develop their employees.

                Initial Orientation and Training

                By having proper orientation and initial training in place, companies can mitigate long term, systemic issues in job performance. If you teach employees correctly before they begin their career, they will be less likely to make the same mistakes over and over. For example, the Ritz-Carlton hotel chain trains employees to embrace and memorize the Ritz-Carlton Basics as part of employee training. Thus, the hotel knows that every trained worker has a grasp of the Ritz-Carleton basics committed to memory.  

                THE RITZ-CARLTON BASICS

                  1. The Credo will be known, owned and energized by all employees.
                  2. Our motto is: “We are Ladies and Gentlemen serving Ladies and Gentlemen”. Practice teamwork and “lateral service” to create a positive work environment.
                  3. The three steps of service shall be practiced by all employees.
                  4. All employees will successfully complete Training Certification to ensure they understand how to perform to the Ritz-Carlton standards in their position.
                  5. All employees will successfully understand their work area and Hotel goals as established in each strategic plan.
                  6. All employees will know the needs of their internal and external customers (guests and employees) so that we may deliver the products and services they expect. Use guest performance pads to record specific needs.
                  7. Each employee will continuously identify defects (Mr. BIV) throughout the Hotel.
                  8. Any employee who receives a customer complaint “owns” the complaint.
                  9. Instant guest pacification will be ensured by all. React quickly to correct the problem immediately. Follow-up with a telephone call within twenty minutes to verify the problem has been resolved to the customer’s satisfaction. Do everything you possibly can to never lose a guest.
                  10. Guest incident action forms are used to record and communicate every incident of guest dissatisfaction. Every employee is empowered to resolve the problem and to prevent a repeat occurrence.
                  11. Uncompromising levels of cleanliness are the responsibility of every employee.
                  12. “Smile-We are on stage.” Always maintain positive eye contact with our guests. (Use words like- “Good Morning,” “Certainly,” “I will be happy to” and “My pleasure”).
                  13. Be an ambassador of your hotel in and outside of the work place. Always talk positively. No negative comments.
                  14. Escort guests rather than pointing out directions to another area of the Hotel.
                  15. Be knowledgeable of Hotel information (hours of operation, etc.) to answer guest inquiries. Always recommend the Hotel’s retail and food beverage outlet prior to outside facilities.
                  16. Use proper telephone etiquette. Answer within three rings and with a “smile.” When necessary, ask the caller, “May I place you on hold.” Do not screen calls. Eliminate call transfers when possible.
                  17. Uniforms are to be immaculate; Wear proper and safe footwear (clean and polished), and your correct name tag. Take pride and care in your personal appearance (adhere to all grooming standards).
                  18. Ensure all employees know their roles during emergency situations and are aware of fire and life safety processes.
                  19. Notify your supervisor immediately of hazards, injuries, equipment or assistance that you need. Practice energy conservation and proper maintenance and repair of Hotel property and equipment.
                  20. Protecting the assets of a Ritz-Carlton Hotel is the responsibility of every employee.

                   

                   Career and Professional Development

                  Having programs, seminars, training sessions, etc. where employees can learn and grow are key factors in developing quality employees. As we learned earlier, when we can introduce job enrichment and job enlargement, we can increase an employee’s job satisfaction. However, job enrichment and enlargement must also be paired with proper professional training and development. When companies implement these development pieces into their corporate strategy, they can develop a quality workforce.

                  Success Criteria

                  Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                  I can explain at least two strategies or concepts involved in developing and retaining a quality workforce.

                   

                  Developing quality employees is step number one. Next, businesses must focus on retaining these employees. Many businesses spend a lot of time and resources on developing quality employees only to fail to retain them.

                  Page 5-5B: Retaining Quality Employees

                  Learning Goals

                    • Explain the strategies and concepts involved in developing and retaining a quality workforce.

                     

                  Retaining Quality Employees

                  There are a number of ways that organizations try to ensure that their good employees stay with the company and do not get lured elsewhere.  Outside of salary/pay, three of the best retention strategies are outlined below.

                   

                  Stay Interviews

                  We all know about the job interview, and some of us know about the exit interview; however, very few people know about the “stay interview”. This is an interview that is conducted with current employees to get a better understanding of why they stay with the company. Many companies will interview employees who have been with the organization for a long time and ask them questions like: Why did you come to work here? Why do you stay here? Is there anything that would make you leave? What would you change? Etc. Using this information, a business can then create an employee retention strategy.

                  Bonuses, Contests, Benefits

                  These three items really fall into the “perks” that a job offers. They are things that are not necessarily directly written into the employee contract, but are offered by the employee’s company in an effort to promote job satisfaction and productivity. Some companies offer extra pay for superior performances, others offer contests to the employees that can sell the most, close the most cases, or find a new client. Other companies will offer fringe benefits like the use of a company car or free cafeteria food. Regardless of the perk, the idea is to offer incentives that employees may not get with other companies.

                   

                  Social Opportunities

                  In order to increase the quality of work life, many companies have social committees or social engagements. This helps to foster personal relationships outside of the office or working conditions. When employees have the opportunity to better relate to their peers they feel a sense of belonging and this is key to retaining good employees. Examples of social engagements include:

                    • Lunch outings with colleagues.
                    • Staff parties (Christmas, Thanksgiving, New Year, etc.).
                    • Company Outings (Movies, Theatre, Dinners, Escape rooms, etc.).
                    • Pub Nights.
                    • Family Picnics (where employees bring their families to the event).

                  Below is an example of a workplace social engagement. As you will see in humorous video below, office parties can bring people closer together which is an important part of retaining quality employees and their teams.

                  Success Criteria

                  Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                  I can describe the three strategies used to retain quality employees.

                   

                  Management Opportunities (Education, Training, Skills, Experience)

                  In this forum you will research and discuss current management opportunities. You will also learn about the education/training that these positions require and link some skills that relate to employee retention to your new hire.

                  Forum 5-5C: Management Opportunities [CTA]
                  Vocabulary (Quizlet)
                  Stay Interview
                  Learning Log: 5-5 (Target: 2 hours) — Questionnaire
                  6
                  5-6: Performance Appraisals (2 hours)
                  Quizlet 5-6: Vocabulary Quizlet

                   

                   

                  Lesson Vocabulary

                  Quizlets

                  Use the following link to help you review vocabulary and concepts in this lesson. Feel free to explore the different modes on Quizlet such as Flashcards, Test, and Gravity. Quizlets are a great tool to help you  understand difficult concepts and prepare for unit tests and evaluations.

                  For this lesson, focus on the following words:

                    • 360 Degree Feedback
                    • Behaviourally Anchored Rating Scale (BARS)
                    • Comparison Method of Performance Appraisal
                    • Graph Rating Scale
                  Click on 5-6: Vocabulary Quizlet to open the resource.
                  ▼
                  Performance appraisals not only take corrective measures to improve employee performance, they are also a key resource for businesses to improve communication, set goals, increase employee confidence and determine future training needs. The primary reason for doing performance appraisals is to ensure that employees are fulfilling their obligations to the company and to point out areas of success and failure. This can result in a negative outcome for the employee, but more often than not, it is an opportunity to reinforce positive behaviour and success. In this section we will review the many types of performance reviews.
                  Lesson Overview — Key Idea

                  The key learning in this lesson revolves around performance appraisals, their benefits, and the different methods of performing them.

                  Learning Goals & Success Criteria
                  1. Explain the nature and importance of performance appraisals within an organization
                    • I can explain what a performance appraisal is
                    • I can state at least three benefits of a performance appraisal
                  2. Compare major performance appraisal methods and techniques
                  3. Explain the advantages and disadvantages of the different performance appraisal methods
                    • I can describe at least three different performance appraisal methods
                    • I can compare and contrast two different performance appraisal methods
                    • I can explain at least one advantage and one disadvantage of each method
                  Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)
                  • Critically think about performance appraisals
                  Benefits of Performance Appraisals

                  Performance appraisals involve an executive/manager evaluating an employee's performance. This encourages employee-employer communication which is an important element of business success.

                  Page 5-6A: Benefits of Performance Appraisals

                  Learning Goals

                    • Explain the nature and importance of performance appraisal within an organization.

                   

                  Performance Appraisals

                  A performance appraisal is a formal assessment/evaluation of an employee that is usually completed by his/her direct manager. They are usually done once per year and can include input from many different sources.

                  Benefits of Performing Performance Appraisals

                  1. Improved employee performance: employees are evaluated and given feedback as to how they can improve performance.
                  2. Goal setting: once employees understand where they need to improve, they can set goals for future success.
                  3. Increased confidence through constructive criticism: employees feel safer and can increase confidence if the assessment/evaluation is done formally with their future success in mind. These scheduled evaluations are better rather than only criticizing an employee whenever he/she makes a mistake.
                  4. Improved communication: having performance appraisals can improve the communication channel between the employee and his/her boss. Sitting down and discussing performance, goals and expectations can enrich the employee/employer relationship.
                  5. Determine future training: if many employees are experiencing the same difficulties with job performance, management can use these appraisals to determine which employee training sessions will be useful going forward.

                  The video below provides tips for performing effective performance appraisals.  These appraisals allow business leaders to set goals for their employees which ultimately leads to enhanced future performance.

                  Success Criteria

                  Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                  I can explain what a performance appraisal is.

                  I can state at least three benefits of a performance appraisal.

                   

                  Methods of Performance Appraisal

                  Now that we have learned about the benefits of performing performance appraisals, let us learn more about methods of performance appraisal.

                  Page 5-6B: Methods of Performance Appraisal

                  Learning Goals

                    • Compare major performance appraisal methods and techniques.
                    • Explain the advantages and disadvantages of the different performance appraisal methods.

                     

                  Methods of Performance Appraisal

                  There are many ways that managers perform appraisals. Employees tend to fear performance appraisals when employers do not know how to effectively perform them.  Below is a humorous example of how a manager or executive should not conduct themselves in a performance appraisal.

                  Not only was the questioning ineffective and inappropriate, but even the seating arrangement in the above video did not convey that a fair conversation would be undertaken.  Managers and executives need to understand that mutual respect and fair assessment is at the heart of any performance appraisal.  

                   Comparison Method

                  This method falls into the category of a judgmental evaluation. The judgmental method is typified by a manager making judgments about employee performance by rating the employee against some predefined standard. In the comparison method of a judgmental evaluation, employees are not rated against a set of predefined standards; rather, they are rated against one another. An example of this type of evaluation would be a manager rating the sales performance of his/her sales force. If employee A, B, and C all made over one million dollars in sales this year, then employee D may get a “below standard” rating for selling $800,000 worth of products. 

                   

                   Behaviourally Anchored Rating Scale

                  The Behaviourally Anchored Rating Scale (BARS) is a system of rating employees based on the behaviours they exhibit. Much like a rubric, there are a number of levels or ratings in a BARS system. For example, an employee may be rated on how well he takes suggestions for improvement on a scale of 1 to 5:

                    1. The employee does not listen to any suggestions.
                    2. The employee listens to the suggestion and then proceeds to complete the task without implementing any suggestions.
                    3. The employee listens to the suggestions and attempts to implement some of the suggestions into the task.
                    4. The employee listens to the suggestions and attempts to implement all suggestions into the task.
                    5. The employee listens to the suggestions, repeats back his/her understanding of the suggestions and then implements all suggestions into the task asking for help or clarification when necessary.

                  The assessor/evaluator would then circle or assign a number to the employee that best describes the employee’s behaviour in the circumstances described. Another example can be seen below.

                   

                   Graphic Rating Scale

                  The graphic rating scale asks pre-selected questions to the assessor/evaluator about the employee and has them rate the employee in terms of agreement. The evaluator can strongly disagree with the statement, strongly agree with the statement, or land somewhere in the middle. An example of this type of rating scale can be seen below: 

                  Question:

                  The employee is always on time for business meetings.

                  1

                  Strongly Agree

                  2

                  Somewhat Agree

                  3

                  Neither Agree nor Disagree

                  4

                  Somewhat Disagree

                  5

                  Strongly Disagree

                   

                   360 Degree Feedback:

                  This form of feedback is more qualitative in nature and accepts evaluative input from staff who work with the employee. The 360 degree component ensures that there is feedback from all directions. Therefore, the employee will be evaluated by his/her manager, colleagues and subordinates. Most of the time in this type of feedback, open ended questions are asked to other employees and the data is organized and given to the manager who is usually the ultimate end evaluator.

                   

                   Objective Checklists

                  In many jobs, evaluation is done as an objective checklist. This ensures equality among all employees, as there is very little room for judgment error. Often times, the criteria in the list is black and white and can be assessed by many people – all of whom will arrive at the same conclusion. An example of the objective checklist is below.

                  Did the employee…

                  bring in three new clients this year? 
                  make over one million dollars in sales this year? 
                  receive ten positive customer reviews this year?   
                  receive less than two negative customer reviews this year?   
                  attend two professional development training sessions? 

                   

                  Success Criteria

                  Before moving on to the next section, make sure you understand the following:

                  I can describe at least three different performance appraisal methods.

                  I can compare and contrast at least two different performance appraisal methods.

                  I can explain at least one advantage and one disadvantage of each of the performance appraisal methods.

                   

                  Discussion Forum

                  This next activity will give you the opportunity to demonstrate your learning. Now that you have completed the lesson, participate in the discussion forum.

                  Forum 5-6C: Reflect your Thoughts - Performance Appraisals [CTA]

                  5-7: Unit 5 Highlights (Review)
                  ▼
                  These unit highlights will summarize the main concepts from the lessons of Unit 5. You can also use this page to check if you understand all of the concepts covered in Unit 5 and prepare for the unit test.
                  5-1: Organizational Structures
                  • Vocabulary: Organizational Structures, Vision, Vertical Hierarchy, Sales, Operations, Team Structure
                  • Understand the three primary traditional organizational structures: Functional, Divisional, and Matrix
                  • Explain the three primary contemporary organizational structures: Team, Network, and Boundaryless
                  • Explain the advantages and disadvantages of each organizational structure
                  5-2: Organizational Design
                  • Vocabulary: Middle Managers, Manager, Theory Y, Shorter Chain of Command, Decentralization, Increased Empowerment, Organic Structures, Productivity, Negotiations, Synergy, Empowerment, Communication, Organizational Design
                  • Explain the role of the manager in dealing with trends in organizational design structures
                  • Understand how elements of organizational design support positive corporate culture (Communication Channels, Team Structures, Alternative Work Schedules, Employee Empowerment)
                  5-3: Organizing the Work Environment
                  • Vocabulary: The Master/Slave Relationship, The Symbiotic Relationship, The Dual Exploitative Relationship, The Common Goal Relationship, Fostering, Meaning of Work, Psychological Contract, Quality of Work Life, Job Satisfaction, Personal Growth, Engagement, Variety of Skills, Task Identity, Task Significance, Autonomy, Job Rotation, Job Enrichment, Job Enlargement, Job Simplification
                  • Explain the four major types of employee-employer relationships
                  • Describe factors that foster a good employee-employer relationship
                  • Understand the major principles of job design
                  • Explain the various alternative types of work settings: Job Sharing, Self-Managed Teams, Flextime, Compressed Workweeks, Bankable Days, Shift Work Maximums
                  5-4: Human Resource Process
                  • Vocabulary: Recruitment, Goal Setting, Training and Development, Compensation and Benefits, Performance Appraisal, Career and Leadership Management, Termination, Wages, Employment Equity, Health and Safety, Employee Rights, Bargaining Agreements, HR Process, Planning, Selection
                  • Explain the various stages in the HR process
                  • Analyze the legal considerations in the HR process
                  • Understand Human Resources and their work to the overall goals of an organization
                  5-5: Human Resource Strategies
                  • Vocabulary: Ritz-Carlton Basics, Quality Employees, Employee Training, Job Enrichment and Job Enlargement, Corporate Strategy, Quality Workforce
                  • Explain the two strategies in developing quality workforce: Initial Orientation and Training, Career and Professional Development
                  • Understand concepts in retaining quality workforce: Stay Interviews, Bonuses, Contests, Benefits, Social Opportunities
                  5-6: Performance Appraisals
                  • Vocabulary: Performance Appraisal, Goal Setting, Training, Constructive Criticism, Confidence, Comparison Method, Behaviourally Anchored Rating Scale, Graphic Rating Scale, 360 Degree Feedback, Objective Checklists
                  • Explain the benefits of performing performance appraisals
                  • Describe the different performance appraisal methods with advantages and disadvantages

                  Final Project
                  Part A (25%) + Part B (5%) • 15 hours • Section 48
                  ▼
                  Congratulations, you have reached an important milestone in this course by arriving at the final evaluation! What a ride it has been! This means that you are now ready to show the knowledge and skills you have learned in the course.
                  A
                  FP-A: Final Project — Part A In-Class Assessment (25%)
                  ▼
                  This is an in-class, proctored written assessment where students analyze a real-world leadership and management case study. The purpose is to evaluate their ability to apply BOH4M concepts to organizational scenarios, demonstrating both critical thinking and problem-solving.
                  Students will demonstrate the following:
                  • Knowledge & Understanding: Demonstrates knowledge of leadership and management theories and terminology
                  • Thinking & Inquiry: Uses analytical and critical thinking to assess organizational challenges and possible solutions
                  • Communication: Presents ideas clearly and logically, using appropriate business and leadership vocabulary
                  • Application: Applies leadership and management concepts to the case study and makes well-reasoned recommendations
                  Success Criteria
                  • A. Foundations of Management: Assess the role of management; use proper business vocabulary; evaluate how ethics and social responsibility affect management
                  • B. Leading: Apply understanding of human behaviour; describe how group dynamics work; identify and apply proper leadership techniques
                  • C. Management Challenges: Explain how communication works; evaluate strategies for stress and conflict; compare different motivation theories
                  • D. Planning and Controlling: Analyze importance of planning; demonstrate appropriate planning tools and techniques; analyze strategic planning; analyze response to change; assess importance of control
                  • E. Organizing: Explain different organizational structures; assess how structures change; evaluate the role of human resources
                  For Optimal Success

                  Students should review Unit Highlights for each unit (1-6, 2-5, 3-5, 4-7, 5-7) and review the feedback provided for Case Studies in the course (1-1F, 1-4E, 3-3D, 3-8).

                  OPEN BOOK: Students can access all course pages and lessons during the in-class assignment. Students should have knowledge of the topics in each lesson, be prepared to navigate to the Unit Highlights lessons quickly, and make sure there is a clear understanding of Key Course Vocabulary and their related concepts.

                  Duration: This in-class assignment is designed to be completed in 2 hours. The assignment will remain open for 3 hours.

                  Important: You are not allowed to use Artificial Intelligence or tools such as Grammarly to generate responses while writing this in-class assignment. All writing must be in your own words. Use of ANY external tools (search engines, translator apps, etc.) while completing this in-class assignment will result in 0.

                  All responses will be graded according to the KICA Achievement Chart.

                  Quiz *FP-A: Final Project - Part A In-Class Assessment [ICA] 25%
                  B
                  FP-B: Final Project — Part B (5%)
                  ▼
                  By now you have developed an understanding of business leadership concepts and theories related to decisions made every day. A fundamental knowledge of business leadership is important when making career decisions. In this assignment, you will record a 2-minute video to reflect on 2 specific assignments from the course. You can choose work from your graded formatives, content formatives, or summative assignments. In your video, you will discuss what you learned while completing the assignments and how the knowledge learned in completing the tasks will help with your intended career choice or personal life decisions.
                  Assignment *FP-B: Final Project - Part B 5%
                  Important!: This is the final summative evaluation activity in this course. Please check your Student Progress page to ensure that all summative activities have been submitted. Deadline extensions for missed activities are not allowed once this activity is complete.

                   
                  *FP: Final Project - Part B [5%]

                  This activity will be counted in your final grade

                  Overall Expectations & Learning Goals

                  • Assess the role of management within an organization. (A1) 
                  • Demonstrate the use of appropriate communication techniques related to business management. (A2) 
                  • Evaluate the impact of issues related to ethics and social responsibility on the management of organizations. (A3) 
                  • Apply an understanding of human behaviour to explain how individuals and groups function in the workplace. (B1) 
                  • Demonstrate an understanding of group dynamics. (B2) 
                  • Demonstrate an understanding of proper leadership techniques in a variety of situations. (B3)  
                  • Demonstrate an understanding of the communication process within the workplace. (C1) 
                  • Evaluate the strategies used by individuals and organizations to manage stress and conflict. (C2) 
                  • Compare theories of how to motivate individuals and teams in a productive work environment. (C3) 
                  • Analyse the importance of planning to the success of an organization within the workplace. (D1) 
                  • Demonstrate an understanding of appropriate planning tools and techniques in a variety of situations. (D2) 
                  • Analyse the relationship between strategic planning and the success of an organization. (D3) 
                  • Analyse how companies respond to internal and external pressures for change. (D4) 
                  • Assess the importance of control in management. (D5) 
                  • Demonstrate an understanding of the various organizational structures used to manage the workforce effectively. (E1) 
                  • Assess the ways in which organizational structures have changed to adapt to the changing nature of work. (E2) 
                  • Evaluate the role of human resources within an organization. (E3) 

                   Assignment Overview

                  By now you have developed an understanding of business leadership concepts and theories related to decisions made every day.  A fundamental knowledge of business leadership is important when making career decisions.  In this assignment, you will record a 2-minute video to reflect on 2 specific assignments from the course.  You can choose work from your graded formatives, content formatives, or summative assignments.  In your video, you will discuss what you learned while completing the assignments and how the knowledge learned in completing the tasks will help with your intended career choice or personal life decisions.   

                   

                  Task  
                   
                  Step 1: Reflect on What you Have Learned in the Course / Make a Connection  
                  • Review your assignment submissions from Unit 1 through Unit 5.  
                  • Identify 1 assignment from Units 1 - 3 and 1 assignment from Units 4 - 5 that you will be using for your reflection. When identifying an assignment consider what you learned and the skills you developed. 
                  • Summarize the key ideas learned in each assignment related to business leadership.  You may want to use the functions of management as a guide.   
                  • Identify and describe 3 specific transferable skills learned in these assignments.   
                  • Identify 2 specific examples of careers related to a specific concept from Unit 1 – 3 (Foundations of Management, Leading, Management Challenges) and 2 specific examples of a career related to specific concepts from Unit 4 – 5 (Planning/Controlling and Organizing) in which the skills and concepts you learned would be relevant and applicable.   
                  • Identify and explain how 1 specific idea or skill you learned in the entire course could be applied to your future personal life decisions.   
                   
                  Step 2: Prepare your Response 
                  • Organize your ideas and notes into an oral response that is 2 minutes in length that answers the question: How do the concepts and skills learned in this course apply to my future career and personal financial decisions?   
                  • To create your response:  
                    • Create an outline or list of key ideas in the order you wish to discuss them. Include all the information from Step 1.  
                    • Use the vocabulary, terminology, and concepts from the course.  
                    • Use point form. It is not necessary to create a fully written script. If you do, make sure you do not read directly from it.   
                    • Order your ideas so that they are logical. Use transition words to move from one idea to the next.  
                    
                  Step 3: Record your Response.  
                  • Practice delivering your response until you are comfortable and can deliver your presentation with clear pronunciation and without hesitation.   
                    • Speak loudly and clearly.  
                    • Speak in a formal tone. Avoid contractions, slang, and informal language. This is an academic presentation.   
                    • Speak at a reasonable pace.   
                    • Focus on maintaining good eye contact! Do NOT read your notes or text. Look at the camera!  
                    • Pay attention to your body language, facial expressions, and hand gestures. 
                    • Demonstrate your interest in the content you are delivering.  
                    • Make sure you can pronounce all the words you are using. If not, practice!  
                    • Enunciate clearly.  
                  • Record your presentation.   
                    • Ensure that when you are recording, your face, shoulders, and hands are visible.  
                    • Find a quiet space to make your recording.   
                    • Check that your voice is audible before submitting. If not, re-record.  
                  • Submit your reflection as an mp4.  
                  For more support on how to make an effective presentation, please review the Academic Skills Module How to Present Effectively.   
                   
                  Submission Requirements  
                  • Submit an MP4 video file for this assignment.   

                   

                  Submission Instructions

                  • Once you are ready to add a submission, make sure you are using Google Chrome. The video response tool will not load on any other browser.
                  • You will have 2 options to choose from to upload your video. Refer to THIS MANUAL to understand how to record and upload your video using either option 1 or option 2.
                  • Once you have read the manual and are ready to submit your assignment, click on the "Add Submission" button at the bottom of this page.


                   
                   
                   
                   

                   Success Criteria

                  You will be assessed on the success criteria that are listed in this rubric:  

                  1. I can select samples of my work that demonstrate the concepts and transferable skills I learned. (A2)  

                  1. I can summarize the concepts learned about foundations of management, or leading, or management challenges. (A1; A2; A3; B1; B2; B3; C1; C2; C3)  

                  1. I can summarize the concepts learned about planning/controlling or organizing. (A2; D1; D2; D3; D4; D5; E1; E2; E3) 

                  1. I can identify and describe the transferable skills of business leadership that I have learned in this course.  (A2)  

                  1. I can logically organize my thoughts to communicate clearly. (A2) 

                  1. I can use appropriate business leadership vocabulary from the course in my oral presentation to communicate my understanding of course content.  (A2)  

                  1. I can speak at an appropriate pace and tone (with inflection) and can deliver a presentation in an engaging way without reading directly off my notes/script and my pronunciation is clear and accurate (A2) 

                  1. I can identify and describe careers related to the business leadership concepts and skills related to course concepts.  (A2) 

                  1. I can identify and explain how the skills and concepts of business leadership could be applied to my future personal life decisions.  (A2)

                   
                   
                   

                    How to Submit

                    • This activity is meant to be completed by you. Please ensure that you follow the academic policies that are outlined in your Academic Integrity contract.
                    • Please review your assignment before submitting, errors in uploading will result in a mark of 0.
                    • Submit your completed assignment using the "Add Submission" button located at the bottom of this page.

                  Final Reports and Reflection

                  Take a few minutes now to reflect on your work habits and set realistic goals for yourself in the next stage of your education.
